name: Discovery Battling T-Rex Game
description:
Lunge, dodge and attack in a head-to-head battle between two mighty foes.

Tail controllers enable full control over the action
Built-in sensors keep score
Powerful roaring sound effects
Articulated dinosaur action
Realistic prehistoric landscape
Step back in time as dueling dinos roar, snarl and battle each other. Just grab the tail controller and challenge a friend to see which dinosaur rules.

name: Black Hole Explorer
description:
Black Hole Explorer is an interesting children's game about building a rocket to travel to and study a black hole. The game is designed to be light-hearted, educational and fun.

The game is played in three steps:

First construct your ship using what funds you have available -- $10 million to $60 million. Your ship must have probes, radiation shielding, gravitational strength and power to drive your spaceship.

And, don't forget to name your spaceship!

Next, travel to the black hole and enter into a low enough orbit with it to launch your probes.

There are spaces around the black hole to draw Event cards that may help or hinder your mission.

Finally, escape the black hole's gravity (which is harder than getting there), return to Earth and study the data from your probes. Did you gather enough information to win the Nobel Prize? The first player back gets to roll for the chance first. But is he or she fails, then the next finisher gets the chance.

The game has competitive and collaborative playing options, and also information for playing the game with large groups.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Variable Player Powers

name: Plunder
description: A three-player trick taking game in which each player gains control of an exposed dummy after winning a trick. The trump suit for the hand changes depending on which player controls the dummy.

name: You're Talking Absolute...Football
description: This is a football (soccer) trivia game. The game includes a plastic ball with electronics which operates as a timer and a noisemaker. Teams of players compete to answer questions to be the first to score seven goals and win the match. Red and yellow penalty cards can be given to players on the opposing team.

name: Muntslag
description:
English translation from the box:

Muntslag are a tense tactical game, where by buying and selling of currencies, the player can create the winning collection.

The first player who has collected a series of currency on the market is the winner. The player builds its series of currency by buying and selling currencies on the market and trading with other players.

name: Pop-Dog
description: Players pop a die and turn a block of the same color shown on the die. The winner is the first to construct a picture of Pop Dog.

name: The Age of Fighting Sail
description: Naval miniatures rules for the Napoleonic period. Single ship to Fleet Actions. Trafalgar fought in 6 hours by 30 players. Single ship engagements last from 10 to 20 minutes. Easy to learn, fast playing.

name: Katana
description: Tactical miniatures rules for Samurai battles.

name: Gunfight!
description: Miniatures rules for the Old West - Cowboys, gunslingers, Civil War, and Indians.
categories: American Civil War, American Indian Wars, American West, Miniatures, Wargame

name: Screaming G.I.'s
description: An innovative set of WWII skirmish rules.

name: Cavalry Game
description:
This educational card game was intended to teach children "the names and numbers of the British cavalry regiments". The cards are illustrated with the various regiments, and the instructions note that: "It is taken for granted that the players know that there are seven Dragoon Guard Regiments". Players compete through drawing and exchanging cards to complete sets of the regiments, with the player completing the most regiments winning.

This game appears to have been published sometime between 1900 and 1920.
publishers: De La Rue, H. P. Gibson & Sons, The International Card Company

name: Robin Hood Merry Card Game
description: Robin Hood Merry Card Game has 48 cards depicting Robin Hood and members of his outlaw gang and villains from the story.

name: WarPaint
description: Tactical miniatures rules for the American Indian wars.
categories: American Indian Wars, American West, Miniatures, Wargame

name: Post Office
description: The winner becomes the Postmaster by returning to the Post Office after delivering all their mail. Plan mail routes which can be altered by draw cards.
mechanics: Pick-up and Deliver, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Lingo Word Dice
description:
Not to be confused with the Lingo games which are played with pegs, cards or scrabble-like tiles.

The 25 letter dice are placed at random into the spaces of the grid. The 12 scoring pegs are placed in the holes in the corners.

Players then take turns to think of words beginning with the letters showing on the tops of the dice in the grid & each time a player names an acceptable word they remove the appropriate die from the grid & keep it (for scoring at the end of the game).

The winner is the player with the highest number of points !

name: The Wandering Merchant
description:
In The Wandering Merchant, players play the roles of merchants buying and selling goods. They drive carts pulled by horses transporting them between small villages separated by dangerous wilderness areas in a fantasy setting. The goal is to be the first player to earn a fixed amount of money. Players can also upgrade their carts to transport more goods per trip or buy more horses to travel faster.

This game was an entry to the Good Portsmanship contest in March 2007, and it's based of Merchant of Venus by Richard Hamblen.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Pick-up and Deliver, Trading

name: Equil√≠brio
description:
Board consists of a trail with three separate parts. A central part, where the players must combine 5 balls in two colors to match the pattern they have at hand, and a left and right section with three balls each, where the players put the balls to feed the central section.

Very similar (if not identical) to Aya

name: Epoque
description:
Epoque is a futuristic wargame system which deals about battles between three futuristic factions.

Main battle units in Epoque are M.A.P.S., huge mechanical armours. The battle system uses proprietary 1/48 scale models for M.A.P.S. and 30mm miniatures (for infantry), plus various support vehicles.

The rule set allow players to use other models and miniatures in the game.
categories: Miniatures, Modern Warfare, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: McDonald's PlayPlace Game
description:
McDonald’s PlayPlace Game is a children's game in which players follow a colorful track leading to and through a three dimensional game board resembling a McDonald's PlayPlace. Players start at home and follow a path to the PlayPlace. Once there, they must turn their token over, indicating that they have removed their shoes, before they can continue. The first player to go through the PlayPlace, put their shoes back on, and make it home is the winner.

On the path there are some arrows that lead forward and some that lead backward. Players advance by spinning a color wheel and moving to the indicated color.

name: Caccia al Tesoro
description:
Cluedo-like game from a TV show.
The players try to find treasures and move by helicopter on the map.
Introduced from a famous dj of '80: Jacques "Jocelyn" Antoine.

name: Up There Cazaly
description:
Up There Cazaly is a 2-player game that simulates the game of Australian Rules Football. Players use cards and dice to control the ball and attempt to score.

Players pick 6 Cazalies to play on 6 of the 22 positions of the field. On your turn you move the ball along one of the routs from position to position. If you have one of your Cazalies at the new position (and your opponent does not), move again. If your opponent has a Cazaly there, they get possession of and move the ball. If there are no Cazalies there, flip an "Umpy" (umpire) card to see who gets possession and the next move.

When you get to one of the positions close to the gaol, roll a dice to see if you score.

This was a licensed VFL (Victorian Football League) product.

Game Contents:

Score pad
44 "Cazaly" Player cards (2 sets of 22 numbered cards)
48 "Umpy" cards
Plastic football
Game board
Six-sided die
Rules insert

name: Emperor of China
description: Emperor of China is a card game simulating the rise and fall of dynastic empires throughout the turbulent history of China. The winner of the current hand becomes the new Emperor and gains Victory points. The other players are Rebels and Barbarians looking to gain power next time.

name: Conquests of Charlemagne
description: Conquests of Charlemagne is a card game depicting the exploits of Charles the Great, King of the Franks, 768-814 AD. Players carefully play cards to be the first to conquer 10 regions and gain Victory points while preventing their opponents' from doing the same.

name: Northern Wars
description:
Northern Wars is a Card game that depicts the conflicts in Northern Europe circa 13th-15th Centuries AD. 12 unique Major powers available each with their own special ability. Players accumulate Army counters and Territory Tokens and they draw from Battle Decks and Event Decks. A complete copy of the rules is available for free at:
http://www.angelfire.com/games2/warpspawn/NW.html

name: Jeu du Veldiv
description: A French 1930s game, of which there were four versions. The first version only had 6 riders (one per team, no rules for team racing). Later versions had twelve riders (two per team). The cheaper versions had cardboard riders, the "deluxe" version had metal riders. Veldiv, short for Vélodrome d'Hiver (winter velodrome), was a very popular cycling track in Paris.

name: Punic Wars Combined Arms
description:
Punic Wars Combined Arms is a tactical level Boardgame for 2 players. One will be Hannibal and his Punic forces trying to overtake Scipio and his Roman army. No cards or Dice are used, rather, pieces have Chess like movements with application of Force at a distance. Different Units have different abilities per their historical counterparts. Lead your Cohorts to Victory! A complete copy of the rules are available for free at:
http://www.angelfire.com/games2/warpspawn/PWCA.html

name: Word of Mouth
description:
Waddingtons Word of Mouth: A quick-witted word game of imagination and bluff.

From the back of the box:

Word of Mouth is a modern variation of an old game in which players select obscure words from the dictionary and try to make up bluff definitions. In Word of Mouth, the fun has been enhanced as players must place their best on the one definition they feel fits the "official" definition. The first player to fill his/her home base with betting chips wins, so that the name of the game is to come up with the most believable sounding definition, be it fact of fiction.

The beauty of this game is that it isn't necessarily for high-brows. If a player's vocabulary knowledge is shaky but his imagination and bluffing skills are tops, he could easily win the game by persuading the other players to pass their betting chips his way.

name: Remagen 1945
description:
On March 7th, 1945, the Americans captured one of the last standing across the mighty Rhine River in Germany. It was pure luck that the Germans had failed to blow the bridge up.

Operation Loralie, the codeword to destroy this key crossing and been fumbled. Fumbled badly by the Germans. Confusion reigned on the German side and the Americans seized the bridge.

Now, the battle began. Germany’s “wonder weapons” were all directed at the bridge, from V-2 Rockets (which came close), jet bombers, massive Jagdtiger, Jagdpanther, Tiger II tanks and even SS Frogmen, all took their turn at sending the bridge to the bottom of the Rhine. The 9th, 11th and Lehr Panzer Divisions attempted to destroy the American bridgehead but were low of fuel.

The game captures this pure luck situation, as at any moment, luck can change the course of the battle, as in real life! All the elements are present that were there in the battle. What might have happened had the bridge been destroyed after the Americans had crossed? or, had the German panzers been able to attack as a coherent force?

The game uses a point to point movement system, easy to learn and hard to master. Daily turns, units range from company to battalions. The Americans must capture the bridge and cross to expand the bridgehead.
categories: Print & Play, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Movement Points, Point to Point Movement

name: Boer en Rooinekspel
description:
A Dutch board game produced at the time of the Anglo-Boer War.
One player represents the Boers (literally "farmers", the name then used for people of Dutch descent in Southern Africa). The other player the British. The players roll and move their pawns around the board. The Boers have to arrive in Cape Town, while the British have to arrive in Pretoria.
The first player to arrive at their destination wins the game.

name: Insite: The Party Game of Predicting the Future
description: Insite is a unique concept in games because it opens up the universe inside your own mind. Includes manual, board and cards. Appears to be somewhat similar to tarot cards.
publishers: John N. Hansen Co., Inc., Reach Incorporated

name: The Ginger Meggs Paper Chase Game
description: A roll and move type game using the theme of Ginger Meggs, who is a famous cartoon boy in a long-running comic strip in Australia. Players compete to accomplish objectives on the board while avoiding challenges like bullies.
publishers: John Sands Pty Ltd, Rutland Cowling Smith and Associates

name: Reiter and Tercio
description:
Reiter and Tercio is a simple card driven wargame with a Pike & Shot Theme. It simulates a 16-17th Century Battlefield. Each figure represents a company or unit of men. Win by capturing your opponent’s Field Commander or Camp. Rules for different troop and terrain types. A free copy of the rules can be found at:
http://www.angelfire.com/games2/warpspawn/RAT.html

name: Jive Bunny's Chart Challenge
description: Jive Bunny's Chart Challenge is a game using the themed cartoon character of "Jive Bunny." Players compete in the music industry for the success of their career, with the winner the one who makes it to the top of the charts.

name: Party & Co: Ingenios
description: This is a Party game from the same creators of Party & Co. The players have to come up with crazy definitions for very original words.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Open Drafting, Paper-and-Pencil, Voting
publishers: Diset S. A., Nordic Games GmbH

name: Hungry Huey
description:
Hungry Huey is a purple monster with an open mouth into which players reach to extract a particular set of "grubs." If the players disturb Huey while they are reaching into his mouth, Huey responds by vomiting.

From the publisher: "Reach into Huey's 'real feel' gooey guts and risk vomtastic gastric action as you try and rescue your ghastly grubs from Huey's bloated tum. You need to get the right four grubs to win, but watch out - if he vomits - you'll have to put one back!"

name: Scrabble Junior Madeline
description: The Scrabble Junior Madeline edition features the adventurous little girl Madeline. She and her friends (Miss Clavel, Pepito and the eleven other girls) are out for a walk in the park. The board features pictures and the corresponding words for the people and things they encounter. Players earn one of Madeline's little yellow hats when they match their letters to the already spelled out words on the board. The board is two-sided, one side for French and the other English. Included with the game are 18 bilingual flash cards to teach French and English.

name: The Great War
description:
The Great War is a World War I themed game along the lines of Axis and Allies. It introduces many new units, such as blimps, railway guns, cruiser and armored cars. As well as, aspects particular to the Great War, such as poison gas, trench warfare, convoys and railways. Additionally, neutral powers are subject to political influencing in order to draw them into one or other alliance.
The game is primarily available as a MapView module, but can also be played as a table top game.
mechanics: Area Movement, Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling

name: Shark Attack! Bowling
description: This is a simple bowling game in which players take turns winding up a motorized shark and aiming it at six fish-shaped pins placed 2.5 to 3 meters away (8-10 ft) on a hard floor. The motor is built such that the shark starts by moving slowly, but then quickly lunges forward. A steering dial on the shark allows for hooks.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Animals, Children's Game, Electronic

name: The Glorious Cause
description: The Glorious Cause is an introductory game on the American Revolution on a strategic level. It has an area movement map, a one-page set of rules and low number of counters.

name: Procession
description:
Procession is an abstract strategy game of trying to move a master piece (queen) across a chess board along routes projected horizontally and vertically from 5 setup pieces (pawns).

Full rules are at: http://www.luchacabra.com/?p=55

name: Selva
description:
Played on a 13x13 Go board with go stones and 2 special stones each ("tigers"), the game is mostly about moving stones such that they bump opponents stones, with the hope to have them move past your tigers where they will get eaten. The winner is first to eat the opponents tiger or eat all the opponents stones, or immobilize the opponents tiger.

Full rules at: http://www.luchacabra.com/?p=34

Online Play


Super Duper Games

name: Tris
description:
Tris combines some of the ideas of Tetris and Connect 4, with the further idea of pushing stones and them falling. It is played on a chess board, and players alternate either placing stones or moving them. Place stones can be placed on either edge, or a at the top of a column of stones from an edge. Stones can be moved one space left or right into an unoccupied space, and if it is unsupported, they "fall" to the bottom. Four stones in a row of your color are "captured" and removed from the board, the remaining stones "fall", and if more 4-in-a-rows result, this recurses. Stones in a full row are locked. Winner is first to capture 12 of their own pieces, or to fill their side of the board with locked rows.

Full rules at: http://www.luchacabra.com/?p=37

name: Tower of Terror
description:
This is a childrens game Ages 4 and up

The aim is to race to the tower with your playing pieces and be the first to get one there.

On your turn you choose which of 2 possible ways you will move a playing piece:

a- running, your piece stands up vertically in the holes and you throw 2 dice

b- crawling, your pieces crawls on its belly. You only throw 1 dice

You move according to the number on the dice. For each barrel symbol shown you get a chance to make an attacking move. Lift the barrel up to the top of the tower and swing it to knock out other players' pieces.

name: Original Dessert
description:
The box can easily be mistaken for a box of chocolates. Which is of course where the name of the game pitches in.
During the game the cards allow you to choose from 6 different options: to give definitions of difficult words, to judge over historical facts, to complete proverbs, to act out a word, to solve riddles, thereby going through several steps, and to improvise a story.
The game is good for about half an hour of acting, tale telling and guessing.

name: Pirate Attack
description:
Subtitled "Classic Seafaring Action" Pirate Attack is a game based on the public domain Battleship.

It comes with a suitable pirate themed game board and pieces including pirate ships with sails that are knocked off when hit. The game differs from the classic game by adding two special weapons. Cannonballs are the standard shots, but players also have the limited options to use "Shrapnel" or a "Telescope Targeting"

name: Bug Balancing
description: This is a dexterity/skill game for children involving the placement of ladybug pieces on the leaves of a palm tree. The palm tree leaves (fronds?) have various colored circles on them in rows from closest to the trunk to farthest away from the trunk. The tree leaves have some degree of movement, and if too much weight is placed on them, they will dip or bend down. Players take turn rolling a dice with various colored sides, and then placing a ladybug piece on a matching colored circle on a leaf. The goal of the game is to get rid of all your ladybugs, but if your placement causes ladybugs to fall, those pieces become yours. The game continues until one player is out of ladybugs. The leaves have different lengths and there are three sizes of ladybugs (small, medium and large), so there is some definite strategy about which ladybug gets placed where. The tree, leaves, and ladybugs are all nicely formed and painted wooden pieces.

name: Spanish Fury: Voyage!
description:
Spanish Fury, Voyage! is a STAND ALONE game of Corsair activity in the Caribbean from 1550 to 1585. The Corsair player (or players) enters the region with ships packed with either Trade Good or troops (usually both) in hopes of turning a profit by hook or by crook. The Spanish Empire player must see that he prevents the Corsairs from succeeding (and discouraging others) while at the same time running the Caribbean efficiently so as to not lose his Vice-royalty (is that a word?).

FREE game to download here: http://perfectcaptain.50megs.com/sfvoyage.html
categories: Miniatures, Nautical, Pike and Shot, Pirates, Print & Play, Renaissance

name: Alte Spiele
description:
Alte Spiele -- Games of Old -- Jeux d'Autrefois
1975 Calendar

This was a 1975 promotional calendar from printing press manufacturer Roland Offset. it contained six roll-and-move style games from the 1800s.

From the first page:
"Present-day games have contemporary goals: The imagination envisions planetary flight and the psycho tests of the psychologist are dinner table discussion. In this context, who would like to hazard his fortune on a throw of dice? Even in cases where chance is permitted, workaday personal and occupational practices persist - the neighbor is shunted aside or his property gloatingly purchased at auction...

All of this was not evident at the beginning of our rushing century. All one wanted to do at the end of the day was to relax. Television, radio, record player and cinema were unknown. The first motorists purchased their fuel at the apothecary and the operator of a magic-lantern illuminated his coloured glass slides with a kerosene lamp. The village squares were still the site of public wells, although some well-to-do people already had gaslight. Geese were allowed to graze the entire summer. Skiing was just beginning to be recognized as a sport. A race track for horses in the city was a novelty. And a locomotive engineer was admired by all the boys: 'What a man!'

Games of old reflect this world of the small adventures, where it was an event if a train derailed or even when a fowl flew its coop. Then in those days games were modern and exciting. Even for their producers..."

January/February - "The Ski Race"
March/April - "The Tramway"
May/June - "We Take The Train"
July/August - "The Goose Game"
September/October - "The Automobile Race"
November/December - "Commerce And Trade"
categories: Animals, Children's Game, Economic, Sports, Trains

name: Dugout Dreams
description:
Dugout Dreams is a baseball simulation that used one 20-sided die and two 10-sided dice. The game comes with 17 pitching charts on 5 pages, a color playing field on which to keep track of outs and base runners, score sheets, and various charts, including: fly outs, hit & run, hitting direction for left- and right-handed batters, runner advancement, ground outs, hold/steal, errors, and steals. Teams are available from various seasons, including some recent ones and 1926, 1948, and 1971. Players' ratings are listed on 8.5 x 11" card stock, one page for each team. (There are no individual cards in this game.) Ratings are based on actual performance from these respective seasons.

To play, roll a d20 and cross-reference the result with the Batting Rating on Player's Batting listing with that of the Pitcher's Chart, where the following results are found: blank (an out), W (a possible walk), or H (a hit). Each of these results requires an additional 2-4 rolls of two d10 dice to resolve a given play.

Pitchers are rated for Start/Relief effectiveness, walks, strike outs, home runs yielded, ground balls, fly balls, stamina, hold ability, and fielding.

Batters are rated in the following categories: Batting, HR, 1B, 2B, 3B, W, K, Fielding, Range/Arm, SAC, BS (base stealing) and BR (base running).

name: Dragon War: Pandora's Box
description:
This set contains 1 board game card with 12 Pandora's Box cards. If a player dares to peek inside Pandora's box, evil sprites can be unleashed upon the board.

Expansion to Dragon War
categories: Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Fighting
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move, Variable Player Powers

name: Dragon War: Underwater Way Set
description:
This set includes 10 underwater cards that get inserted into the game. To pass through the underwater section one will need to get to air squares, or they will end up being easy prey for the massive underwater creatures in the underwater section.

Expansion to Dragon War
categories: Card Game, Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Fighting, Racing
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move, Variable Player Powers

name: Dragon War: Gypsy Caravan
description:
The Gypsy Caravan adds 1 oversize board with 4 cards for the board and 6 wares reference lists. This expansion allows players to pick up new weapons and powers that will help them make there way to the Dragon Throne.

Expansion to Dragon War
categories: Card Game, Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Fighting
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move, Variable Player Powers

name: On Q
description:
Scheduled for Essen 2007

A small 2-player abstract. The gameboard is a Q and on each space there are 2 stones. Stones have one of 4 colours and are neutral. Players take turns to remove stones from the board and place them in one line in front of them. Getting can only be done from either and of the Q, Placing can also be done to either and of the cue in front of the players.
The objective is to avoid stones with a colour not anotherwise in the cue.

name: Zamboni Wars
description:
A little roll-and-move shoot-'em-up game using a Treehouse set of icehouse pieces, Martian Coasters, and a 6-sided die.

Players use stacked nests of pyramids to represent a Zamboni with a giant laser on top - the mechanics are simple, run around the board, shoot at your opponent until you're the last one on the field.

Since the pieces are nested, each time your Zamboni is hit, another bit comes off, leaving a more vulnerable core piece to be shot at the next time. After three hits, you're out!

rules are here - http://icehousegames.org/wiki/index.php?title=Zamboni_Wars
mechanics: Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Hockey Action
description:
Hockey Action is a game of strategy and chance. The winner is the one who will scores the most goals by using the players in a strategic way, while benefiting from some elements of chance that the different cards might provide.

This game also provides you to be a coach because it's you who places your own players to fool your opponent. It provides you to be a hockey player by drawing the pass cards to get a shot on goal. You're also the goaltender by keeping secret your weak spot from your opponent.

Even if you don't know the rules of hockey, this game will gives you much pleasure. It's very easy to play and you'll be able soon to even beat experts on the matter.

name: Battsy Baseball
description: Box says this is an "Exciting Tabletop Baseball Game". Hidden pitching controls, pitch a fastball, slowball, high ball or sinker. Bat the ball with spring activated bat. Play and score like a real baseball game.

name: Whirling Derby
description:
The game is the successor of the Global Air Race game from the same company.
Game components are an 8 inch metal globe with large numbered and colour-coded base with integrated two-dimensional spinner, 4 coloured magnetic jet planes, 16 flight plan and 32 chance and a large lot of fuel cards, play money and a transparent distance finder.

You have to round the globe first, starting in New York in eastern direction. On the way you have to land on 4 pre-dealt cities depicted on the flight plan cards. You encounter hazards and have to refuel your plane.

In order to move you whirl the whole globe (hence the name of the game), and the two-dimensional spinner at the globe base connected to the globe shows on the inside what chance cards and hazards are encountered and if and how much you can refuel. On the outside is shown how many hours (points)you can fly and how much fuel is consumed.

And there is also a colour code depicted on the globe base, which adapts to the various countries spread all over the "world".
You have to take all these informations into account to work out the best route with the help of the transparent distance finder depicting the travel distances point-to-point.

There are also some extra advantages to gain achieving some goals during your travels (such as crossing the equator).
mechanics: Open Drafting, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Futboleo
description:
Futboleo is a very easy game based in questions about soccer, sports and culture.

Each payer must to ask questions about it, but also, has to draw and makes mimicry to win.

The box contains:

- A board
- 325 cards questions-answers
- 1 Dice
- 2 Pencils
- 1 Roulette
- 1 disc with ball form
- 1 sand clock
- Rules

name: Kainuupeli
description:
This is the Kainuu version of the Kaupunkipelit (City Games) series.

Unlike most games in the series, this one is not centered on a single city/town but rather a wider geographic area - in this case, the eastern-central Finland region of Kainuu, the capital of which is the town of Kajaani (and which is why there is no Kajaani version of the game).

Kaupunkipelit is a series of games, each of which is basically a light version of Monopoly localized to a city/region of Finland. The games promote local companies, councils, educational institutes etc. and were designed as a fund raising effort for local sports clubs.

The main differences between these games and Monopoly are:

-Instead of a "street" each square on the board represents a local business.
-There are no hotels or houses, but each square has two title deeds instead of just one, allowing two players to jointly own any location on the board.
-The majority of the event cards are trivia questions about the locality the game is set in.
-While the effects of the first two corner squares (Go and Jail in Monopoly) remain the same for every edition (Go and Stock Market Crash), the effect of the other two corners varies from edition to edition and is the only real difference between them (except for the trivia content, of course). They are typically also local businesses but without title deeds and thus no rent either, but some special effect instead, such as pass a turn or get an extra throw.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Stock Holding

name: Deutsches Museum: Das Erlebnis Spiel
description: We lack Quiz as a mechanism and Science as a theme. This is a non-trivial quiz based game based upon the superb and highly entertaining Science and Aeronautic Museum in Munich, Germany. Answer technical questions based on the different areas of study in the Museum, such as Flight and Astronomy, Communications, Energy, and move through the zones on the board. Gain more points the more you progress to the centre in tactical moves.
categories: Civilization, Educational, Electronic, Environmental, Industry / Manufacturing, Modern Warfare, Space Exploration, Transportation, Trivia

name: A.D.T. Messenger Boy
description: Very old track race game the object of which is to take a message to a certain location and then return home.

name: Dragon War: Escape from the Haunted House
description: This expansion to Dragon War adds nine cards and four key cards that create a Haunted House for all players to escape. This requires one of the keys, found in the dangerous shifting house.
categories: Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Fighting
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Dragon War: Artifacts of Avalon
description: This expansion to Dragon War adds 20 Magic Item cards for the players to use.
categories: Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Fighting
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Stirling Moss' Rally
description:
Another game of the scarce Pepys double feature series.

Game box contains 14 high speed cards, 14 low speed cards, 7 hazard cards (black letter) and 5 hazards (red letter).

For movement players use 6 car cards: Jaguar, Sunbeam Talbot, Riley, Bentley, MG and Ford Zephyr.

Added are 3 long card strips depicting various towns, scenes and check points along the route of the real Rally Monte Carlo.

Each player gets a hand of 4 cards.
In his turn, he can play a high speed or low speed card in order to move his car card 1 or only 1/2 length along the pictures of the movement strips.
If another player has layed out a movement card there is the possibility to lay a hazard card upon it.
The faster you travel the worser the hazards.
Play ceases at every check point, the later you come the more penalty points you score.
A new hand is dealt then.
After the last checkpoint game alters, the players have to fix for themselves if they want to travel high or low speed until they reach finish; no other card is then allowed.
After arrival at Monte Carlo a last point total is scored.

As with most Pepys card games the graphic artwork is astounding and adds to the atmosphere of the game. Nice little filler...
mechanics: Open Drafting, Point to Point Movement

name: Philmont: The Adventure Trail ... Game of Survival
description: Philmont The adventure trail ... Game of Survival after standard roll and move, draw a card and answer for reward or penalty. Questions involve animal identification, backpacking and camping knowledge, and knots (Philmont is a Boy Scout camp). The goal of the game is to get a certain number of reward chips for answering questions correctly.

name: Wettfahrt im Blitzzug
description:
Published circa 1955 (http://www.spielbox-online.de/indxtemp.html?/sbmain/ersatzs....).

Nice family game where you have to deliver the pre-dealt wooden chips onto the corresponding circles on the board.

At the same time you have to visit as much of the 36 cities (each one provided with a card)on the map as possible. These are of 3 different values regarding how large they are.

You have to watch out that your visits include 4 cities at the far east, south, north and west borders of the board and to avoid the already laid out green chips: If you travel by one you have to pick it up.

Game ends when all 36 cities have been visited or if a single player has delivered all his green chips and is in posession of at least 8 city cards.

Points are scored for each city card to its full value for the player, each green chip scores 2 and each border city not visited 10 points against the player.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Pick-up and Deliver, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Mafioso
description:
This game is the predecessor of the well known game The Mob/Capone.

It was first time presented 1987 at the legendary "death row" of the London Toys and Games Fair.

Game components are of a very high standard regarding there were only few copies released: 4 x 8 large wooden and brightly colored discs, each depicting another different family member and -car with a colored sticker fixed to it,32 wooden hood pieces (German "Poeppel"), 56 colored racket cards, 40 gold bars (bankroll chips), a lot of play money and a large, colorful gameboard with comic-like drawings.

Added is a Mafia book containing the stories of real family members in the year of 1931, fixed with the some drawings you find on the member discs.

Game-play is nearly the same as in The Mob: Many cards for only some places to conquer, but nobody knows how much are at the same time in play!
Possibilities to invest in legal businesses or to send an opponent to the fishes (cement boots are replaced by an offer from the Colt Company which you can't refuse...)are also presented.

Players are on the run for the gold bars and to be the first to amass 10 of them!

Re-implemented by:

The Mob

name: Gettu betur: barna og unglingaspili√∞
description:
An Icelandic trivia game based on one of Icelands most popular tv show, the Gettu Betur trivia show where students representing their secondary schools compete for the Golden Microphone.

There are 2250 questions (language depentent) in this version of the board game which is aimed at children and teenagers.

name: HEROES in Mythical Greece
description:
"HEROES in Mythical Greece" is a greek CCG (Collectible Card Game) that takes place in Ancient Greece. The game is heavily based in the greek mythology trying to be as faithful to it as possible.

The players take control of a famous greek Hero and they play allies, locations, actions and equipment to assist him in his quests. The game can be played in two modes "Duels" and "Quests". In "Duels" two players fight each other, trying each to eliminate the opponent by either reducing his life total or gaining enough fame. In "Quests" players try to advance their Hero, by taking him from his early age and completing quests in order to take fame and have him rise to become a living legend. At the same time their opponents try to stop them by playing monsters that will prevent them from completing their quests. The first one to reach a certain level of fame wins.

Currently, only one set has come out, the first Rhapsody as it is being called, named Genesis. There are plans for more expansions in the following years.
categories: Card Game, Collectible Components, Fantasy, Fighting, Mythology

name: Kunstbox
description:
One out of 30 pictures from art history is hidden under 12 wooden tiles and revealed part by part. After any "revelation" the players have to answer one of 14 questions from a questionnaire and talk about the part that can be seen plus answering the question. Each answer that sounds correct to the other players, gets a point (chip).

Since any player is allowed to answer each question only once, it gets harder in the successing game to reply properly.

After the picture is completely revealed, the answers are re-checked in the rulebook, and each correct answer gets more points.

More a game for funny talk and make it believable, than for real art education. But the details you can explore in the process of revealing the pictures and discuss the answers, are illuminative fun.

name: Stafaspili√∞
description:
Stafaspilið (The Game of Letters) is a lot like Scrabble but without a board. Players get 8 tiles with a letter on each and the goal is to get rid of all the tiles from the hand. Each tile has a value which is used when a word is formed.

Each word that can be read from the new one is counted. For example if a player puts down 'house' he gets points for both 'house' and 'use'. The player who finishes first gets the points from the tiles in the hands of the other players.

name: Junk
description:
Junk is a parody of Battletech-style wargames, with a strong 'redneck' theme throughout the rules and artwork.

From the back cover:

" A Game of Mechanized Combat in a Not-So-Intelligent Future.

Junk is a twisted interpretation of the classic mecha theme. In Junk, players pilot giant robotic fighting machines called 'Cans, made from scavenged materials and jury-rigged weapons, and powered by engines that run on beer. They are unreliable, dangerous machines that nevertheless are the kings of the battlefield on the junkyard planet of Joisey. It is a world were life is short and harsh. A world where beer is worth it's weight in gold. A world where pretentious game hype is mocked and trodden underfoot. A world where only the strong survive. You know, sorta like the Bronx.

This book includes rules for 'Cans, vehicles, and rednecks on foot, as well as a campaign system to tie it all together. "
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Quickfire: Pre-Dreadnought Era Fast-Play Rules
description:
Fast-play naval miniature wargame rules for the pre-dreadnought period.(circa 1900)

This is a free set of rules that can be obtained from: www.wtj.com
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Paper-and-Pencil, Simulation

name: La Bataille du Garigliano
description: Game appeared in the magazine Casus Belli (Issue 17 - Oct 1983). Map of 41x 30 cm with 65 counters.

name: Pa-tol
description:
This is a traditional native American dice game, played exclusively by men. It is also a board game, with the board created on the ground using stones and sticks as markers and pieces. Forty stones are placed in a circle to form the track; players use a stick as their marker (or horse). Players cast three wooden billets, known as Pa-tol sticks, onto a flat stone; how they fall indicates how far their piece can move. Landing on another player's piece sends it back to its start. Players may choose where they wish to enter their piece and can choose to go round the track in either direction. The winner is the first player whose marker completes a circuit of the track.

While ostensibly a game of chance, descriptions of the game claim that expert players can throw the sticks to get their desired results.

Rules and more information are available here:
http://www.scienceviews.com/indian/indiangames11.html

name: American Airlines Travel Game
description:
This was a Cheerio's premium that was folded inside Cheerios Cereal Boxes. It was a 2-sided paper gameboard that came measuring approx. 17 1/8" x 15 1/4" unfolded and was copyrighted 1955 by Milton Bradley company.

It contained the rules for 6 different games that could be played on this 2-sided sheet with playing pieces and a spinner that were cut from the outside of the Cheerios boxes. Also contains various info about American Airlines flight crews, et c., plus a route map.

name: Jeane Dixon's Game of Destiny
description:
Jeane Dixon’s Game of Destiny: A Card Game of Numerology and Astrology.
Milton Bradley, 1968
Game components include instruction booklet, 3-pocket card holder, 6 info cards, 59 Destiny Cards.

name: Anansi
description:
An abstract game for 2 to 4 players inspired by Tibetan sand mandalas and named after a mythic spider from African folk tales.

Equipment:

* a go board
* a uniquely colored set of 32 stones for each player
* a deck of cards with a “web” drawn on each

(In lieu of this, you can also play with just pencils and a sheet of grid paper, but you'll still need the deck of cards.)

Each player draws a card and keeps the web pattern secret from his opponent(s). Each player takes turns placing one of his stones on the intersections of the grid (only the center 12×12 grid on the go board is used.) Your goal is to recreate the web pattern on your card by placing your stones on the board. Once a stone is placed, it cannot be moved. It is possible that the webs two players wish to create will overlap, in which case it becomes a race to see who can capture those intersections first. Points are scored based on whether the stone placed is in alignment with your web or one of your opponent's web, with more points being scored for stones that are placed in alignment with your web.

The game ends when all players have used all their stones. The winner is whoever gets the most points at the end of the game.

name: Annuvin
description:
Annuvin is played on a hexagonal board (4 hexagons on a side) with 6 pieces per player arranged in opposite corners.

A stone can move up to N spaces in any combination of directions (it may even move over intervening stones), where N varies depending on the number of stones he has remaining:

* Six pieces: one space per turn
* Five pieces: two spaces per turn
* Four pieces: three spaces per turn
* Three pieces: four spaces per turn
* Two pieces: five spaces per turn
* One piece: six spaces per turn.

A stone captures an opposing piece by moving onto it. If a stone makes a capture before it has used all of the spaces available to it that move, it may continue to make additional captures until it has moved its limit.

The player who captures all of his opponent's stones wins. Also, if a player reduces his opponent to a single stone without losing any of his own he wins.

name: Alchemy ICE
description:
Noughts and crosses (aka 'Tic-Tac-Toe') with randomized 'symbols' of five different types, played with Icehouse pieces.

Equipment:

* 5 stashes of Icehouse pieces (of any color, as long as they are different)
* Opaque bag
* chess board

Each player tries to get four in a row of at least three different colors. This symbolizes alchemists trying to grow enough of different types of chemicals in order to turn lead into gold.

name: Antshouse
description:
Ants running the gauntlet over a pavement while mean kids tries to splat them.

Equipment:


1 Icehouse stash per player (they don't need to be stackable)
Chess board


Get your ant across the pavement and back with more building material for the anthill while trying to stop your opponents by bombarding the other ants with an assortment of weaponry.

Antshouse was an entry in the 1st Ice Game Design Competition.

name: Official Baseball Game
description: Players draft teams of real players to play this simulation of America's past time. Milton Bradley released an Official Baseball Card Game at about the same time.

name: Arena
description:
By keeping track of, and selecting, the speed of your ship you will move around an imaginable arena for space combat, where the galaxy's aces settle the score! But watch out - if you crash into the walls or any of the arenas obstacles, your ship will be hard to control. Goal of the game: To kill your opponents!

Equipment:

* As many Icehouse stashes as possible, a minimum of 1 per player
* Tiled/checkered playing area, such as a chessboard, but the game has been optimized for a 8*8*8 board.
* A way of indicating height if not enough pyramids are available (8-sided dice are perfect)
* A way of indicating speed (again, 8-sided or even 6-sided (as you don't want to go very much faster than 6 in most cases) dice are good)
* Markers to use for obstacles and power-ups, such as coins (different values of coin can be different power-ups) or Icehouse pyramids.
* Several 8-sided die

Game System

Icehouse Pieces

name: Ladybug Dominoes
description:
Glückskäfer Domino or Ladybug Dominoes is a German children's game that uses cards shaped as ladybugs with unique spots on their wings. Ladybugs can be turned forward or backward to match spots as they are placed in a row. The first player to place all their cards is the winner.

The English name of the game on the side of the box was mistranslated as "Ladybird Dominoes."
mechanics: Pattern Building, Pattern Recognition, Tile Placement

name: Blockade
description:
From the Rules: Blockade is played with multi-shaped wooden pieces representing Naval Formations, Air Units, Submarines and Cargo Ships on a six-color map. Victory consists of capturing or sinking all enemy Merchant Shipping so that the enemy is completely blockaded and cannot obtain further supplies from Neutral sources.

The Map shows four countries (two sets of paired enemies). The land war between them is considered to be locked in a Maginot Line type of stalemate so the battle hinges on the war at sea. The map has 32 ports (5 in each warring country and 12 on the coasts of the neutrals).

Each country has a different starting mix of units (for example Leoland is high in Naval Formations and Adlerreich has the most submarines). The player round consists of moving all your cargo ships 1 space then rolling the dice and moving your units. A player may make a single air attack instead of moving any naval units. The air units have unlimited range and the number required to make an attack is based on the target. Losses are also based on the target and are automatic (for example it takes 4 air units to attack a naval formation and 2 air units are automatically lost).

A merchant ship can join a naval formation and create a convoy for more protection. Naval combat consists of a surprise attack (by submarines) and open attacks between naval formations. The surprise attack can be triggered by a roll of 8 or higher and an open attack requires the player to spend 1 or 2 pips of the dice roll.

name: Im Obstgarten
description: A Pachisi variant (roll and move, be the first to bring your 4 pieces to the target area, 2 pieces act as a barrier and so on ...). Slightly altered rules (one piece is on the track already). Most interesting and very nice idea in this edition: the game board is a large printed table cloth (approximately 1 by 1 meter).

name: Freisch√ºtz
description: Published in Nuremberg in 1821, the game components consist of a board, 12 cards, 7 balls, and two dice and is based on the important German opera which hit the stage in the same period.

name: Qi Guo Xiang Qi
description:
This "variant" of Xiangqi is played on a 19 X 19 grid (Go board). Seven armies represent the seven warring states of the late Zhou Dynasty (1045 - 221 BC):
Qin (white), Chu (red), Qi (indigo), Yan (black), Han (orange), Wei (green), Zhao (purple).

Each army is played by one player. For less than 7 players, there are several predetermined "allies", so one or more players direct two armies.

Every army has 17 pieces, which makes a total of 120, regarding the central single piece, representing the kingdom of Zhou. This piece does not move at all and cannot be captured.

Each of the armies consist of the following pieces:
1 General - moving like the Queen in modern Western Chess.
1 Deputy General - moving like the Rook in modern Western Chess.
1 Officer - moving like the Bishop in modern Western Chess.
1 Diplomat - moving like the Queen, too, but cannot capture or be captured.
1 Cannon - like the Cannon in XiangQi (moving like the Rook, but capturing over one intervening piece).
1 (Unit of) Archers - moving like the Queen, but only for 4 spaces.
1 (Unit of) Crossbowmen - moving like the Queen, but only for 5 spaces
2 (Units of) Swordsmen - moving 1 space diagonally.
4 (Units of) Broadswordsmen - moving 1 space vertically or horizontally.
4 (Units of) Cavalry - moving 4 spaces: 1 in a straight line and then 3 diagonally.

There are several rules regulating possible allies and winning conditions over single states. Residual pieces of beaten armies are removed from the board.

Simplified, it can be said, that to gain a victory over another state, a player has to capture the general or more than 10 pieces of this state. The player with the most captured pieces at the end of the game wins.

There are similarities both to Go (the central piece as the centre of the universe/representing the Zhou Dynasty, or the removing of "dead" armies) and Xiangqi (the pieces, the armies ...); this and the 7 players make this game unique in the history of strategic boardgames.

name: Prison
description:
An abstract game: the 13 red pins are the prisoners, 4 black pins are the wardens. Wardens (starting on each of the four corners of the 8 x 8 board) have to capture the prisoners by jumping over them - if only 3 red pins are remaining, the game is won by the warden player.

The red pins try to reach all 4 corner spaces (which is their victory condition).
A warden cannot be eliminated, but is forced to jump over a red pin, if possible.

name: Flips & Flops
description: Use your wits, guts and drop of luck on your way to the gold, in this exciting memory game. You will advance along the track by flipping the jumping cards. jumping over an opponent will send him back. Try to avoid the crocodile cards and be the first to reach the end of the track, pick the gold medal and win the game.

name: AA Game of the Road
description:
An Exciting Car Touring Game.

Start at London, tour Great Britain and be the first to return. But be careful - the road is full of hazards laid by other players! Take the fast route and meet the hazards head on, or take the slow route and collect protection cards. Which is the best route to win the game?

Object

The aim is to go around the circuit and be the first to return to London. The first player to do this is the winner. Instead of a turn, you can lay hazards for other players. When taking the longer route, you can stop at AA Service Centres and collect protection cards or take the shorter route and pass the other drivers. If you land on another player's hazard counter he hands you a hazard card. Do you have the right protection card? If not, call the AA van. When it arrives you can travel again.

Game Contents:

Game Board
5 Cars
4 AA Vans
5 Triangle Warning Signs
20 Hazard Counters
25 Hazard Cards
20 Protection Cards
1 Die
Rules
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement

name: Order of the Stick Adventure Game: The Linear Guild
description:
Get your evil twin on! This is the upcoming expansion to the Order of the Stick Adventure Game: The Dungeon of Dorukan, featuring fully playable versions of villainous Nale, Sabine, Thog, and the rest.

This will be a stand-alone expansion to the The Dungeon of Dorukan and will not require the base game to play. The expansion can be combined with the base game for even more gameplay options!

Rich Burlew basically announced that he had an illness that limited his health to the point that he had to devote all of his time to the comic (and the collection of said comics into books.) As he does the art for the game (and created the Order of the Stick world) and didn't have the time to devote to it, this expansion was put in limbo.
categories: Adventure, Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Modular Board

name: DNA
description:
DNA is an Icehouse-game and needs a chessboard in addition to four stashes of Icehouse pieces (in different colors).

The object of DNA is to possess the greatest value of pieces at the end of the game.

A single small piece of each color is placed in one of the center four squares of the board. Some method should then be used to determine which player goes first. It will be important at the end of the game to remember the starting player.

There are three elements to a turn: placement, scoring, and mutation. Placement must happen first. The player then has the choice of mutating and then scoring, or vice-versa. After a player has placed, mutated, and scored, the turn moves to the next player.

The game ends at the end of a turn in which no player has any pieces in a gene pool. Extra turns are played if the game does not end on the fourth player's turn to equalize the total number of turns per player. The value of the pieces (small = 1, medium = 2, large = 3) is totaled for each player's archive. The player with the highest total wins.

name: Mojave
description:
Played on a grid of 15 x 15 squares.

Playing pieces are 6-sided dice with "normal" numbers.

Each players have 15 dice each. They start in the 3rd and 4th row in a fixed position and orientation. Players move one of their dice each turn as many fields as the number on the top of it in any direction with the opportunity to change direction once orthogonality. While moving the die is tipped with each step to the next side.
If a die is placed adjacent to one or more dice of the opponent it captures them if its number is higher than the sum of the opponent`s or the other way round.

To win the game you must capture all of your opponent's` dice.

name: Football Strategy
description: Hal Holiday Games produced this Football Strategy game in 1950. The game had little cardboard men who were moved into position before the play was 'run' The play was shown on a play sheet. That play sheet showed where player could or would go. Game has scoreboard, field yardage markers, blue and red cardboard stand up men and an instruction sheet.

name: James Hunt's Grand Prix Racing Game
description:
This is a game to celebrate the James Hunt victory of F1 Championship in 1976.

Contents
1 Board
6 Cars
48 Playing Cards

Each drivers takes a cars and is dealt 7 cards.
The card showing speeds from 20 m.p.h. to 170 m.p.h.
In the first round, the driver at back of the starting grid must play a card, then the driver in front of him on the grid play his card, and so on, ending with the driver in pole position, who has the advantage of having seen all others cards played before.
After the first round drivers must play their cards in the same order in which they lie on the track.
The winner is, obviously, the first driver to cross the finish line having completed the number of laps agreed at beginning (usually 2).

name: Uppdrag Skaraborg
description: In Uppdrag Skaraborg the players will travel through the county of Skaraborg, visit eleven cities and buy houses etc. using money and by answering questions. To win the game you need at least two "houses" in two different areas, and money left so you can buy the endtest-card in the town you where starting from. The question categories in the game are in geography, sports, culture, history and entertainment.

name: S.S. Van Dine's Great Detective Game
description:
This game, based on popular 1920s and 30s fictional detective Philo Vance, revolves around each player trying to collect a set of clue cards which matches one of ten suspect, whose attributes are kept hidden in play. After collecting a set of clues, a player may accuse one of the suspects, and if enough of their clues match the suspect, the suspect can be arrested and brought to court. If the player is able to present sufficient additional evidence, the suspect is convicted and the player wins.

While this game has been compared to Clue, there aren't many similarities. Instead of trying to gather evidence to identify a specific suspect selected and hidden at the start of the game (i.e. Col. Mustard with a Cuisinart in the Rumpus Room), the goal of this game is to wander around collecting clue cards until a picture of one of the ten suspects comes into focus, and then try to gather enough clues to put them away. It's actually kind of a perversion of justice if you think about it.

Another odd element of the game is that landing on other players' pieces (i.e. "bumping") can serious screw with the player, so there's an interesting screw-your-neighbor aspect to play. Aside from that, the fact that repeated plays will almost certainly result in players memorizing the cards means that the replay value might be limited, but the bumping might actually keep the play interesting.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Track Movement

name: Draw Poker
description:
Draw Poker is part of Classic Games' Collectors' Series Dice Games, which is based on the card game of the same name. The game includes nine over-sized six-sided dice that feature every card in a standard deck (including two jokers). The dealer randomly selects five dice for a player to roll. After rolling, the player can then opt to trade up to four dice for four new dice, which represents drawing new cards. The dice are then given to the player on the left. Players must keep track of what "cards" have already been played in a hand so that no one can have a duplicate. Any duplicate cards must be rerolled.

The game includes chips and a scorecard for betting.
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Dice Rolling, Set Collection

name: Vom Neanderthaler zum √ñtzi
description: A stone-age themed simple card game, which aims to teach children about the stone age, various harmful and beneficial animals and plants, as well as give them some negotiation skills.

name: Berlin
description:
A “History Repeats Itself” game for the piecepack.

The Berlin Wall: A barrier surrounding W. Berlin that closed off E. Germans' access to W. Berlin from 1961 to 1989 and served as a symbol of the Cold War's division of E. and W. Germany. The barrier was built in response to the flight of about 2.5 million E. Germans to W. Germany in the years 1949-61. First erected on the night of August 12-13, 1961, the wall developed into a system of concrete walls topped with barbed wire and guarded with watchtowers, gun emplacements, and mines. It was opened in the 1989 democratization that swept through Eastern Europe.

Object: be the first player to collect 12 pieces of the wall.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: T√∂framenn
description:
An Icehouse battle of wizards

Töframenn is an Icehouse game for two players, requiring stackable Icehouse pyramids and a chessboard. Each player will also need one coin or other marker for use as an Archmage token.

Each player has one stash of 15 pyramids, five small, five medium, and five large. However, unlike other Icehouse games each player's stash may use any number of colors. (Both players may even have some pyramids of matching colors!) Multiple colors are almost always desirable, but no color has an advantage.

Rules Link
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Variable Player Powers

name: Tempt Destiny
description: The patent pending Tempt Destiny™ game method enables fans and family members to play the entire TV sports broadcast, including the commercials!

name: TrickTackToe
description:
TrickTacToe is a card game where players try to play three X or O cards in a row (horizontally, vertically, or diagonally), taking the 3 cards as a trick and scoring the points on the cards. Cards are played by matching same colors to adjacent sides.

Cards can also my played on top of existing cards, as long as they are still adjacent to a card in play AND the number on the new card is a lower value than the one it is covering.

name: More Metric Milers
description:
An expansion for Metric Mile from Jeff Packe and Terry Goodchild that adds 50 milers to the original set - 36 new, 12 revisions to milers in the original, and a 2-runner 'freebie' of Jeff Packe's personal picks as threats for the World Championship.

Also, the four milers that were issued with Replay Report (newsletter) have been re-worked and included with the 36 new milers, instead of the Revised set.

Expands:

Metric Mile

name: This War Without An Enemy
description: Andy Ogden's game of the first English Civil War, loosely based on Hannibal: Rome versus Carthage, features split-action Event/Strategy cards, extensions of the the Battle card system for resolving field engagements and new siege/assault rules for investing major and minor fortresses.
categories: Civil War, Pike and Shot, Wargame
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Point to Point Movement, Simulation

name: Z.O.D.
description:
Epic battle of "Z" forces VS "D" forces.

Competing corporate powers fight for supremecy in urban ruins, with infantry, tanks, aircraft and large robots. New sets can be added, expanding the troop choices and the size of the battlefield.

Box set comes with:
- 18-20 high quality figures (3 sets available):
1 set: 10 marines, 6 mechs (4 heavy armed and 2 light), 2 fighters,
2 set: 10 marines, 6 mechs (4 heavy armed and 2 light), 3 tanks, 1 rocket forces tank,
3 set: 10 marines, 6 mechs (2 heavy armed and 4 light), 2 tanks, 1 special tank.
All mechs in all sets are different. Marines not T_T

Also every set includes:
- Ruined buildings constructor (40-60 high quality pieces),
- 2 1d6 dices,
- 1 special dice,
- 40 counters (used with armlists),
- 20 camouflage counters (marines only),
- Instructions for ruined buildings assembly,
- Instructions for figures assembly,
- Tips for painting,
- 2 reference sheets,
- Battlefield board,
- Unit cards (aka armlists),
- Scenarios book (4 different scenarios per set),
- 12-page rulebook .

http://www.tehnolog.ru/product/zod/

name: Choosy Sushi
description:
A changing landscapes game for the piecepack.

You are a waiter at Choosy Sushi, a very busy (and often times chaotic) sushi restaurant. Customers will make their orders, and it is your job to pick up the exact order off of the conveyor belt and deliver the food the fastest.

That would be easy, if the conveyor belt would just cooperate with you.

Be the first to get four dishes on your tray & deliver your food.

name: Chemin Montagneux
description:
A Changing Landscapes game for piecepack.

Once upon a time, four civil engineers decided to hike up and down a famous mountain range in France. Unfortunately, they were better engineers than they were hikers, so they tried to make the adventure more interesting by terra-forming the rough mountainous ground into gently sloping paths. Using shovels, pickaxes and dynamite, the engineers slowly turned the mountain range into a beautifully sculpted landscape. Now, you can recapture the glory of those original engineers as they struggled to conquer the mountains.

Trail-blaze a path and be the first to hike your way to the top of your own mountain peak. In the basic version of this game, no player can attempt to climb his peak until all peaks are visible. Once all four peaks are visible, players hike toward their particular peak. The winner is the first player who reaches his peak during his hike.

name: Chaos
description:
A game played with Icehouse pieces.

Equipment:

* 10 stashes of Icehouse pieces, in all of the different colors that are available as of the date of this revision (black, purple, blue, cyan, green, yellow, orange, red, clear, and white)
* 2 ten-sided dice (preferably ones with single-digit faces rather than the “tens” faces)

In this game of controlled chaos, the players compete to capture all ten colors of pieces.

The object of the game is to capture one each of all ten colors of pieces by pointing attackers at defenders (which are much like the attackers and defenders in Icehouse) in one of the four colors that each color of attacker is able to attack.

Whenever an attacker is placed such that it points at a defender in one of the four colors that the attacker is able to attack, the player who placed that attacker captures a piece corresponding to the color of the defender by taking the largest available piece of that color from the linear array of pieces.

The game ends when one player has successfully captured one piece in each of the ten colors of pieces. That player wins.

name: Krabbel, kleiner K√§fer!
description:
From the Box:

Four beetles have a funny race all over the country. The coloured dice determines which of them can move, the number dice determines how far the journey goes each time. Who's first to the sunflower?

Overview:

A simple little game that can be played with any child that knows how to count up to three, and can tell their colors. Whoever moves a beetle to the sunflower gets to keep that beetle. The person with the most beetles at the end of the game wins.

Content:

1 long game plan made from cardboard pieces, 4 wooden beetles in four colours, 1 coloured dice, 1 dice with number spots and game instructions.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Ton: The Game of Professional Darts
description:
Features:
The top 250 dart players from the WDF, the BDA (men) and the BDA (women) are rated for overall skill. You get 750 players in total.
Throw-by-throw action; separate scoring systems for ton+ scoring and doubling out. Out chart included.
100 action cards drive the game engine; a match can be played in a matter of minutes.
Score sheet allows for statistical tracking as you play.
Graphical dart board included; you may call your own shots for a player rather than use the out chart. Complete rulebook included.

name: Martian Race
description:
The object of Martian Race is to be the first player to get all of the Martians from your family from your Home to the Government Center (to sign up for the program and get supply vouchers), the Supply Depot (to get, well, supplies), and then to the Launch Pad (to head off into space and down in history).

You will need one Icehouse-stash per player as well as two six-sided dice and a chess-board.

The complete rules are available online.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Rev up!
description: From the publisher, "Whoever wants to Rev up !, needs a good grip. The cars only move ahead if the driver finds the right card. A memory game for 2 - 4 race drivers." In the game the players roll two dice (color, model of car) which will determine what kind of card they will try to find in order to advance on the race track.

name: Picture Tri-Ominos
description: This is a children's version of Tri-Ominos aimed at kids Ages 4 - 8 The game consists of 35 tiles. There are 4 rule sets for the games: Beginner, Basic, Advance, and Solitaire.

name: Blockade
description:
A simple abstract strategy game, suitable for adults and children alike.

In head to head player, players take turns to place their shapes, until one player can no longer play. The game is rather simplem, although an experienced player will defeat a newcomer, as it must be taken into account what shapes both you and your opponent have remaining to play well.

For the solitaire game, the game instructions come with 19 puzzles to try and recreate. Some of them are suprisingly challenging to do. You can also create your own challenges by placing the king (and optionally one or two blocks) on the board and trying to fill in the remaining space with the remaining shapes.

Submit a better description and contact Admin Skelebone for a GeekGold reward.

name: ROL-OFF Indoor Golf
description:
ROL-OFF Indoor Golf is a dice rolling game meant to imitate a game of outdoor golf.
According to the publisher:
"Any game that can be played on the outdoor golf course can be played with a ROL-OFF INDOOR GOLF GAME. (A) 9 or 18 hole games (B) WIth singles or partners: 1,2,3, or 4 players(C) Low total score (D) Match Play wither each hole is counted separately (E) Low ball-low total (F) Least number of putts, etc..."

Playing rules are as follows:

A. Each player gets 3 shakes (2 shakes on a par 3).
1st shake is the drive. Remove the lowest die.
2nd shake is the fairway shot. Remove the lowest die.
3rd shake represents putting. Remove the lowest die.
The total of the dice removed represents total strokes for that hole. Mark your score on the score card.
B. Points are also awarded. Birdies are worth one point. Eagles are worth two points. A five-of-a-kind is a hole in one. It's worth 3 points. Points are recorded on the score sheet in the proper box for that whole.

C. The lowest score in the total column wins the game. The highest extra points in the total column wins the points.

D. Penalties:
-When a player shakes three "1's" in one shake, he removes two aces and so his count for that stroke is 2. (Sand Trap)
-When a player shakes three '2's" in one shake he is penalized 2 strokes and must remove two deuces so his count for that shake is 4 strokes (out of bounds).

When the above rules are followed, the scores will be very representative to a regular outdoor game of golf.

name: Iwo Jima
description: Iwo Jima was published on the (freely distributable) game magazine Strategos #2. It's a small, fast wargame on the battles for the control of Iwo Jima island in 1945.
categories: Print & Play, Wargame, World War II

name: Monster Pack #1
description:
This one hit wonder was the only publication by War-Oboe Publications. These ASL scenarios are designed for multiple players with up to 8 players on a side. Most scenarios require at least 4 players. Many scenarios feature the uncertainty of both sides not knowing what the other sides Order of Battle and or Victory Conditions are until the games end.

The counter art used represents some of the icons used by the Germans in WWII to represent military units.

Contents:
El Alamein, Egypt, 26 October 1942:
Players: 4-6 total, two to three per side.
Scenarios: 1

Kursk, Russia, 12 July 1943
Players: 8, four per side.
Scenarios: 4

Normandy, France, 6 June 1944
Players: 16, 8 per side.
Scenarios included: 8

Saipan, Marianas, 7 July 1944
players: 4, 2 per side.
Scenarios: 1

Iwo Jima, 25 February 1945
Players: 4, two per side.
Scenarios included: 2

Tournament Scenarios
Buna, Papua New Guinea, 1 December 1942
Papua, New Guinea, 8 December 1942
Leyte, Philippines, 28 October 1944.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Wargame, World War II

name: Super Test (1975-1995: La Aventura de la Libertad)
description:
A trivia game about history (mainly Spanish).

Each player takes the role of a Spanish minister and tries to be the first to get through 240 squares.
In the way you can find some special events, and you will always be asked a question about politics or history.

The dice has a different color for each side, representing the different type of questions:
Yellow: Sports and spectacle.
Blue: Spanish politics.
Pink: Spanish society.
Green: Science and art.
Red: International history.

The questions are from different ages depending on the area where the player is: 1975-1980, 1981-1985, 1986-1990, 1991-1995.

Box contents:

- 1 board game (240 squares, representing Spanish and world history).
- 9 "mini-ministers", but with only 6 feet (only 6 simultaneous players).
- a big set of question cards.
- some special "challenge" cards.
- a box with separators for the different ages of the questions.

name: DFL
description:
From the game's main website:

Introducing Dice Football League the action-packed board game where every roll of the dice can mean the difference between winning and losing.

From single games to entire seasons, Dice Football League will provide hours of fun for family and friends, young and old!

You can play Dice Football League right out of the box...no complicated set-ups, no 1000 page user manuals, just pop open the box, set up the board, and you're good to go. Frat-parties, kid's birthday parties, fun get-togethers, whatever the occasion, Dice Football League is a great way to have fun. Play it once, and you'll want to play again and again.

name: Hi-Ho! Santa Claus Game
description:
You use a spinner to go around the board, trimming the tree in this old Christmas holiday-themed game.

OBJECT: To be the first player to put his 8 colored balls and Santa Claus on the Christmas Tree.

Players spin the spinner once each turn. If the spinner lands on his color, he may put one of his colored balls in the hole on the Christmas tree that shows the matching color. If the spinner lands on the tree, he must remove one of his colored balls from the tree. If a player spins Santa Claus before he has 8 balls on the tree, he can spin again. Once a player has all his 8 balls on the tree, he spins on his turn for Santa Claus. When he has all 8 balls and spins Santa Claus, he yells out "Hi Ho! Santa Claus!", thus winning the game!

name: Sesame Street Preschool Games for Growing: Shopping
description:
Sesame Street Preschool Games for Growing-Shopping Set "is designed to help your child learn about earning, saving, and shopping wisely." The set contains 3 Main Games and 2 Introductory Games

The Introductory games introduce the board and cards to younger children.

Game 1 Fun to Earn: Uses the bottom half of the Board. Players take Job Cards from the Home space to their respective Earning Places and trade them for a Sesame Street Coupon. The first player to save 3 Coupons wins.

Game 2 Shop and Swap: Uses the top half of the Board. Players get Shopping List Cards from the Home space, move to the correct Store, and pay the listed Coupon for the correct Item. The first player to complete 3 Shopping trips wins.

Game 3 Big Bird's Surprise Birthday Party: This Combines the ideas of game 1 and 2. Players earn Coupons by completing Jobs, and then buy the items from their Shopping Lists. The first player to bring 2 items Home for Big Bird's Party wins.
categories: Card Game, Educational, Movies / TV / Radio theme
mechanics: Pick-up and Deliver, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Jim Prentice Electric Baseball Model 505
description: 1950's era electronic baseball game. Players press buttons that determine the pitch (good, bad) and the batter action (swing, take). Balls and strikes are called by light bulbs lighting up. Hits are determined by an electric motor spinner. Pegs are moved on the board to indicate base runners, balls, strikes, and outs.

name: Hippopotamus
description:
This appears to be an electronic puzzle game for two players.

Placing the board between them, each player receives the pieces for four plastic hippos in their color. On a turn, the player draws a card from the center of the board which outlines where their hippos must be placed on their side of the board. The timer is turned, and they must then assemble their four hippos, place them in the indicated sockets, and then thread the light cord through the hippos in the correct order and plug it into the destination hole. If the light comes on, it indicates the puzzle was completed successfully.

After a set number of turns, the player with the most completed cards wins.

name: The CIPHER FILE
description: What if you had to reduce the greatest Truths of your civilization down to 40 ciphers? What truths would you choose? From the mahogany shelves of an exquisite library in a house hidden from view on a secluded road, comes the mysterious and intriguing APOLOGUE of THE CIPHER FILE by Rosetta Sherwood Stone. THE CIPHER FILE game/kit is designed to give you hours of pleasure, and years of thought.

name: Tawlbyund
description: The Welsh tafl game Tawlbyund or tawl bwrdd is thought by many scholars to have obtained its name meaning "throwing board" specifically because it most often was played with dice. Linguistically this makes sense but evidence is otherwise scarce. The game was definitely played on an 11x11 grid and a diceless version is described at http://www.gamecabinet.com/history/Hnef.html. The dice if used would as noted above either have determined if a player got to take a turn or how far he could move a piece.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement

name: Gamenight
description:
This game was created in a thread by Legomancer to which he wanted to create a game from an idea he had, but wanted all BGGers to help if they wanted to posting it through a thread on the bgg, ending up here: http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/88063

Through about a 2 week period, this game came to light, was played, critiqued and tested; some good some bad, but in the end, it worked.

The players are BGGers getting together for game night. Each has brought a pile of games and is trying to get certain games on the table for playing. Best played with 3+ players due to the bidding mechanism.

A board is set out on the table. A 20 point, timer track encircles the entire board. In the center is a board with five tracks on it. The tracks are labeled "Theme", "Weight", "Luck", "Strategy", "Interaction"
Each track is numbered 0, 1-9, with the zones 1-3, 4-6, and 7-9 clearly marked.
