During the course of the game each player will blind bid to move the marker up or down the track of their choice, trying to either keep that track in the same zone as their played game(s) or new game they wish to start. Blind bids are all taken, even if you don't win. The counters used for bidding are divided amongst players who bid zero, keeping a closed economy for "money".

The game ends after a set amount of "game-time" has gone by which all players' games add to when they are completed. Add up the total games' times for the winner; highest wins.

Each person who decides to make this game will be able to place the name and categories of their own favorite games as it comes with blank cards to print out. Also, a supply of counters will be needed for the bidding as well as a printing of the gameboard.

The rules can be found on the thread: http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/88063

name: Ace Handicap Golf
description:
Ace Handicap Golf game comes with two large double sided boards depicting 18 golf holes and a practice hole. Each hole may contain some of the various golf hazards: bunkers, water, rough, trees etc. Three different games are described in the rules: novice, standard and handicap. For each golf hole, players select from several possible routes marked on the boards, study a club/distance chart to determine which club best suits the chosen route then roll a 14 sided dice to determine the accuracy of the shot (accurate, good, poor, hook/slice, fault). This repeats until the green is reached. Once on the green, separate charts manage the process of putting.

The handicap version of the game allows chips to be won for good shots which can be played at various times during the hole eg to avoid bad rolls, negotiate hazards or make small advancements.

Not so much an edit as an addition to the information. The designer and artist of this game was Eddie Solomons,not Eric as stated. He was assisted by his family who have happy memories of researching and dry running the game. One daughter, who was just 18 at the time was sent off to the patents office in London, England, to research the design of the then innovotive multisided dice based on a golf ball.How do I know all this? I am that daughter! Sadly, Eddie passed away on the 9th September 2011 aged 86. It was kinda nice to see his game remebered on the internet. Unfortunately, when his grandson arrived at his hospital bed to show him, he was already starting to slip away. Thank you,all the BoardGameGeeks, for immortalising part of the eccentric late Eddie Solomons.

name: Wild Turkey Opoly
description: In Wild Turkey Opoly, all of the spaces are real hunting lodges, Clubs and Taxidermists. Such hunting brands such as Primos, Quaker Boy, HS Strut and Jerry McPherson's Montana Decoy are included on the board as well.
publishers: Huntertainment, Inc., Late for the Sky Production Company

name: Drakguldet
description: Drakguldet (English, the dragon's gold) is a Swedish children's game. The object of the game is to collect the gold without waking the dragon.

name: Den glade mytomanen
description: Den glade mytomanen (English, The happy pathological liar) is a Swedish party game in which the object is to deceive your opponents to the best of your abilities.

name: Monopoly: Bournemouth & Poole Edition
description: Another localized version of Monopoly, this time featuring areas in and around Bournemouth and Poole.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading
publishers: Parker Brothers, Winning Moves UK Ltd.

name: Shrek Road to Royalty Board Game
description: Travel Shrek's world with Shrek, Fiona, Charming, and Donkey. Work you way from Shrek's humble home to the Poison Apple Tavern, through the evil trees and up to the royal castle to be crowned the ruler of Far, Far, Away and win the game! Includes 4 sculpted pieces.

name: Coyote Moon
description:
A game for the piecepack.

“The spirits have taken your stones and hidden them on the path”, explained the shaman, “Go, find your stones and return them to their totems around the fire. The first to complete this task is the strongest among you.”. The four braves had seen many strange things under the guidance of the shaman, but a race was something familiar and welcome. All four braves paused only a moment, and then they were gone down the path in both directions. The shaman squatted by the fire to wait.

Equipment:

* 1 piecepack
* 1 suitable container for randomly drawing coins (optional)

Players race to be the first to gather and place their spirit stones on the moon totem spaces of the spirit wheel.

name: Walt Disney's Snow White And The Seven Dwarfs Game
description:
The large 3-D accessories dominate the board as the dwarfs rush to rescue Snow White from her sleep.

The Dwarf movement is dictated by a spinner which indicates which color to move a given dwarf to, Candyland style.

No player controls any specific dwarf, but rather holds several discs with dwarf portraits on them. During the game, these discs may be spied on and traded with other players, with players trying to jockey their favored dwarfs into position while keeping the lead dwarf in their hand of discs.

The winner is the owner of the chit that matches the first dwarf to reach Snow White.
categories: Children's Game, Fantasy, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: The Hockey Card Game
description:
The game is played with a deck of standard size cards. On one side is a player's name and small picture. On the reverse is the player's statistics through to the year the deck was printed. The object of the game is to sort the players based on one of nine categories: Jersey number, number of teams played for, rookie year, total goals, total assists, total points, penalty minutes, number of seasons and position drafted.

The deck is placed with the stats side of the cards face down. One card is stats side up and a category is selected. The object is to place the player on the top of the deck with the other stats-up cards, in order, for the given category. Keep going until you make a mistake.

In the basic game, one category is selected. Whoever gets the most players positioned correctly without making a mistake wins.

In the tournament game, nine rounds are played, one for each category. Each round you receive one point for each correct placement, to a maximum of five.

Six different decks exist, one for each of the Canadian NHL teams (Ottawa, Montreal, Vancouver, Edmonton, Calgary and Toronto).

name: Molecular Flip
description:
Explained in Gladstone's Games to Go, Molecular Flip is an abstract strategy game played on a 3x3 grid with 9 coins. Players flip patterns of coins within their own Flipping Square to match the patterns of a central Target Square.

From Gladstone’s Games to Go:

Here’s a game that test’s your ability to solve spatial logic problems. It’s great for solo play, but the extra pressure of playing with a group will appeal to highly competitive gamers as they race to see who can solve the problems first. Note-taking is absolutely forbidden during play.

name: Sweep!
description:
SWEEP! is based on the sport of Curling and the objective is to place your rocks closer to the center of the scoring circle than your opponent. This game is played on a board which represents a Curling rink. Each player, in turn, will choose which lane they are throwing from and draw a card from one of 8 different decks which each represent a different type of throw/strategy which informs you as to the result of that throw.

Game components include the following:

1 curling rink gameboard (14 x 28 grid)
2 plastic brooms
16 plastic stones (8 red & 8 black)
8 packs of cards representing different throws
1 shot diagram chart illustrating each throw

name: MAM !!!
description:
UNAUTHORIZED PRODUCTION



The information that BGG has on this item indicates that MAM !!! is a non-authorized version of SET.




Each card contains 1-3 matching objects, in one of three colors, shapes, and shadings. Twelve cards are laid out, and the first person to spot a set of three collects those cards. The cards are replaced from the deck and play continues.

A set consists of three cards which are either all alike or all different in each attribute: for instance, if all three cards have the same number of objects, but different shapes, shadings, and colors, then they're a set. If two of the cards have a common attribute that is not shared by the third, they are not a set.

name: The Category Game
description:
The Category Game is a word/trivia game for ages 6 and up. In many ways, it can be seen as a simplified form of 'Scattergories.'

In a given round, five category cards and five letter cards are dealt out in two parallel lines. After the timer is flipped, players have a set amount of time to come up with as many answers as possible corresponding to each category/letter pair. Once the timer runs out, duplicates answers are eliminated and points are scored for each remaining answer.

The player with the most points after four rounds is the winner.

Box contains:
24 Category Cards
24 Letter Cards
1 Timer
Rules

name: Das Dornr√∂schen-Spiel
description:
Content:
1 board
40 fairytale cards
16 fairy cards (8 good fairy, 8 evil fairy)
1 bright magic wand for good fairies,
1 dark magic wand for evil fairies

Each player gets a series of fairytale cards with numbers 1-10, 2 good fairies, 2 evil fairies

The idea is:
Each player shuffles his 14 cards and lays them as a hidden deck in front of him at the table.
At his turn the player draws an own card and tries to place it onto a field with the same number.
If the opened card is an evil fairy he takes his dark magic wand and turns an discarded card face down. Here no card may be laid until a good fairy turns it back open again.

The player who can discard his hand first wins

name: Monopoly: My NBA
description:
Choose 22 of 30 National Basketball Association Teams and place them on the game board where you want. Then...buy, sell and trade your favorite teams in an effort to own and control the NBA, a basketball fan's fantasy. The team labels are removable and reusable so, if you choose, you can play different a game each time.

It's as much fun to set up as it is to play!
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Donkey Kong Country
description:
Set up a cardboard backdrop and attempt to pitch POGs accurately behind walls and into holes in the correct order to win the game.

This game includes a complete set of 36 Donkey Kong Country milk caps exclusive to this game.

name: Democratic: El Juego de la Democracia
description: A political game where each participant is at the forefront of a political party and should undertake an election campaign, travel across the country, participate in elections, investing in advertising, and if necessary, go to the courts in defense of allegations received. All of this ends in the general election and the votes tell who will be the president.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Open Drafting, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Gun Fight
description:
I free game for use with any miniatures or counters.

Test who is the fastest gun in the west. Or at least in this game.

Very quick and easy game with 'advanced' rules.

http://www.csschicora.com/Free-Game.html Although it doesn't look like it is formated for easy reproduction.

name: Divorced, Beheaded, Died, Divorced, Beheaded, Survived.
description:
A game for the piecepack.

Out of all of the kings and queens in the Tudor dynasty, King Henry the VIII (1509-1547) is perhaps the most well known. After his marriage to Catherine of Aragon, Henry wanted to divorce from her, against Roman Catholic mandates. Not agreeing with the Pope, Henry starts the English reformation, branching off into the Anglican Church. Henry then marries 5 more times during his reign, the historical order of his wife’s goals which is best remembered in the mnemonic device “Divorced, Beheaded, Died, Divorced, Beheaded, Survived.”

Now you can live the life of King Henry the VIII and give your six wives the same fates.

The object of the game is to meet 4 different goals; “divorce” two of your own queens, “behead” two of your queens, have one of your queens “die”, and to have one of your queens “survive”. Each of these goals requires a different interaction of pieces and or positions to be met. The first player to meet all of these goals is the winner.

name: Cyber-Quest
description:
Cyber-Quest: The future is in your hands...

With the advent of the Internet, computers have become more important than ever. Cyber-Quest has been designed by industry professionals to help you and your entire family learn about the Internet and the computers needed to run it.

Your quest along the paths of knowledge will teach you much that you need to know about the Internet and computers in general. As you surf the paths, you will gain valuable knowledge about the Internet. That knowledge will gain exposure for your growing web site as you collect powerful hit points and special upgrades. The size of your web site is measured by the amount of hit points that you have acquired. The person with the largest web site when the game play ends is the winner.


Description Source: Front page of the player instruction sheet included with the game. **
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Open Drafting, Roll / Spin and Move, Simulation

name: Little Gibraltar: the Storming of Stony Point
description:
At midnight of 15 July 1779, about 1,150 Americans under Brigadier General 'Mad' Anthony Wayne began their assault on 650 British troops holding Stony Point. The British were completely surprised and thoroughly defeated, with few American casualties.

This game includes the following components:
- one 9-page rulebook
- two sheets of tables
- 112 uncut single-sided counters: 56 blue American counters (with six blanks) and 56 red British counters (with 14 blanks)
- one 11 x 17 sheet containing the hex map and record-keeping tracks

name: And the Transport Empire
description:
From the One Page Wars game series.

The players compete to be the first to earn 100 credits by purchasing buses, trains, and planes and using them to transport passengers for hire between the seven cities on the hex grid mapboard.

Each type of transport unit is rated for cost, movement and passenger capacity. There are a limited number of such units available: 10 aircraft, 5 buses, and 3 trains.

In addition, the players can build a portion of the transportation system, as there are no train tracks marked on the board - the tracks may be purchased and placed by the players during the course of the game.

name: Auf zur Burg
description:
Game about exploration of Burghausen, a little city in the south of Bavaria in Germany.

Each player retrieves two cards from each of three parts of the city to which he has to go. Travelling is done by rolling the dice. If a player reaches one of his targets he has to read the text of the card and follow its instructions that usually favour far away locations and add handicaps to near locations.

Beside the normal movement there exist two special movements: one clockwise around the map by travelling by bus and one counter clockwise by travelling by 'Plätte' (tourist ships that were used for shipping salt along the river in former times.) The special movements normally increase your travel speed but add the risc of too far movements.

After a player has reached all his targets he has to move to the castle of Burghausen (the longest in Europe or probably in the world) in the middle of the game map. There he has to roll the dice for each of the six castle wards. The first player to reach the most inner ward wins the game.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement

name: La Battaglia di Waterloo
description:
Game for two players of the battle of waterloo for children. Map divided in squares, simple rules, counters type miniatures and the combats are solved of way similar to checkers.
Components: book of rules,book history,map and miniatures paper.

name: Montrose Triumphs: The Battles of Alford and Auldearn
description:
Fifth entry in the English Civil War series, this DTP wargame depicts two different battles, Alford and Auldearn, both victories of the Earl of Montrose, a Royalist general, during his second Scottish campaign.
Each battle has a single A4 full color map and about 40 counters.

Available through wargamedownloads and Arima.it as direct download, and through Boulder Games and Noble Knight Games as printed DTP wargame.
categories: Civil War, Pike and Shot, Print & Play, Wargame

name: Die Feuerwehr ist da!
description: Caution....it burns at several places at the same time! The players act as courageous firemen and try to put out the burning fire as fast as possible. Fast comprehension and skillful planing decide who gets the most firemen merits for successful actions.

name: Die Sonnenpyramide
description:
In old Peru in the Inca empire King Atahualpa gave some of his people a brain teaser. Inside his palace he hid 34 animal symbols on a certain floor area.
When all symbols are solved each player counts his gold treasure.

name: Die Dinos sind los!
description: Each player tries to hide his dino eggs while at the same time trying to find his opponents dino eggs. The winner is the player who best hides the most eggs.

name: MiniT
description:
The idea is to win a MiniT (=Mini-Tennis) Tie-Break.
The game has 56 position cards, 20 running cards, 32 forehand cards, 32 backhand cards.

The game starts with the usual serve of a normal Tie-Break.
The played cards are put down on the table so that a pattern of cards is being developed into the size of a tennis court (8 by 5 cards). Player A starts with his serve. Then the players alternate getting 2 serves, starting with player B.
Play continues to 7 points or until a player leads by 2 points once 7 is reached.

name: Kleine Rechenschule
description:
4 basic arithmetic operations are exercised in this game.
Each player gets cards with a math problem. Whoever has solved all his problems first wins the game.

name: Alles Banane!
description:
The game is played in 5 rounds. Players take turns flipping over cards. When a banana card is flipped up, the active player gets a big banana. When a monkey is shown, the banana has to be put back. Banana peels mean there is no change. When all cards are face up the round is finished. The player who has the big banana at the end of the round gets a small banana. The player who has the most bananas at the end wins.
The game is entirely luck-driven and targets the very young.

name: Das l√§ngste Wort
description: Are you "wordy"? Then you will have fun with this fast and funny game. The game idea is to build words out of a "handful of characters". Short words or long words. The longest words let you move quickly forward to the finish line.

name: Pocahontas-Abenteuer-Spiel
description: In the Indian village Pocahontas looks for friends Meeko and Flit. After she has found them she walks to Grandma Willow's where she gets help for her adventures. Together with Captain John Smith she walks across the rock and the river to the ship. They have to pass the malicious Governor Ratcliffe. Whoever reaches the ship first with Meeko, Flit and John Smith wins the game.
categories: Adventure, Dice, Movies / TV / Radio theme
mechanics: Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Open Drafting

name: Dupe
description:
From the publisher's website:

A quick and skillful strategy game for two where players thread the two-tone cord back and forth through the holes of the hand held board until all adjoining hole options are filled. Maneuvering an opponent's cord end into a blocked position requires rational decision making and observation skills so make sure you're not the one getting strung along!

name: Qwikstat Basketball
description: Fast playing stat summary basketball game. You can get individual player stats for all major stat categories for each game. All NBA seasons from 1954/55-2006/07 seasons. ABA seasons 1966/67-1975/76 coming spring 2008. All games available as Adobe pdf files only and delivered by email. Basic game is instructions, charts and any 2 NBA seasons for $9.95 Paypal preferred. My email address and Paypal ID is rgfray@Yahoo.com. For checks, mail to Bob Fray, 202 Ann St., Phoenixville, Pa 19460. $4.00 extra if you want files on cdrom mailed. For brochure requests, email me - many other original sports games available.

name: Sherlock Holmes: The Case of the Dead Duke
description:
SHERLOCK HOLMES: THE CASE OF THE DEAD DUKE

Sherlock Holmes has been called in to find out who killed Duke Richard. The Duke was unloved by all and found poisoned in his study. The players make up the clues Holmes finds. Clues point to who did it. Players try to pin the murder on one another. Someone has to be guilty.

This is an Engle Matrix Game so players pick a character in the story to champion. Each turn they buy the right to make what action happens next (Like what clue Holmes finds...) Action are not automatic. They pick another player to be their referee. The ref sets the "to happen" roll. Other players may jump in with counter-arguments forcing big dice rolling contests. Bit by bit clues add up until one of he players is arrested. Since players never make up the same clues the game plays differently each time.

The Case of the Dead Duke plays out like an episode of the TV show “Law and Order”. First the players find clues then someone is put on trial.

This is an intermediate level Matrix Game. It comes in a box with a 20x15 inch hard board map of London, character sheet booklet, rules booklet, scenario booklet, wooden counters, plastic gold coins and 2 dice.

TYPE: Intermediate Engle Matrix Game
PLAYERS: 2 to 10
AGE: 12 to adult
DURATION: 2 hours
COMPLEXITY: Moderate
REPLAYABILITY: High
COST: $40.00
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Murder/Mystery, Novel-based
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Role Playing, Storytelling, Variable Phase Order

name: Bucket O' Muzzleblast
description: Quick, simple miniature wargame rules covering the American revolution to the American Civil War.

name: W.V.U.-opoly
description:
From the manufacturer:

If you’re looking for outstanding academics, an active collegiate social life, big time college sports, all wrapped in a beautiful Appalachian setting, West Virginia University is the place for you. WVU is a top choice for scholars, researchers, and athletes. Located in the picturesque mountains of north-central West Virginia, the university is the state’s flagship land-grant college.

We visited Morgantown, West Virginia and asked students and alumni, “What makes this place so great?” We spent time lounging in the Lair, listening to stories about WVU legends, Rhodes scholars, athletic prowess, the best pizza in town, etc. We strolled around campus and watched the sun set on the Monongahela River. We even took a ride on the futuristic PRT. The result of all this intense research? A game so full of WVU, we could hardly get the lid on!
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading
publishers: Late for the Sky Production Company

name: Saygo
description:
Description from Uncles Games:

"Similar to Scrabble, players are creating word puzzles in a crossword fashion, only with Saygo, you do not have a community board. Instead, players builds their own word puzzles in front of them. Letters are worth points (vowels are worth 1 point, consonants 2 points, and super consonants J, K, Qu, X, and Z, are worth 4) the object of the game is to be the first player to reach 500 points. Every player randomly selects eight tiles and places them face down. Simultaneously, players turn them over and begin building the puzzles with as many letters from their individual pile as possible. Once someone has used up all eight tiles, he or she says "Saygo" and all players will select another tile. If nobody can use their tiles it is a stalemate, and everyone selects another tile. Should players find they can not use all of their tiles, they have the option of rearranging their puzzles as often as needed, in attempt to use all letters. The game continues until all tiles are used and the last person to use his/her last tile yells "done". Once the group verifies the accuracy of the winning player's words, the winner collects the remaining letters and adds them to his/her score. Once a player has 500 points (that number can be lowered or raised if desired), the round is finished and players can play again."

name: Mighty Landlord
description:
(Translated from the Japanese rulebook)
In this game, the players are owners of inns, and the goal is to get as many staying guests, earning the most money in a set period of time.
But it's not easy preparing rooms for all those people who have come to the festival in town. Among the normal guests like travelers and merchants, there is the King, the General and even assassins and Demon Lord! It's a chaotic mix of everything.
Each guest has their own condition for staying the night and paying the room. Some are content if you serve them tasty food, some look only for good service and some are looking for a good fight…
If you can't please the guest, not only will you not get paid, but you have to pay instead, so you'll have to be careful which guests you accommodate. You can push dangerous guests to your neighbour's door, but if you're not careful, you might get one yourself!
The character the players play all have different areas they are good at and bad at. And they, too, are former adventurers, so they have individual skills to attract or deter guests. The one who uses these skills the best, gets the most content customers and earns the most money during the festival will be declared the winner.
mechanics: Hand Management, Variable Phase Order, Variable Player Powers

name: Chicken Warriors
description:
(Translated from the Japanese rule book)
In this game, players cooperate in order to defeat huge monsters. All damage dealt to the monster is directly converted into Victory Points, and the one with the most VPs when the third monster is defeated, is declared the winner.
But it is not an easy task to deal damage to these huge creatures. If you're too far away, you can't deal any damage at all. In order to deal damage, and earn points, you need to get close to the monster, and run the risk of taking damage yourself.
And dealing damage isn't the only thing you must be careful about. The other players are aiming at your back. They might try to push you to the front line. If you're pushed to the front, and the monster gets you, all your points are halved!
Seeing to that the leading player gets nicely defeated, and still having cards left to deal some damage to the monster, will make you the winner.

name: The Story of Genghis' Conquest of the West
description:
This game covers Genghis Khan's invasion of Central Asia against the Khwarazm (Khorezm) Empire from 1219-1221. It appears to be a strategic-level game, unlike the accompanying Temujin's Battles.

The game includes 1 A2-sized map with 81 counters.

This game was designed by Works-Zero (www.works-zero.com).

name: Temujin's Battles
description:
Tactical-level game with three scenarios, each with a map.

The game includes 3 different A3-sized maps and 116 counters.

This game was designed by Works-Zero.

name: Spion im Werk: Das Opel-Spiel
description:
Spion im Werk or Spy in the facory was produced by Adam Opel AG in order to encourage the employees to communicate more with each other. The Goal of the game is to catch a spy, that has sneaked off into the Opel factory in Rüsselsheim, Germany. There are two teams: One plays the spy and the others play a team trying to catch the spy, but the spy has some sneaky skills to avoid being caught by the other team, If he succeeds in stealling a specific amount of secret files from the factory, the spy wins.

The game mechanic is a mixture of roll & move and answering questions.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Dresda
description:
Dresda is a ‘fast-play’ fantasy battle skirmish system designed for small numbers of troops yet involving more than a little role-playing on the part of the players. Indeed, unlike many conventional wargames with little or no ‘role-playing’ element, in Dresda you are your units' Commander in the field, and you not only have the responsibility of commanding the unit in battle, but also the headaches of paying your troops, buying their equipment and generally trying to improve your (and their) financial position.

Dresda is a scenario driven game, not points based one. This means that careful thought needs to be given to the designing of scenarios by the GM. So, although you can line up your troops on opposite sides of the table and simply advance until you bump into each other in the centre, you'll find this isn't really much fun, and you'll quickly find that your games will be much more enjoyable if you (and/or a good GM) put some effort into designing an interesting or challenging scenario.

Of course, it also helps to create a feeling of unit continuity by treating your unit as a group of individuals rather than disposable 'cannon (or halberd)-fodder'. Name each of them, decide what they like to eat, drink and how they feel about their Mum, and suddenly you can see them as characters in a role-playing game, not just as troops in a ‘one-off’ wargame.

Over a number of games you'll see your unit develop, watch their fortunes wax and wane and individual characters come and go. Eventually you'll find that some of these factors will start to dictate your actions on the battlefield, for instance you may see ‘heroic’ traits develop in one character or cowardly traits in another as the miniatures begin to become characters in their own right, and not just anonymous lumps of painted white metal.

The Aim of the Game

The basic aim of Dresda is to raise a small unit of fighters, fight battles and get rich!

Unfortunately, whilst this basic aim is simple, it isn't necessarily easy. What's more, this is likely to be a more 'hands-on' experience than you may be used to, even in skirmish wargaming. That's because you, the Player, will take on the role of your unit's Commander, and will be represented on the battlefield by a miniature figure!

name: Fetch the Ink
description:
From the instructions: Fetch the Ink! was devised to give an entertaining insight into printshop routine, which can be pretty hectic at times! In view of the tight delivery deadlines involved there is often a fine line between human error and superhuman achievement.

"Ink is a basic essential for printing, so the winner of the game is the player whose team is the first to reach the coveted ink buckets in the centre of the board."

Each player starts off at the printing press in the colored corresponding corner and strives to reach the matching ink bucket in the middle of the board.

There are two circuits linked by four cross paths and a player must try to reach the colour spectrum via the line of squares in his or her colour.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Isabella
description: The player who returns to the castle with his two knights and brings the ring of Isabella with him/her wins the game.

name: IceGolf
description:
IceGolf is a dexterity game for Icehouse Gaming Pyramids.

One to five players can compete with a single Treehouse set, using the pyramids as golf balls, the die as the hole, and the tube as a golf club!

Play a quick hole on a tabletop with the Basic Game.
Use Martian Coasters as hazards in the Advanced Game.
Try your hand at the more challenging head-to-head Matchplay variant.
Or, if you feel too restricted on a tabletop and want to let loose, an entire room may be used to create each hole!

Complete rules can be found at the Icehouse Games Wiki.

Game System

Icehouse Pieces

name: Dominew
description:
Dominew is a domino-like game in which the tiles are made of plastics crosses with 2, 3 or 4 numbers on it. You score points by placing the tiles so that there are several similar numbers in a row (for example, 6 + 6 + 6 = 18 points) or as consecutive numbers (eg 2 + 3 + 4 = 9 points).

The player with the most points wins the game.

name: Isle at War
description: Isle at war is game of conquest set on a fictitious island of warring feudal kingdoms, players tax their population and use the wealth to raise great armies and build castles. To win a player must conquer the entire island. Isle at war is a print and play game and can be printed out on one page, all that is required to play on top of that is a single 6 sided die.
categories: Medieval, Print & Play, Territory Building, Wargame
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Area Movement, Dice Rolling

name: UNO: LeBron James Special Edition
description:
An Uno variation themed on LeBron James, star basketball player for the NBA Cleveland Cavaliers team.

WHAT MAKES THIS DIFFERENT FROM TRADITIONAL UNO: Exclusive "Hail to the King" card and rule that forces an opponent to draw cards from you and other players

name: The Color Train Game
description:
In this memory game players start with their own train board with 8 empty train cars. Players alternate turning over boxcars (tiles) on the main board attempting to find colors to sequentially match the empty cars of their trains. The first player to fill all 8 train cars wins.
Each train board has cars in different color order.

name: Planet der Sinne
description:
Together with the Sensor, the little sensory explorer, the players set off on an exciting journey. Depending on the activity square where Sensor lands, the player has to find out of six filled tins which are the two with the same weight, or recognize which wooden piece has suddenly disappeared. Or he has to intelligently work out and guess which piece of the tactile chain is searched for. Whoever is successful in carrying out these activities collects many marbles on their little planet of senses.

Planet der Sinne (Planet of Senses) is a game collection with 12 different activities to stimulate the senses: seeing, hearing, smelling, tasting, touching, and moving. The activities have different degrees of difficulty and the number of activities can be freely determined. Triggering at the same time memory skills, language skills, and quick reactions.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Children's Game, Deduction, Educational, Memory

name: Hexa-Zoki Puzzles
description:
From the rules:

Choose one of the 14 puzzle layouts to solve. Shuffle the deck and deal to each player the number of cards indicated in the figure for layout you are playing. Set the rest of the deck aside and out of play. Then solve the puzzle by connecting all the cards so that all touching sides match and the final puzzle shape matches the puzzle layout you are playing. First player to solve puzzle wins!

Ages 4 and up

Home Page: http://www.eternitygames.com/index.php?ID=hexa

name: Tetrano
description:
This game is a 3D four in a row (Qubic), but represented on a simpler 4 X 4 board. The board is a 4x4 grid and each player has 4 different size rings of his color. The sizes are such that the rings will nest.

The object is to complete "a line of four" 4 rings of same color to win the game. Three kinds of alignments on a "line of four" are possible: same size of rings across 4 spaces, 4 different progressive sizes across 4 spaces, or 4 concentric rings on the same square.

Interestingly enough with this set you can also play Four Score. To play Four Score, you must play from smallest to largest ring in a particular playing space (or visa versa). The object again is to make a "line" of four.

name: Pach-Ice-i
description:
Pach-Ice-i is a race-to-the-finish game for two players based mostly on pachisi. The objective is for a player to get all of his pieces to the opponent's starting pad before the opponent gets all of his pieces to the player's starting pad.

Rules Link

Game System

Icehouse Pieces
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Par-Trees-i
description:
Par-Trees-i is a game for two or four players using one Treehouse stash, a Volcano board and an ordinary six-sided die. The objective is to be the first player to get all three of his pieces to the center, in decreasing size order.

Rules Link

Game System

Icehouse Pieces
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Martian Coaster Chaturanga
description:
Martian Coaster Chaturanga is a game for two or four players using a Treehouse set and a set of Martian Coasters. Players move and capture pieces on the board, with the objective of having the greatest number of points at the end of the game.

Rules Link

Game System

Icehouse Pieces


Design Competitions

Ice Game Design Competition - Entry in 6th Competition

name: Start de Persen!
description:
Start the Printers:

You are a chief-editor of a major national newspaper and have to fill all 5 sections of your paper with news. You collect the news by moving over the gameboard and answering trivia. You can also steal news from another newspaper. When you have filled all the sections you have to deliver your paper to the printing-plant.
The game is like Trivial Pursuit with a newspaper theme.
Nice touch is that the dice is 2 times 5, the gameboard is a pentagon and the player pawn is a chair.

Subtitle of the game: Het verrrassende 5 krantenspel.

This game was produced as part of the celebration of 400 years of newspapers. The papers featured in this game are 5 major national newspapers of the netherlands: Volkskrant, NRC Handelsblad, Parool, trouw and Algemeen Dagblad.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Venusian Bowling
description:
102,000 years ago (2000 years before the Martian civilization reached its peak) the Venusians crushed the Martians early pyramids with their superior polyhedron shape. Today the only thing that remains of the Venusians is this game...

Players setup the pyramids in a cross formation touching each other, centered on an overturned mouse pad and role a D20 at the pyramids. Scoring more points for knocking down more pyramids. Players get additional balls for throwing strikes.

Game System

Icehouse Pieces

name: Link 26
description:
Millions of words, 100 categories and only 26 letters make Link 26 one of the most challenging new games of the year! Players must quickly think of words that link together using the letter drawn for a specific category.

For example, the category is "Things That Make Music." The letter "F" is drawn. Player A says "Flute". Now player B must use the last letter in that word to come up with the next thing that makes music... how about Euphonium?

Can be played as a solitaire game or with 2 or more players.

name: The Appreciation Game
description:
The Appreciation Game

The object of the game is to allow family and friends to become better acquainted and to be aware of and appreciate their own uniqueness while sharing together

name: APBA SuperStars Football
description:
A children's board game (preschool to early elementary school aged) simulating football using real NFL teams and players.

From the publisher:

"Be the first to make it down the field and score a touchdown with APBA NFL SuperStars! Stop for hot dogs, autographs, and more in a race to pay dirt! Be careful, special wild cards can slow you down! APBA NFL SuperStars includes game cards and pieces with real photos of your favorite football heroes and a game board designed like a football stadium. Introduce the child in your life to football in a fun and easy way! APBA NFL SuperStars is for two to six players ages 4-7"

name: Kreuz & Quer
description:
Content: board out of leather, 2 dice, 4 x 4 jewels

Each player tries to move his 4 stones from his/her own quarter crisscross to the opposite quarter. There are a lot of possibilities. Therefore, not only is luck necessary, but also skill and courage while trying to take a risk.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Baseball Frenzy
description: MLB-branded trivia game which features more than 800 up-to-date questions about all 30 teams and their players, complete with team logos and graphics. Most questions are multiple choice or true/false, so players don't need to be an expert to play. Gameplay is much like a real baseball game (hits, runs, outs, etc.) Contents include game board, 4 batting figures, 4 running figures, spinner, scoring pad and rules.

name: Naval Competition
description:
This is a multi-player card game in which players take part in the naval arms race in the run-up to World War I, aiming to build the best battleship and prepare for the upcoming conflict.

The game comes with 108 cards.

The designer also designed similar games subsequent to this: Tank Extravaganza and Prototype Competition.

Published in old Game Journal #61.
categories: Card Game, Nautical, Wargame, World War I

name: Tenka Fubu
description:
Tenka Fubu (War under the sky) is a multi-player game in which players take on the roles of the major samurai clans. The Takeda, Oda and Asai clans are battling for power from the 1560s to the 1570s. There's a political element, as alliances shift back-and-forth, as well as military action, as players' armies contest each other across the board.

Note: Â§©‰∏ãÂ∏ÉÊ≠¶ (Tenka Fubu) (under the sky - spread war) refers to the characters on Oda Nobunaga's personal seal that he inaugurated during this period.

name: Geister-Stunde
description:
Content:
board with watch hands, 20 action cards, 4 pawns, 1 wooden die

At midnight the ghosts slip out of the key holes and take their turns walking the halls. At 1 o'clock the spook ends. Which ghost will reach a key hole? Whoever does remains visible for the next 300 years! The ghosts throw the die and move according to the roll of the die. The watch moves forward and can be moved back by throwing a 1 or 6.

name: Dudenk√∂nig
description:
Content:
German dictionary "Duden", board,36 cards, 6 pawns, 6 counting stones, 1 die, 1 sand watch

When the players reach certain fields after throwing the die and moving, they have to fulfill different games around words and characters.
The player who won the most points and reaches the top most step of the stairs will be "Duden-King"

name: Electro Quizzman
description: This game exists out of 2 books (an expansion of 2 other books came as well). You place the book in the electronic device "computer" and put in the code of the page you want to play. Now you get trivia questions about the subject on the page of the book. This game can be played with two as well as alone. The electronic device is there, just to see whether you gave the right answer and to remember your scores.

name: Forts
description:
All is not peaceful in Fortland. Each country on the square-shaped continent is preparing an army to conquer their neighbors. The only problem is that their neighbors have armies invading their countries as well! The only answer is to build forts.

On each player's turn, that player rolls a six-sided die. The result is the number of actions their army must take this turn. Actions include marching, turning, building forts, and tearing down forts. The army must use all their actions during their turn, although they may be used in any order.

Game System

Icehouse Pieces

name: Det h√§nder med h√§nder
description:
This is a Swedish educative game where the player learns how to use and converse through sign language. The game is divided in two different games that are played on the same board but with a different cards.

One of the games is called Teckenspelet (the sign game), where one player takes a card with a picture of a person preforming a sign, and imitates it. Then the other players then tries to guess what the sign means.

The other game is called Meningsspelet (the sentence game). In this game you use the cards to create short sentences. This is done by small images of the sentence on the cards, with numbers telling where in the sentence they should be.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement

name: Killing Machine
description:
A science fiction infantry tabletop miniatures wargame retaining as many 'realistic' features as possible, while striving to minimize complexity.

The game, intended for use with 25/28mm miniatures (of whichever manufacturers the players prefer), features morale and fog-of-war/limited intelligence rules which have a significant impact on the battles - at least as much as actually killing the opposing forces. Troop types from lightly armoured basic infantry (say, Aliens Colonial Marines level) up to heavy power-armoured juggernauts (for example Starship Trooper Mobile Infantry or WH40K Terminators), as well as robots, cyborgs, remotes etc (thus allowing armies from the Terminator films, Cybermen, etc).

Vehicles are intentionally not featured within the rules, leaving it as a game with the focus on infantry (from high tech to very high tech) and their main support weapons.

Rather than treating tabletop battles as simply "line up 1000 points per side and fight until one side is gone" affairs, Killing Machine takes a more intelligent, mature look at this kind of skirmish gaming with its morale and intelligence rules.

name: Druid's Duel
description:
Druid’s Duel is a quick-playing card game. In Druid’s Duel, you’re a druid competing with other druids in a shape changing contest to display your wits and prowess. The druid who best adapts to the tactics of his or her opponents becomes the new head of the Circle.

Everyone starts the game with a full had of strategy cards. Each round you secretly pick a shape (lion, peacock, or jackrabbit) and a strategy card to play. When shapes are revealed, you may or may not get to discard your strategy card, depending on the shapes and strategies of your opponents.

If you’re a Jackrabbit, you succeed if you played the lowest strategy card. If you’re a Lion, you succeed if you played the highest strategy card. If you’re a Peacock, you succeed if no one else played a card that matches your card’s rank or suit. If you’re the first one to discard all of your strategy cards, you win.

Druid’s Duel is a game for two to four players. Druid’s Duel uses a standard Poker deck. You can read the rules at http://www.invisible-city.com/play/470. A four-player game takes about 30 minutes to play. Druid’s Duel is appropriate for ages 13 and up.
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Fantasy, Print & Play
mechanics: Hand Management, Simultaneous Action Selection, Trick-taking

name: Deathball
description:
From the Heresy Miniatures website

"Deathball is a popular gladiatorial pit-fighting variant that is played mainly in the Kingdom of Morica, ruled by Dark Duke Henry the Red, also known by his official title of Duke Scaldis II."

My description:

A game of fantasy mayhem loosely based on football, or maybe some ancient religious game from the Aztecs. Mayhem with miniatures, dice and strategy.

In the same family as Blood Bowl and Futbowel

Rules and board can be downloaded free for personal use at http://www.heresyminiatures.com/deathball.htm

name: Confrontation
description:
Confrontation was the name given to the original Warhammer 40,000: Rogue Trader skirmish game set on Necromunda in which gangs fought against each other, and attempted to increase their prestige and equipment.

The game was published over a number of issues of White Dwarf, starting with Issue 130, and with the last installment in Issue 142.

The mechanics focus on realism, allowing characters to make use of cover in specific ways, and requiring them to make specific tests when under fire. Actions are performed on a points basis, so a character could run forward and fire a few badly-aimed shots, or stand still and fire more rounds at a target.

The game contains a large amount of detail concerning combat and psychological effects.

Rules for purchasing and trading equipment for players' gangs, were also included.

The game appears to be the precursor of Necromunda, published five years later.

name: Spelet om Amerikas st√§der
description: Each player asks another player for a city card, and if he has it he has to hand it over. The goal is to complete as many sets as possible (each set corresponds to a province, and contains a varying number of cities).

name: Pre-Emptive Strike!
description:
Pre-Emptive Strike! is a board game for 2 to 6 players in which each player controls one of the factions warring for control of the desert region of Iraghania. Pre-Emptive Strike! is a tongue-in-cheek look at our world’s current leaders and the problems they can all create.

The Pre-Emptive Strike! download, print, and play game contains over 700 full color tokens, a huge board game map, scenarios, faction tiles, and two full 56 card decks of event cards. All you need to bring to the table are the dice.
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Point to Point Movement, Tile Placement

name: Uncle Lester's Word Game
description:
Word game based on dictionary definitions. Board is circular with each space designating one of 11 different question categories. Players roll 2 dice, one die determines number of spaces moved, the other the level of question difficulty and point value. First player to 20 points wins the game.

From the box: "Lester Drotts loved wooden toys, games, and Christmas. He began developing this word game in the 80's on his Apple IIC computer and was planning on having it produced for sale. We have put together his brainchild and hope you will learn to love Uncle Lester's Word Game."

name: Washington's Wars
description: These miniature rules also cover the French & Indian War. The rules also include sample historical battle scenarios, army lists and uniform guides for the British, French and US armies.

name: Safari Adventure Game
description:
Safari Adventure Game

Safari provides game players an opportunity to explore wildlife... an adventure filled journey around the world... Teaching about wildlife and geography, Safari has a strong but fun impact for pre-teens through adult..."

Players move around the board answering trivia questions and placing tokens in the back of a little plastic safari truck.

Includes a colorful board, dice, cards, stylized plastic Landrover trucks, score chips, rules, and storage insert.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Track Movement

name: Peloponnesian War
description:
Card game for 2 players simulating the Peloponnesian War. One player is Sparta, the other is Athens. Players take turns playing cards. Cards score Victory points, add to your force total, or have special effects. The player with the highest force at the end of a round wins the victory points. The cards include the personalities, land forces, naval forces, allies, and events unique to the conflict. A copy of the rules is available for free at:
http://www.angelfire.com/games2/warpspawn/Pelop.html
categories: Ancient, Card Game, Print & Play, Wargame

name: Jelly Bean Jumble
description: Players each get their own special Jelly Bean jumbler die. Jelly bean cards are laid out in front of the players. All players roll simultaneously and try to quickly grab a card matching the jelly beans they rolled. If a player rolls a wild, then they may grab a jelly bean card from another player. The winner is the player who grabs the most jelly bean cards.

name: Or-Connek
description: The game is played on a board topologically equivalent to a 15x15 grid with all points connected horizontally, vertically and diagonally. The manner of play is best described as both reminiscent of Go and yet markedly different. A variable number of pieces, subject to strict rules, are placed in a line on each turn. Opponents' pieces are captured by replacement when any but the first piece placed onto the board [which must be on a free space] overlies an opposing piece, but one's own pieces block new lines of pieces.

name: Nest Egg
description:
The objective of this "eco card game" for Ages 11 and up is to collect sets of cards (consisting of a family of an adult males, an adult female and any number of chicks) of endangered native New Zealand birds. There are 6 birds to collect, worth different points, in descending order of value they are: Kakapo, Albatross, Kiwi, Takahe, Kokako and Blue Duck. The game is intended to educate about the conservation of these species and the threats that they face in the wild.

The mechanic of the game is similar to the card game Rummy - on each turn the player picks up a card, either the top card from the deck or the top card from the discard pile, and then the player discards a card. Once a player has a complete family they must lay it down on the table.

In addition there are three other types of card with various properties. These are protection measures, conservation actions and threats. These can be played at any stage of the game during a players own turn.

Threats can be played against the families laid down by other players and will either destroy a whole family or only take one or more chicks depending on the type of threat. Threats include cats and dogs, rats, stoats and weasels, long line fishing, plastic waste, developers, infertility and virus. Protection measures are laid down on families on the table and they protect against some of the threats. Conservation actions allow a variety of different actions such as exchanging cards with other players, picking up an additional cards and neutralizing threats.

Each round finishes when one player goes out by playing all the cards in their hand onto the table. Points are scored for going out, for each bird in the families on the table and for having protection measures in place on those families. Minus points are scored for having threat cards remaining in a players hand when the round ends. A game ends after a set number of rounds or when a player reaches a set points target.

name: Sommerland
description:
Content: board, 16 pawns in 4 colors, 1 die

Vacations have started. 4 families want to travel by train.
But - oh, my gosh! The ticket seller has mixed up the seat reservations, and now all persons are sitting in the wrong wagons. The player who has his family together first wins.

name: Near Chess
description:
Near Chess is similar to Skirmish Chess by Tony Paletta, in that both start with pieces forward one row, eliminating the initial double move of the pawn.

The purpose of Near Chess differs from Skirmish Chess however, in that its purpose to be one of the fastest ways to introduce people to chess, and the world of chess variants, without being trivial to those who play it still. Near Chess expands upon the pawn simplification of Skirmish Chess, and removes rules from regular chess that aren't needed and also makes it harder for new players to learn. The end result is a
game that can be taught quickly to newbies, and get them playing faster.

name: S√∂guspili√∞
description:
One of the oldest Icelandic boardgames, Söguspilið (The Game of History) gives you the change of living through Icelandic history from the Age of Settlement to modern times.

The game has two main parts, firstly you travel round the outermost circle on the board (The Circle of Ages) trying to get as much money as possible before you embark on the journey towards the center of the board where you can land on black (penalty) or white (bonus) spots and have to draw a card for each spot you land on which tells you the nature of the penalty or the bonus.

name: Jag l√§r mig l√§sa
description:
Learn to read!

This game will help you to spell the pictures right. Help the youngsters in a funny way to learn how to read.

name: Playoff
description:
Playoff is a fast paced discard game similar to Crazy Eights. It is played on a mat and uses a special deck of cards.

Play a card that matches the suit or value of the previous played card. If a player is unable to do so, cards must be drawn until there is a legal play, and the player pays one chip to the pot for each card drawn.

The eights in the deck are replaced by 'star' cards, which allows players to change suit and collect the current pot. The player with the most chips wins.

In 1976 a version featuring Jack Klugman and Tony Randall, The Odd Couple, was published, with Klugman and Randall cards in the deck.
publishers: E. S. Lowe Company Inc., Milton Bradley

name: John Company and the Conquest of India
description:
A Miniatures Game System for Warfare on the Sub-Continent 1750-1860.

Caters for all miniatures scales with each player controlling roughly a brigade (ca. 50 figure bases). In addition to the wargame rules and army profiles included are a bibliography, scenarios, notes on figure sources and uniform guides.

The scenarios included are:


The Battle of Assaye (2nd Maratha War, 1803)
Desperate Measures: Outside Kabul (1st Afghan War, 1841)
Meeting Engagement at Mudiwal (1st Sikh War, 1845)
The Relief of Luckhipore (Indian Mutiny, 1857)

name: Monopoly: Regensburg
description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μœåνος (alone or single) + polein πωλε·øñν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements of Regensburg, in Germany.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Magistratvm
description:
Welcome to the Roman Republic! The aim of the game is to win political control of the Republic. The two areas of play are the Provinces in the electoral circuit and the Offices. Players will place influence tokens in the Provinces in the hope of winning provincial elections which provide influence. Magistrates and Governors also provide influence, and can be used to take special actions which will help players defeat their rivals. The game ends once all 24 Provinces have been decided, in which case the player with the most influence from both the Provinces and the Offices wins.

Equipment Needed:
a) 1 standard piecepack;
b) about $2 in change to represent gold (ideal breakdown would be 50 x 1c, 10 x 5c, 10 x 10c;
c) cubes in 4 different colors to use as influence markers (20 per player);
d) a printout of the Table of Offices from the rules

Rules can be found on the Piecepack Wiki.

Game System

Piecepack Game System

name: Flip-Flop
description: A tile turning game in which players attempt find the fewest moves that will result in turning all tiles in a 3x3 grid to a to a particular side. Each tile has a different power, which may be used in flipping other tiles, so careful planning and sequencing of tile flips is the key to winning. Similar to Ricochet Robots, players study the layout and make bids about how many moves it will take to reach a solution. Players score points by successfully reaching a solution in light of others' bids.

name: Air War Europe
description:
“Basic Simulation of the Air War component of WWII. Victory: There are two ways to win: Reduce your opponent to zero Production Points. Accumulate twice the Strategy Tokens of your opponent.”

The game is played with three types of cards - a Mission Deck, an Event Deck, and Plane Decks (with unique cards for each player, Allied and Luftwaffe). Players set up attack missions against their adversary and attempt to intercept incoming attack missions. Strategy Tokens are received for successfully completing Ground Support Missions.
categories: Aviation / Flight, Card Game, World War II

name: Fifth Element
description: A card game based on the movie of the same name. One player represents the side of Good, the other the side of Evil. The players draw a hand of eight cards which feature characters and elements from the movie. After discarding and redrawing up to four cards, the players compare their hands and the player whose cards have the highest total wins. The first player to win three hands in a row wins the game.
categories: Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction

name: Advanced Star Frontiers Lensman
description:
“In this game you play a Lensman Ranger with his intergalactic assault scout ship. You must use your Lensman Powers to undermine enemy bases while battling any Morad ships that you encounter . . . When you have successfully infiltrated and brought down all four Morad quadrant bases in the Second Galaxy, you win.”

This solitaire game is played by randomly selecting cards from a deck containing a variety of Morad ships (frigates, destroyers, and cruisers) and four “Quadrent Base” cards. You must defeat each ship until you have encountered and successfully infiltrated all four bases. Each ship is rated for power, hull strength, number of weapons/attacks, and weapon strength.

name: Afrika Korps
description:
From the deigner :
“Simulation of the North Africa campaign of WWII.
Card game for two players.
One player is the Germans (& Italians), the other player is the Commonwealth (British & Allies).”

Each game turn consists of three phases. In the Logistics Phase, the players draw a hand of cards (the number drawn by each player varies from six to eight depending on the stage of the war). In the Strategy Phase, the players may discard up to three cards and draw replacements. In the Battle Phase, the players reveal their hands and the player with the highest Force point total wins the hand and takes a Terrain Token from the loser.

Each player starts the game with three Terrain Tokens. The game ends when one player controls all six Terrain Tokens.
categories: Card Game, Wargame, World War II

name: Amulets
description:
A fantasy themed multi-player Mastermind style deduction game.

"A (not really) fantasy game of deduction for 3-5 players. Five spirits are captured in five amulets. The wizards try to find out their correct placements on the altar to cast the freeing spell. Succeeding means honour, failure means
eternal doom."

Designer's note: "This game, years old and deriving from boring school times, is nothing else but a master mind clone, but a funky multi-player one. Experienced players should not need more than 5-6 questions. This is not really a party game, since all players stare at their notes and beg each active player for a thinking break :) - give it a try."

name: Ancient Skirmish
description:
“Battle between two Ancient Armies. Bronze Age/Age of the Chariot. Each figure represents a group of 500 men. Victory: You win if you destroy the opposing General or Camp.”

Chits or miniatures are used to represent the combat units. The units come in six types: Heavy Infantry, Light Infantry, Heavy Cavalry, Light Cavalry, General, and Camp.

The game is played on an 8x8 grid (chessboard) representing the battlefield. Each player starts with one unit on each square of his back two rows. Units may not stack.
There are four custom card decks used in the game: the Infantry Deck, Cavalry Deck, Shock Deck, and Missile Deck. The cards are used to initiate movement and combat, and to defend against attacks.

name: Arab Israeli Wars
description:
“Solo Card Game System simulating the Arab Israeli Wars 1948+. Currently only cards set for the Israeli War of Independence is available. The player takes the role of the Israelis. Arab deployments are automatic.”

The game is played on three Fronts: the Northern Frontier (Galilee), Central Frontier (Jerusalem), and Southern front (Negev). Each Front is represented by six Territory Tokens, all of which are under the control of the Israelis (the solo player) at the start of the game. If the Arabs are able to acquire control all six tokens on any one Front, you suffer a Complete Loss. If you win all battles on all three Fronts for two turns in a row, you achieve a Decisive Victory. If the Arabs run out of unit cards, you achieve an Attrition Victory.

The Unit cards are intended to represent Arab and Israeli forces involved in the 1948 hostilities. Units are drawn and played to the Fronts - Arab units to designated Fronts and Israeli cards as desired by the player. Each turn one card is drawn from the Event deck. The Event card confers benefits to one side or the other.

name: Autumn Mist
description:
“Abstract simulation of the Battle of the Bulge (Ardennes). Each figure (unit) represents a division. One player is the Germans, the other is the Allies (Americans & British). Time Table: Each turn is one day starting December 16, 1944. Allies may make Air Attacks starting Dec 26. Victory: The Germans win if they can occupy Bastogne, St. Vith, Liege, Namur, and Dinant. The Americans win if the Destroy all German Divisions or by January 16.”

The game is played on a 14x14 grid and utilizes a deck of approximately seventy cards. Movement and Attack cards must be played in order for your units to move or attack. The number 1 or 2 appears on each of these cards, establishing the distance of the movement or range for the attack. There are also cards which can be played to negate Movement and Attack cards.

name: Battlestar Galactica
description:
A two player boardgame based on the original Battlestar Galactica series, with one player as the Cylons and the other as the Battlestar Galactica.

The game is played on a single row of 100 squares. At one end is Caprica, the starting space for the Galactica, and at the other end is the lost colony of Earth. Every third square is a Planet space and the remaining squares are Deep Space.

The Cylon player is seeking to destroy all of the Galactica’s fighters. The Battlestar player wins if the Galactica makes it to Earth with some fighters left.
categories: Fighting, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction

name: Blitz
description:
“Card game. Simulates the Battle of Britain. July-September 1940. Players will have to make their own sets of cards.
The RAF and Luftwaffe have their own unique decks. Both decks have 62 cards. Notice that most cards have a force value. The Germans also need 20 tokens to represent bomb damage.”

Both players start the game with four cards. The players draw two cards at the start of each turn, with the maximum hand size at the end of the turn being eight cards. The German player has the option not to play a raid, in which case the turn ends. If the German player plays a raid, the players alternate playing force cards until neither player wants to play a card. The strength of the opposing forces are compared. If the RAF has a higher force total, the raid is stopped. If the German has the higher force total, then the amount of bombing damage caused by the raid is determined and added to the German’s score.

“If the German’s accumulate 20 points of bombing damage then they win. Hitler decides to go ahead with operation Sealion. If the German player goes to draw a card and there are no cards left in his deck the British win. Hitler postpones operation Sealion indefinitely.”
categories: Card Game, Print & Play, World War II

name: Delta Skirmish
description:
“Board & card game for 2 players. Highly abstracted skirmish level combat. Simulation of a counter-terrorist team operation. One side is the commandos: Delta/SAS/GSG-9/GIGN/etc. The other side is Terrorists holding hostages in a building. Victory: To win the Delta team must kill all the terrorists before taking 4 casualties. The Terrorists win if they kill 4 Delta team members, which allows them time to kill the hostages.”

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the commandos and terrorists. The terrorist group is composed of one Leader and seven Followers. The commando force consists of one Team Leader, three Shooters, two Demolitions Experts, and two Snipers. A custom deck of cards is central to the play of the game. The players draw hands of cards from the common deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, or defend.

“The Special Forces have many more cards at their disposal, which reflects their high degree of training & experience.”

name: Flying Circus
description:
“Card game for 2 players. WWI Aerial Dogfight Simulation. One player is the Germans, the other is the Allies. Victory: The first player to shoot down 4 enemy machines wins the battle. Use coins to keep track of ‘Kills.’”

The game is played using a custom card deck comprised of six suits made up of twelve cards numbered 1 to 12. These suits are Pilots, Allied Planes, German Planes, Tactics, Shooting, and Flying. All of the cards are usable by either player except for the Plane Cards - Allied Planes may only be used by the Allied player and German Planes may only be used by the German player.

Each turn the players are dealt hands of five cards. They may discard and redraw up to three cards. Each player then plays an Attack which must include a Pilot card and a Plane card. An attack may also include one card from each of the other three suits (Shooting, Tactics, and Flying.) A kill is scored when the total value of the cards played in an Attack is equal to or greater than the Attack played by the opposing player.
categories: Aviation / Flight, Card Game, Print & Play, World War I

name: Gerrymandering
description:
“Players take turns changing the district lines in order to win the election.”

The game is played on a 10x10 grid. Each square represents a city block. At the start of the game, 100 Block Chits are randomly placed on the map. These Block Chits are randomly created by rolling for four characteristics: Income, Party, Race, and Issues.

Each player supports a candidate running for office. The candidate has eight profile characteristics: Income, Party, Race, two Allied Races, and three Issues ranked for priority.

There are four phases to the game. In the first phase, district lines are drawn by the players taking turns placing 1d6 District Markers on the map until all fifty District Markers have been placed. In the second phase, District Lines are redrawn – the players are able to move a randomly determined number of District Markers.

The third phase is the Census, in which the Block characteristics of the fifty blocks marked as part of the District are totaled. The fourth phase is the Election, in which the District votes for each candidate are calculated based on the Census data and the profile characteristics of the candidates.

The player whose candidate gets the most votes in the election wins the game.
publishers: Academic Gaming Review, Warp Spawn Games

name: Gunslingers
description:
“Board, dice, & card game for 2+ players. Wild West Theme. Battle between gunslingers. Abstract skirmish level combat. Each figure represents a single man (unit). Victory: You win if you kill all enemy gunslingers.”

The game is played on a chessboard or any other 8x8 grid. Chits are used to indicate terrain features. Miniatures or counters are used to represent the gunslingers. There are seven types of gunslingers represented in the game: Cowboy, Outlaw, Indian, Lawman, Soldier, Pistol, and Rifle. Each type of gunslinger is rated for seven attributes, including Guts, Smarts, Cool, Eyes, and Hands.

The Action Deck is a custom deck of cards central to the play of the game. The players draw a hand of cards for each gunslinger from this common deck. Card play determines when units may move, attack, and defend.

Optional rules are provided for horses, shotguns, and carrying multiple guns.

name: Grendel & Beowulf
description:
“Board Game for 2 players. One player takes the role of the Hero Beowulf. The other player takes the role of the Monster Grendel. Victory: Slay your Foe. The first player to reduce his opponent to zero or less hits wins. Each player starts the game with 20 Hit Points.”

The game board is a track 13 spaces long. Each space on the board is a named location. These range from the Great Hall and other places favorable to the Danes at one end, to the dangerous swamps at the opposite end which favor Grendel.

Attack, Defense, and Ally Cards are used in combat. The other cards are used to perform various functions, such as assisting in travel or healing wounds. Some cards may be used to impede your opponent’s travel or to require your opponent to discard cards.
categories: Card Game, Fighting, Medieval, Mythology, Print & Play
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Open Drafting, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Goblin Quest
description:
“Teams of Goblins run around, get into mischief, wreak havoc, and try to not get killed. Not unlike Space Scouts.”

The game is played using a custom deck containing four types of cards: Mission, Threat, Mishap, and Aid. Each player starts with four Goblin characters, each of which has two to three skills.

The object of the game is to be the first player to accumulate a specific number of Victory Points. Victory Points are gained by completing Missions (the amount awarded depending on the difficulty) and overcoming Threats. Victory Points may be spent to give your Goblin characters new skills and to replace a Goblin character than has been lost.

name: Global Warming
description:
“Solo card game. Abstract simulation of Global Warming. Winning & Losing: If the Heat Level ever gets to 10, Global Warming is not controlled and Civilization as we know it is doomed. If at the End of the game the Heat Level is 9 or below, humanity has averted complete disaster. The Game ends when there are no cards left in the Heat Deck.”

The game is played using a custom deck of cards made up of four suits: Pollution, Consequences, Political Will, and Solutions. Each suit had thirteen cards numbered from one to thirteen. A normal deck of cards can be used if the player does not wish to construct the custom deck.

name: Gettysburg
description:
“American Civil War card game for 2 players. Gettysburg: 1-3 July, 1863. The biggest battle ever fought on the soil of North America. One side is the Union, the other is the Confederacy.” The game is played with a custom card deck. The cards portray the military leaders, weapons, locations, and events which played a part in the conflict.

Each round the players take turns playing cards or combinations. The player whose cards have the higher Force value wins the round. Ties are won by the Union player. The first player to win five rounds wins the game.

name: Gamma Chess
description:
“PREMISE: This plays like a cross between Chess and Backgammon. SET UP: Regular Chessboard and pieces plus two dice. OBJECT: Move all of your men to your opponents back row.”

Each turn a player rolls two dice to determine which pieces may be moved (a chart assigns each number on a d6 to one type of chess piece). Pieces may only be moved forward or sideways, not backward. However, a piece can only capture when it is moving forwards. When a piece is captured it is returned to the back row of the owning player.

A short-game variant provides that the game is won by the first player to move a King off the board.

name: French Revolution
description:
“Card game for 2+ players. Simulation of the French Revolution (starting 1789). Victory: The first player to accumulate 10 Reform points is able to consolidate the Revolution and wins the game. Setup: The most ‘French’ player begins as the leader of the Revolution.”

The game is played using a custom card deck made up of five different types of cards: Unrest, Revolutionary Tactics, Reforms, Oppression (Reactionary Tactics), and Anti-Revolutionary. Reform points are scored by first playing Unrest, Tactics, and Oppression Cards to become or remain the leader of the revolution, and then playing Reform Cards, each of which scores one Reform point. Opposing players may negate a Reform card by playing an Anti-Revolutionary card.

name: Firebase Nam
description:
A card game based on a tactical battle in the Vietnam War. One player is responsible for defending a U.S. firebase, the other controls the attacking VC/NVA units. Each player uses a custom deck which is made up of cards representing combat units, fortifications, supply, tactics and morale.

Each turn the players build hands of cards. The player with the hand having the highest combined force total wins the round.

The player who wins the most hands out of 9 wins the game, except that if either player wins 3 hands in a row then the game ends in a victory for that player.

name: Faiths
description:
Each player represents a major religion attempting to spread throughout the population of over more than half of the territories on a map depicting the Middle East and Asia. The game is played using a custom deck containing two types of cards: Magnitude Cards and Event Cards.

The religions represented in the game, and their starting territories, are as follows: Shinto (Japan), Taoism (South China), Confucianism (North China), Buddhism (South India), Jainism (North India), Hinduism (East India), Sikhism (West India), Zoroastrianism (Iran), Islam (Arabia), Judaism (South Israel), Christianity (North Israel).

name: Exploration in the Age of Sail
description:
“Card game for 2-4+ players. Theme of Exploration during the 15th to 18th Centuries.”

“There are 2 Decks: The Expedition Deck. The Exploration Deck.”

“There are 4 types of cards in the Expedition Deck: Explorer, Ship, Crew, Save. There are 3 types of cards in the Exploration Deck: Ocean, Hazard, Discovery. The Discovery cards themselves when claimed serve as a record of Discovery Points (DP). Discovery cards you claim are kept in your Victory pile.”

“Victory: The player with the most discovery points at the end of the game is the winner. End of Game: The game ends when the Exploration deck has been gone through twice.”

name: Deadlock
description:
A science-fiction game of planetary colonization, military conquest, and diplomacy. The game is played on a 5x5 grid. Terrain is randomly generated each game.

“Board/Card/Record Keeping game for 2-4+ players. Based on the 1996 Sci-Fi PC Game ‘Deadlock: Planetary Conquest.’ Races: Each player picks as their identity one of the 7 available races - Human, ChCh-t, Uva Mosk, Tarth, Re’Lu, Maug, Cyth. Victory: You win by occupying all territories on the map.”

The detailed turn sequence has 20 phases: Upkeep Phase, Labor Phase, Event Phase, Population Phase, Morale Phase, Taxation Phase, Rebellion Phase, Resource Phase, Diplomacy Phase, Trade Phase, Black Market Phase, Build Phase, Production Phase, Ability Phase, Transport Phase, Attack Phase, Plane Return Phase, Colonization Phase, Research Phase, and End Phase.

name: Cold War Era
description:
“Simulation of Soviet-American Relations during the Cold War Era (1945-1991). One player takes the role of America (USA). The other player is the Soviets (USSR). Players use Power Tokens to keep track of their Scores in the Areas of Power. Use poker Chips, coins, counters, etc. to represent PT. There are 5 Areas of Power: Military, Economic, Social, Espionage, and Territorial.”

“There are 3 ways to achieve Victory. General Victory: If your scores in the 5 AOP are greater than your opponent’s for two consecutive turns, you win. Power Victory: If your scores in any 3 AOP (except Espionage) are double or greater than your opponent’s for two consecutive turns, you win. Crisis Victory: If your opponent goes to zero (or less) in any AOP (except Espionage) you win.”
