name: Battle to the Gates of Hell
description:
Battle to the Gates of Hell, Bunker Hill June 17, 1775

On the night of June 16th, 1775, Colonel William Prescott of the Massachusetts Army of Observation and his regiment were ordered out onto Charlestown Peninsula under cover of darkness to erect fortifications in preparation of a forthcoming British attack there. Fortune had conspired with the Americans that June in the form of a superior espionage network, allowing the Americans to control and fortify the high ground before the British were even on the peninsula.

Units come in four colors and comprise two different armies.
The Massachusetts Army of Observation is represented by blue colored pieces. Units of the British army are represented by
red, orange and beige colored pieces.

name: Reich of the Dead
description:
The time is January 27th 1945.

Allied Command HQ
Excerpts from the Wolf Group Briefing
Without cause the Germans winter offensive through the Ardennes Forrest has abruptly come to a halt. Along the entire front, hordes of refugees have flooded into Allied camps all telling the tales of the dead coming back to life. Something has gone horribly wrong and zombie German Army humanoids, known as Kroids, are attacking with organized military efficiency.

- Who is leading the Kroids?
At this time we have no idea who, or what, is controlling or leading these Kroid forces. Reports have led to speculation that the leader of the Kroids is a summoned demon that was resurrected or awakened by the experiments of the SS Project Diabolus team at Castle Wewelsburg in Germany.

- Where do the Kroids come from?
All we know at the moment is that they are the reanimated remains of fallen soldiers or zombies – but not the mindless zombies seen in the Dracula movies we watched in the theaters as kids. Instead, these zombies appear to independently think and communicate. As they attack and kill our troops their ranks grow in numbers. What we do know is that a dead soldier, in any condition, burned, missing limbs or shot all to hell will, if not 'finished,' rise as a Kroid within 24 hours. A 'finished' corpse is one that has had its head removed.

- Why are the Kroids here and what do they want?
Sadly we have no idea. We believe this is the result of same wacky Nazi secret weapon experiment gone horribly wrong and we will just have to deal with it as best as we can. We do know that a Nazi machine called the Cyclomatron was built and activated by a team of SS scientists and engineers working at Castle Wewelsburg in Germany. Somehow this machine is the power behind these Kroids.

- How do we defeat the Kroids?
To date our strategy has been one of attacking the Third Reich's ability to wage war. We have been very successful in dismantling their infrastructure by destroying factories, refineries and transport. We have denied them the ability to manufacture and deploy the tools of war. The Kroids have no supply lines and they pick their tools of war up off the ground. They do not need to eat; they do not need to sleep. Their machines do not run on gas and ball bearings. Simply put, we have to change our entire strategy. As commanders you must think with your head. A casualty in your command is a new recruit for the Kroid army. The orders you have already received detail our current strategy, which is one of containment. Until further notice we are going on the defensive.
categories: Horror, Miniatures, World War II, Zombies
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Peaced Off!
description:
Peaced Off! is a small cardgame, produced limited numbers, mostly as a present given to business acquaintances.

It is a simple trick taking game, with a scoring system based on collecting sets of matching cards, including nuns, that score negative points, unless you collect them all.

name: Sudden Full Contact: The Battle of the Bulge 1944
description:
Sudden Full Contact - The Battle of the Bulge 1944 is a detailed new VARIANT Historical Module that tells the story of the Battle of the Bulge and the struggle for the critical village of Hotton, which lays astride the Ourthe River crossing. The gamer is transported into a pitched battle, with German attackers hurling tanks and men against the American defenders in a desperate attempt to ward off the defeat of the Third Reich. Standing in their way are resourceful Yank engineers and tank-men with no intention of taking one step back. This is not a complete game. Ownership of Beyond Valor: ASL Module 1 and Yanks: ASL Module 3 are needed to play this game.

The entire battle-site was mapped on foot by designer Pedro Ramis and the detail is incredible! Scenarios bring you into the ranks of the 23rd Armored Engineer Battalion, Kampfgruppe Bayer, Task Force Mize, CCR, and other hard-fighting combat elements.

The games comes with new historical game map and 8 scenarios.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Wargame, World War II

name: Devils in the Woods: The Battle of the Bulge 1944
description:
Devils in the Woods—The Battle of the Bulge 1944 is a new scenario pack that tells the story of the Battle of the Bulge from the perspective of the dog faces of the American 3rd Armored Division, facing down an onrushing German 116th Panzer Division during 20-24 December, 1944. The gamer is hurled into the height of the most dangerous period of the Battle of the Bulge, in pitched battles that play out over two historical maps, covering Melines and the Quatre Bras crossroads portions of the battlefield.

The game is an Advanced Squad Leader module.

The entire battle-site was mapped on foot by designer Pedro Ramis and the detail is incredible! Scenarios bring you into the ranks of the 23rd Armored Engineer Battalion, Kampfgruppe Bayer, Task Force Mize, CCR, and other hard-fighting combat elements.

The game comes with two historical game maps and 12 scenarios. The scenarios are numbered #9-#20.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game

name: Midway
description:
“Historical simulation of the WWII battle of Midway. Two player set piece Dice game. One player is the Japanese, the other is the Americans. Flowcharts are used instead of Maps.”

Each player controls squadrons of aircraft which are moved on the player’s flowchart. Spaces on the flowchart represent different activities and locations: Carrier, Takeoff, Patrol, Search, Second Search, Attack, and Return. A separate Carrier Box flowchart has spaces related to carrier activities and locations: On Deck, Takeoff, and Refuel/Rearm.

The game portrays the following types of US and Japanese aircraft: Wildcat, Devastator, Dauntless, Avenger, Buffalo, Marauder, Vindicator, Catalina, Flying Fortress, Zero, Kate, Val, and Judy.

The object of the game is to destroy all of the opponent’s carriers.

name: Plassey
description:
“Card game simulating the battle of Plassey 1757. One player is the Army of the East India Company. The other player is the Bengal Army. An Anglo-Indian Force of 3,000 men defeated a Bengal Army of 50,000 men.”

Each player uses a custom card deck. Each deck has five types of cards: Leader, Unit, Artillery, Defense, and Special. The cards depict elements of the historical campaign.

Each turn the players fight a battle by playing melds of cards. The meld having the higher total force value wins the battle. The winner of a battle takes one Territory Maker from the other player.

The object of the game is to control all five Territory Markers. At the start of the game the British have two Territory Markers and the Bengali have three.
categories: Age of Reason, Card Game, Print & Play, Wargame

name: Pueblos
description:
"Card game for 2-4+ players. Theme: American Southwest Indian Pueblo Peoples."

The game uses a custom deck of 44 cards composed of six suits: Gods, Dances, People, Crafts, Homes, and Crops. The cards in each suit are numbered from 1 to 7. There are also two Misfortune cards in the deck: Raids and Drought.

"Victory: The first player to make 5 Melds wins the game. All 5 Melds must be of different types."

name: Sea Intercept
description:
“Card game for 2 players. Modern Naval Warfare Theme.”

The card deck contains four types of cards: Unit, Detect, Attack, and Counter. Units Cards are deployed as part of a player’s forces and remain in play until the end of the game unless destroyed. Detect Cards and Attack Cards are used to make attacks against enemy units. Counter Cards are used to counter attacks.

“The game ends when a player goes to draw a card, and there are no cards left in the deck. The player with the most deployed units at the end of the game wins.”
categories: Card Game, Fighting, Modern Warfare, Nautical

name: Star Craft Spawn
description:
“Two player card game set in the StarCraft universe.” Inspired by the popular computer game.

Each player gets a unique deck – the Terran Deck or the Zerg Deck. The decks include eight types of cards: Spacecraft, Infantry, Vehicle, Hero, Building, Faction, Advance, and Event. Both players start with a hand of five cards and their Command Structure deployed.

Each turn a player may deploy cards. Deployed Units (Spacecraft, Infantry, Vehicle, and Hero Cards) may be used to attack opposing Units or Buildings. The object of the game is to destroy your opponent’s Command Structure, represented by a Building Card.
categories: Card Game, Fighting, Science Fiction, Video Game Theme

name: Wizards
description:
“Two-player Card game based on the animated film WIZARDS by Ralph Bakshi. One player is the good Wizard Avatar. The other player is his evil brother Blackwolf. Both battle for world domination. On Avatar’s side is Magic, Elven Races, and Faerie Folk. Blackwolf's armies are filled with Mutants, Demons, and Ancient Technologies.”

Each player uses a separate custom card deck composed of the following types of cards: Leader, Knowledge, Armies, Place, Event, Technology, Strategy, Resources, and Morale. In addition, the Avatar Deck includes Magic Cards. Each hand the players seek to play cards having the highest total in Power points. The winner of a hand receives a Victory Token. The first player to acquire seven Victory Tokens wins the game.
categories: Card Game, Fantasy, Fighting, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Tarot Wars
description:
"CCG style rules for Tarot Decks. There are so many nice Tarot Decks it’s a shame not to game with them. Card game for 2+ players."

Each card in the Tarot deck is classified as a Character (with a designated Force value), Event, or Modifier Card. Character Cards stay in play until they are killed. Modifier Cards are attached to Characters. Event Cards are discarded as soon as they are played.

Each player starts with fifty Life Points. Each time a Character sustains damage, the amount is deducted from the controlling player's Life Points. The object of the game is to reduce your opponent to zero Life Points.

name: Acronymity: Trivia Edition
description: This follow-up to Acronymity takes things a step further -- while the original game was about defining acronyms, this game features trivia questions whose answers are acronyms. Players get to move forward 1-3 spaces for answering the correct acronym, 4-6 spaces for answering AND defining the acronym. Special spaces on the game board add further variation to play through challenges, all-play events, and changes to the meanings of dice rolls. Team play is encouraged.

name: MSK 6 Extension Kit for 1829 (Northern & Southern Boards)
description:
The 18xx MSK-6 extension kit adds 8 tiles (3 of #52, 1 of #64, 1 of #65, 1 of #66, 1 of #67, and 1 of #68.) with a half-page of rules for their use.

Expands:

* 1829
* 1829 Northern Board

name: Turtle Run
description:
"Board & Dice game for 2 players. Each player controls a nest of newly hatched baby sea turtles trying to make their way across the beach to the sea."

The game is played on a chess board or other 8x8 grid. One edge of the board represents the ocean shore. The row on the opposite end of the board is the Nest Row, where the players' nests are located. Each player starts with six baby sea turtle tokens in the player's nest. There are three predator tokens - the crab, gull, and raccoon.

"The player who gets the most of his turtles off the map & into the Sea wins."

name: F√§delzoo
description:
Fädelzoo (Threading Zoo) is a collection of four games all based on the concept of threading pieces onto or off of a string. The theme is animals in a zoo -- the animals have discovered a new favorite past time, which is to connect all of the zoo inhabitants in a line. They first group the animals together by type (all the penguins, then the elephants..), then link the groups together.

Three of the games are interactive and one of these is cooperative. One is to match the threading to a picture (many pictures for this are included), another is a race to complete the threading first but pieces are only added when the right die roll is thrown, and the third is to cooperatively build a single thread as fast as possible. The fourth activity in the box is a solitaire exercise.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Animals, Children's Game, Educational
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Pattern Recognition, Set Collection

name: Peuple Paille
description:
Le Peuple Paille (the hay people) are participating in the challenges of the Celtic tribes are playing for the honour of the Dame Bleue. They go to the side of the victorious ones and help name the supreme winner.
But in these fairy lands, a lot of things are happening: friendly dances, holy rites, terrifying apparitions of the "burner"...
In order to face those new challenges, you have to be opportunistic and you have to get 'the hay people' to admire you in order to win !

This is an expansion to the Dame Bleue game.

name: Loser's Game
description:
Loser’s Game is a relatively simple trick-taking game for three to four players. Your goal is to end each round with 3 of a kind and 4 of a kind in the cards you took. The twist in this game is that it blatantly favors the underdog; the player with the lowest score at the start of each hand gets to choose what suit is trump.

All you need is a Poker deck (Jokers removed) to play.

name: 18HeXX
description: Fictional/Variable Map System for 18xx. Large Groups of Hexes in cutouts.

name: Millennium Wars Advanced: The Lebanon Scenarios
description:
The game is based on the Advanced Millennium Wars system, incorporating asymmetric situations, non-state actors, and political constraints. The game scale is 10km per hex, units are brigades or divisions, or cadres/groups.

The Advanced Millennium Wars system is quite unique relative to traditional wargame designs. Rather than utilize quantitative "factors" for such things as movement and combat, the game is entirely missions based, with each unit being capable of performing a given set of missions as indicated by icons on the backs of the unit counters. Missions are combined into Operations against specific targets, which can include other units in play, populations centers on the map, or political capital. Targets on the receiving end of such operations must execute specific casualty chains to account for losses caused by offensive operations. The game also utilizes a unique "Tier" system that determines the number of phases the units of any given faction may conduct missions per turn.

The full game (not yet released) explores the past, present, and future of the Arab/Israeli struggle. Includes a 56 page booklet focused on the history behind (and yet to come of) the game.

Scenarios included in the full game:
1. '48 War Phase 1
2. '48 War Phase 2
3. '67 War
4. '67 War Jihad (What if)
5. ‘73 War
6. ’82 Lebanon War
7. ’06 Military Solution in Southern Lebanon
8. '12 Hypothetical

The Counterfact magazine game includes only scenarios 6 and 7.

name: Super Vache L'extension
description:
This expansion offers you to play Super Vache (Super cow) up to 6 players now. There are new fields, new powers for your cow, new "coup-fourré".

Expands:

Super Vache
categories: Animals, Card Game, Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Farming
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Open Drafting, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Pele's Perils
description:
From the publisher:

This fun, educational game teaches about the Hawaiian culture and the hazards of living on a volcanic island.

Pictures and arrows show the way to go UP by sharing goodness with others, and the way to go DOWN because of the dangers of the volcano.

When a player is lucky enough to meet Pele (peh-leh), the goddess of fire, she will uncover a secret passage through a lava tube to the top of the volcano.

But, you must be careful! If you get caught in the middle of a lava flow, you may need to be rescued by a helicopter!

Good luck and mahalo (mah-hah-lo) (thank you) for spreading lots of aloha (ah-lo-hah) (love).
The first player to reach Pele (peh-leh) at FINISH is the Winner!

name: Fighter Pilot
description:
Fighter Pilot is a World War II aerial combat game utilizing metal fighter plane miniatures. The rules feature historically-accurate aircraft capabilities and fighter pilot ratings.

Consists of a 32-page softcover digest.
categories: Aviation / Flight, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Simulation, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Tschikago
description:
This is a dice game in Barti's range of match-box sized games (Art. 3606).

The game comes with 3 wooden dice and 6 red wooden pawns that are called 'bottles'. The first player rolls the 3 dice and has up to 3 rolls to get a score that he/she is satisfied with. Ones count as 100 points, sixes as 60 points and other numbers of pips are face value. A player can stop before using all 3 rolls. Subsequent players now have the same number of rolls to roll a higher score. If a player fails to roll higher than the previous high score, the player has to take a bottle and a new round begins. When all the bottles are taken, the rules change - a player now puts back a bottle in the middle if someone is unable to beat their score. The loser is the last player left to hold any bottles.

name: Finish Lines 2
description: A set of 500 new cards for Finish Lines. It uses the same categories in the base game and is not a stand alone edition.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Party Game, Trivia

name: Muskets and Sandpiles
description:
"Rules for American Revolution and the Alamo. These is a very simple wargame for play on beach or in backyard, with plastic toy soldiers. The focus is on a fast-action game, easy to learn and easy to play. Our game is for small battles, only - with armies of 100 men or less on each side."

"We have taken into account such things as flintlock pistols and the differences between muskets and rifles. (In this era, rifles could not be fitted with a bayonet! Only muskets had the bayonet attachment!)"

The players must supply the appropriate toy soldiers. The rules divide the figures into five types: Infantry (foot soldiers), Cavalry (mounted soldiers), Artillery (gun crewmen and cannons), Rangers (infantry with rifles), and Indians (who fight as infantry or cavalry).

Each type of figure is rated or movement, as are wagons and caissons. Six types of ranged weapons commonly found with Revolutionary War miniatures are rated for range, damage, and rate of fire. Other concepts covered in the rules include terrain effects, hand-to-hand combat, walls/bunkers, forts, and soldiers fighting as units.
categories: American Revolutionary War, American West, Fighting, Miniatures, Wargame

name: Picco Klecksolino
description:
Oh dear, Mr. Klecks the artist has stumbled and all of his colors have fallen onto the floor. Who can help him sort the colors correctly onto his palette? The person to find all the colors and then shout out “Klecksolino!” is the winner.

Oh dear, Mr. Klecks the artist has stumbled and all of his paints have fallen onto the floor. Who can help him sort the colored paints correctly onto the palettes? It’s not really all that difficult: first the lighter colors, yellow and orange, then red and of course, blue and green – look carefully at your palette. Now you’ve just got to find the right colors, which are lying around all mixed up, and you are only allowed to turn over one colored tile at a time. Can you remember which tile lies where? Watch very carefully which colors the other players have turned over and then you should be alright. Have you found all of the colors and sorted them correctly onto the palette? Quickly shout out “Klecksolino” and then you’ve won.
publishers: Selecta Spel en Hobby, Selecta Spielzeug

name: Todos contra el fuego
description:
This game simulates how could be a forest fire, and the objective for the player (can be played by more than 1 player but all play together) is to control it using strategy. Depending on how you placed all the pieces before the fire started you will do a better job.
The game ends when the fire is over or when the players are thrown away from the board by the fire. The fire is not controlled by any player, it grows and moves automatically depending on the wind and other factors.
This game was created to teach students in schools how is a forest fire, and how people work to prevent and control fires.
mechanics: Area Movement, Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Simulation

name: Super Vache R√®gles optionnelles, raret√©s et autres vacheries
description:
This second expansion comes in a book. You can now have cyber cows, cows coming from everywhere in the world. You can buy lasers, armors, etc.

There is also an RPG: Middle-Farm Role Playing Game, and a solo adventure...
categories: Animals, Card Game, Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Farming
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Open Drafting, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Against the Scourge of God
description:
“The Huns were fearsome nomadic horsemen from the steppes of Central Europe. The Hunnic tribes routinely raided and pillaged their neighbors, and each other. The famed Attila was able to unite many of the tribes under his leadership. His devastating attacks on the Christian peoples of Europe earned Attila the nickname 'The Scourge of God.'"

"In 451 AD Attila led a large army west across the Rhine River. After rampaging through Gaul for a time the Huns were confronted by an army commanded by the Roman general Aetius and the Visigoth General Theodoric. At the battle of Chalons the Hunnic invasion was turned back. This decisive victory saved Western Europe from the Huns.”

A miniatures wargame intended for classroom use with two teams of students (grades 6-8). The game is designed to be played on a 7.5x5 foot table using 1/72 scale plastic miniatures mounted two per base. Free print-and-play paper miniatures are also available for use with the rules. Units portrayed in the game include Commanders, Cavalry (heavy and light), Infantry, and Archers.

name: Battle of Hastings (1066 AD)
description:
“When Edward the Confessor, King of England, died without an heir three men claimed the throne. Harold Godwinson had the advantage of actually being in England, and he was crowned king. The other claimants, William Duke of Normandy and Harald Hardrada (King of Norway), were prepared to fight for the throne."

"Hardrada struck first, invading Northern England with a large Viking army . . . The Vikings were routed, and Hardrada was killed. Harold didn't get much time to celebrate, however, as he was soon informed that William had landed in Southern England with an army of Norman knights and mercenaries.”

“Again Harold raced to meet the threat. He decided to confront the Normans as soon as possible. Harold's Saxons formed their shield wall on top of Senlac Hill. With their flanks protected by rough terrain, they knew the Normans would be forced to attempt a frontal assault. All day long the Normans tried and failed to break through the Saxon lines. Then Harold's men made a fatal error and chased the Normans back down the hill, opening gaps in their shield wall. The Normans were quick to exploit the mistake, and they were able to break through and win. Harold was killed on the field of battle, and William became King of England.”
A miniatures wargame intended for classroom use with two teams of students (grades 6-8). The game is designed to be played using 1/72 scale plastic miniatures mounted two per base. Free print-and-play paper miniatures are also provided for use with the rules.

The Saxon force is divided into five commands composed of Fyrd militia and Housecarls. The Norman force is also divided into five commands, each of which is composed of cavalry, infantry, and archers.

name: Battle of Liegnitz (1241 AD)
description:
“In 1241 the mighty Mongol army launched an invasion into Europe. While the main force headed for a showdown in Hungary a smaller army was sent into Poland as a diversion. A large Polish and Germany army, led by Henry the Pious of Silesia, marched off to link up with King Wenceslas of Bohemia's army. The Mongols confronted them as they passed the town of Liegnitz. Although outnumbered, the Mongols fought brilliantly and inflicted a devastating defeat on their opponents.”

A miniatures wargame intended for classroom use with two teams of students (grades 6-8). The game is designed to be played using 1/72 scale plastic miniatures mounted two per stand. Free print-and-play paper miniatures are also provided for use with the rules. Units portrayed in the game include commanders, mounted knights, crossbowmen, light cavalry, archers, and Teutonic infantry.

The game requires a table of approximately 7.5x5 feet. The only terrain features portrayed in the game are several hills which separate the opposing forces.

name: Anaconda (1864)
description:
“United States, 1864. The civil war that both sides had expected to end swiftly has dragged into its third year. The Union blockade of the South, the Anaconda Plan developed by General Winfield Scott and established in 1861, has finally started to take its toll on the Confederate military and its civilian population. Southern logisticians estimate that with current supplies, the South will be forced to surrender due to inability to maintain its military and severe economic hardships in five months.”
“Objective: Be the first side to drive their opponent to the breaking point through a careful combination of naval strategy and army operations - force the surrender of the Confederacy by exhausting their war stocks (zero weeks remaining), or inflict an unacceptable additional 100,000 casualties on the Union (700,000 total), forcing the North to sue for peace.”

“Players of the same side sit side by side on one side of a table (or the floor), facing their opponents. Each player along the line plays a regional military commander with one army regiment and one navy squadron assigned to his control. Players can assume the identities of historic Union and Confederate generals and admirals, or simply be referred to as Commander 1, Commander 2, etc. down the lines."

"This opposing line of players stretches from Virginia down the southern Atlantic and Gulf Coast to Texas and then up the Mississippi River Valley. Any map of the eastern United States can be used, or an outline of the coast created with masking tape, but is not required for play. Each commander has six cards; two navy, two army and two special cards.”

“In multi-player games, players can only communicate by passing messages verbally to other commanders seated immediately beside them . . . Washington and Richmond can attempt to pass a grand strategy to the rest of the team at the beginning of a turn, but the word must be passed ‘down the line.’”

name: Battle of Ia Drang (1965 AD)
description:
“The battle for Landing Zone X-Ray in the Ia Drang valley was called ‘the battle that changed the war in Vietnam.’"

"In 1965 the 1st battalion of the 7th cavalry was dropped by helicopter into the Ia Drang valley where three regiments of the North Vietnamese Army (NVA) and a battalion of Vietcong surrounded them. In the first major engagement between American and NVA soldiers the badly outnumbered Americans successfully defended the landing zone, suffering heavy casualties in the fighting. This scenario focuses on the Vietnamese attack on the morning of the second day of the battle.”

A miniatures wargame intended for classroom use with two teams of students (grades 6-8). The game is designed to be played on a 7.5x5 foot table using individually based 1/72 scale plastic miniatures. Free print-and-play paper miniatures are also provided for use with the rules.

Each figure represents a commander or approximately 5-10 men. The American forces consist of 174 figures and the NVA forces consist of 316 figures. The game includes rules for artillery and air support.

name: Last Stand: The First Battle of Thermopylae (480 BC)
description:
“In the Battle of Thermopylae of 480 BC, an alliance of Greek city-states fought the invading Persian Empire at the pass of Thermopylae in central Greece. Vastly outnumbered, the Greeks held back the Persians for three days in one of history's most famous last stands."

"The performance of the defenders at the battle of Thermopylae is often used as an example of the advantages of training, equipment, and good use of terrain to maximize an army's potential, and has become a symbol of courage against overwhelming odds. Even more, both ancient and modern writers used the Battle of Thermopylae as an example of the superior power of a well trained army defending native soil.”

A “fast and easy” set of wargame rules for use with miniatures. The game is designed to be played on a 7.5x5 foot table using 1/72 scale plastic miniatures mounted two per base. Free print-and-play paper miniatures are also provided for use with the rules.

Every four turns represents a day of fighting, after which surviving units reform in their deployment area for the next day of battle. At the start of the third day, an encircling force of Immortals and skirmishers sets up at the rear of the Greek forces.

Units portrayed in the game include King Leonidas, Javelin Skirmishers, Archer Skirmishers, Commanders, Spartans, Greek Hoplites, and Persian Immortals.

name: Frederick and the Final Prussian Assault
description:
“The Seven Years War (1756 - 1763) was a military struggle between Britain and Prussia on one side, and France, Russia, Austria, and Sweden on the other."

"The leading military figure in the conflict was King Frederick II of Prussia, later known as Frederick the Great. One of his innovations was the oblique attack order. This maneuver was designed to bring the bulk of his army against one of the enemy's flanks, defeating it decisively before the entire enemy army could become engaged. At the battle of Leuthen (1757) he used the strategy effectively to defeat a larger Austrian army.”

A miniatures wargame intended for classroom use with two teams of students (grades 6-8). The game is designed to be played on a 7.5x5 foot table using 1/72 scale miniature figures. Free print-and-play paper miniatures are also provided for use with the rules.

The opposing forces are composed of Cuirassier, Hussars, Musketeers, Grenadiers, Dragoons, Cannons, and Commanders. Only one terrain feature is marked on the game table - the village of Leuthen.
categories: Age of Reason, Educational, Miniatures, Wargame

name: A Ruinous Victory
description:
“The British, under the command of General Cornwallis, were successful in their battles in the southern colonies. Their adversary, General Greene, could not defeat the British but he was determined to deny the British a decisive victory so that his army could remain a potential threat."

"The largest engagement took place near Guilford Courthouse in North Carolina. Greene deployed his men in three lines, with the militia in the first two lines. The British drove the Americans from the field but suffered heavy casualties, and Greene was able to withdraw his surviving army before it could be destroyed. The British said of the battle that ‘another such victory would ruin the British Army.’”

A miniatures wargame intended for classroom use with two teams of students (grades 6-8). The game is designed to be played on a 7.5x5 foot table using 1/72 scale plastic miniatures. Free print-and-play paper miniatures are also provided for use with the rules. Also required for play are materials to represent the several patches of forest scattered around the battlefield.
categories: Age of Reason, American Revolutionary War, Educational, Miniatures, Wargame

name: Campaigning with the Duke
description:
“The War of the Spanish Succession (1701-1714) began when the King of Spain died without an heir. King Louis XIV of France and Emperor Leopold I of Austrian both claimed the throne, and Spain's territory. England and the Netherlands sided with Austria, while Bavaria joined the French . . . At the start of the war the French army had a reputation as the best in Europe. At the battle of Blenheim (1704), also spelled ‘Blindheim,’ the Duke of Marlborough soundly defeated the French, puncturing the myth of French invincibility.”

A miniatures wargame intended for classroom use with two teams of students (grades 6-8). The game is designed to be played on a 7.5x5 foot table using 1/72 scale plastic miniatures. Free print-and-play paper miniatures are also provided for use with the rules.

The order of battle for each army (Confederate and Franco-Bavarian) is broken down according to the position of the units on the battlefield: the left wing, right wing, or center. Each wing has one or more commanders, and each army has an overall commander. A few terrain features must be marked on the game table – namely two fortified towns and a stream which bisects the battlefield between the two armies.

name: Pillz
description:
From the publisher's website:

Build the special pill!

With each card you place, you try to complete as many pills as possible. Each pill must have to colors in order to score points. You can place one or two cards in each turn, but only one card will score you points. And of course each pill has to fit the others, so no dead ends are allowed.

For 2 Grown-ups, 15 to 30 minutes playing time.

name: Troldespillet
description:
The objective of the game is to make your little troll find your lucky balls and hang them in the tree.

During the game you can make the other players lucky balls fall off the tree with help from the bat in which case they have to get help from the fish to get the lucky balls back.

The winner is the player with the troll that gets to hang all - or all but one - of his lucky balls on the tree an then return home first.

name: The Moor was Covered in Blood
description:
A miniatures wargame intended for classroom use with two teams of students (grades 6-8). The game is designed to be played on a 7.5x5 foot table using miniature figures mounted two per base. Free print-and-play paper miniatures are also provided for use with the rules.

“The decisive battle of the 1745 Jacobite Rising took place at Culloden in April, 1746. The English army had been strengthened by reinforcements from the continent, and well trained by the Duke of Cumberland. They were well prepared to fight the Jacobite forces of Prince Charles. The Jacobites were outnumbered, low on supplies, and poorly led in the battle. They were subjected to a deadly artillery barrage, and outflanked by the English. The battle was a disaster for the Jacobites, and ended the rising.”
categories: Age of Reason, Educational, Miniatures, Wargame

name: Butterflies are Free
description: From the box: Play Butterflies Are Free and you won't be catching butterflies ... you'll be setting them free! Move around the cool game board and see who'll be the first player to let these brilliant butterflies go. but the game's no walk in th park! Land on "Take 2 butterflies" and you have to add more to your collection.

name: PQ-17
description:
This wargame portrays the actions surrounding and involving the series of PQ (Scotland to Murmansk) convoys in the Second World War. The map covers the area of the Arctic Sea where the action took place.

"PQ-17" appeared in JagdPanther magazine #8, January 1975 (along with the game Barad-Dur, 3430), later rereleased in PDF format by Amarillo Design Bureau. It has amateur DTP production values. Many different types of ships are represented including Battleships, Cruisers, Destroyers, Merchants, Anti-Submarine Trawlers, Tankers, Escort Carriers, and of couse Submarines and U-Boats.

Employs a written movement orders system. There is a tactical board for combat. Rules for weather, fuel, British Home Fleet, convoy scattering, ice pack, airpower, ASW screens, torpedoes, and crew rescue are included. All this in just 4 pages of rules, plus 1 page of charts.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Minimap Resolution, Simulation, Simultaneous Action Selection
publishers: Amarillo Design Bureau, Inc., JagdPanther Publications

name: Big Bucks: The World of Business
description:
Equipment:
board
2 dice
6 players' tokens
40 markers
3 gold ingots
15 fortune cards
Title deeds: 3 banks, 4 large corporations, 5 manufacturers, 6 retailers, 7 properties
6 insurance policies
5 paintings
20 stock certificates
Big Bucks Bank paper money

The bottom line: Make your money grow with conservative, moderate risk, and speculative investments. The winner? The player who succeeds in buying out all the other players.

Short Version: Players must settle their debts immediately. Loans from the Big Bucks Bank or between players not permitted.
Long Version: Players may borrow money from the Big Bucks Bank or from other players.

Seems to be a Canadian-centric game; all title deeds are for Canadian cities.
mechanics: Commodity Speculation, Investment, Roll / Spin and Move, Stock Holding
publishers: Gestion Group-Or, Productions FRIK International, Inc

name: Hucke-Peter
description:
An old roll-and-move game from the 1930's, re-published recently in the nostalgic games series of Kosmos.

Each player has a figurine that starts with 6 wooden disks in a large pannier on its back. Goal of the game is to get rid of them. First player who manages this wins the game.

The player in turn rolls a die, and moves his figurine forward by the exact amount. Depending on the space he lands on, he might have to do one of the following actions: Give on of his disks to another player, remove it from the game, place it on the board, or take a disk from the board an add it to his load.

Included are two variants: In one, you start without disks and try to collect a given number; in the other, you have the choice whether to move you figurine forwards or backwards after seeing your roll.

name: H√§nde weg von Mississippi
description:
Mississippi is the name of the horse little Anna got from her grandmother. But now some guy called Alligator wants it, and even uses blackmail. The players try to help Anna to keep the animals safe.

7 pairs of animal counters are placed on the table; the large ones open, the small ones hidden. One of the small counters is placed below the alligator card. On command, all players simultaneously peek underneath the remaining counters. When a player thinks he knows which animal the alligator is after, he grabs the corresponding large counter. If he is correct, he gets to keep the pair (1 point for each tile); otherwise he has to give back a piece he collected earlier. In addition, there are a few minor special rules regarding the horse Mississippi.After each round, a new animal pair is added to keep the total at 7. The game ends after 19 rounds, when there are now animals left to refill.

name: Under the Black Flag: an Ambush Alley Mini-Campaign
description:
“Under the Black Flag” contains a three scenario campaign focused on a covert and highly critical action against Somalian pirates. As an added bonus, it contains alternative rules for clearing buildings as well as rules for close assault weapons (SMGs, shotguns, etc.) and handguns.

“Under the Black Flag” is only available by subscription to the "Special Operators Group".
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Modern Warfare, Wargame

name: Fieber
description: A game of Horse Racing featuring the placing of bets and the auctioning of horses prior to the race. Movement is achieved through a card mechanism. Comes with 7 plastic horses and 7 plastic jockeys.

name: Hawaiian Glyphs
description:
From the Rules:

A uniquely interactive experience with Hawaii's ancient past.

The game's objective is to randomly draw Glyph stones from Glyph bags; place them on an identical image on the board; and create a continuous and uninterrupted line of Glyph stones. The winner of the game must, then, create a story based on the petroglyph images in their winning line.

Each player has a collection of 26 glyph stones. There are 12 different petroglyph images and the player will have 2 of each image and 2 blank (wildcard) stones.

name: Scene It? To Go!: Music
description:
From the publisher:

We've packed all the fun of the original game into a compact case! Real songs, video clips, trivia questions and on-screen challenges, featuring artists like Madonna, Johnny Cash and Avril Lavigne, will take players on a journey through four decades of music and pop-culture. Scene It? Music Edition To Go can be played anytime, anywhere.

- Works with portable DVD players and laptops
- Durable travel case
- Magnetic game tokens
- On-screen trivia cards and animated dice
- Great for vacations, airline flights and road trips
categories: Electronic, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Music, Party Game, Travel, Trivia

name: 1865: Midwest
description:
1865: Midwest is a railroad building, and stock trading game set in the United States Midwest, which is based on the 18xx game system. In this, as in other 18xx games, players assume the role of investors in railroad companies. Play alternates between share dealing rounds, in which players buy and sell stock in railroads, and operating rounds, in which players build track, run trains and ferries, and manage the assets of the companies in which they own controlling interest.
1865: Midwest uses 8 major railroads, 4 minor railroads, and 8 private companies to simulate the rich railroad history of the region. As the game progresses, the 4 minor railroads will pair off, each pair forming a larger railroad, or system. Later, two of the major railroads are destined to merge into a third system.
The game is designed, from the ground up, to give each player an equal opportunity to succeed in amassing great wealth during the game. In 1865: Midwest there is more than one path to victory, so don't be afraid of losing the game in the first few rounds. You have more control than ever before of the operations of your railroads, but be mindful: so do your opponents!
1865: Midwest should be a challenging, and engaging gaming experience for the seasoned 18xx gamer.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Network and Route Building, Stock Holding, Tile Placement

name: Wise Alec
description:
Wise Alec is the family fun trivia game that plays to any crowd. Featuring a hilarious demonstration of trivia, tongue twisters, and sassy social strategy, Wise Alec picks up on players’ clever choices, good manners, and a little luck to find the wisest owl on any family game night.

Playing Wise Alec, opponents have a chance for making wise choices before, during, and after the game. On each turn, players try to earn points as they move around the board answering questions in three different categories from elementary school curriculum. Each question offers a choice of an easy or more difficult question. Players can use their strengths for maximum or minimum risk and reward, but when a player lands on a Wise Alec card the fun really begins.

The unique elements of Wise Alec offer a choice of two levels of difficulty on every turn and playing to win by points or time, make the game ideal for multi-generation game play.

Wise Alec was designed by educators to promote a healthy and active lifestyle, good manners, reinforce learning while ensuring each player’s ego remains intact as no one gets eliminated and no one feels like a fool.

Wise Alec was awarded Dr. Toy’s 100 Best Children’s Products.
categories: Educational, Humor, Memory, Party Game, Trivia
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Memory, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Gioco del ponte
description:
{from the back of the box}
The Battle for the Bridge
In a medieval city, two opposing sides of the town, each composed of six teams, fight on the Center Bridge to force the enemy back across and into its encampment.
Astuteness, strategy and a little bit of luck are used by the Generals and their Captains to win the final victory.
The game has two phases. First there is a fast parade around the city walls when each team's force is secretely determined by the cards. Second, the actual battle for the possession of the Center Bridge where the expert usage of Strategy Cards by the Generals and their Captains can increase the strength of a team.
The game is rapid, exciting and never repeticious. No two games are ever the same cause the Strategy cards (Warriors, Flags and Pageant Figures etc.) can continually reverse the momentum of the Battle.
All Players are involved from the beginning to the last second of the game.
This game can be played by 2 players, by an entire family (4-6 players) or by a group of friends (8-14 players). The more expert players will enjoy studying the battle statistics and organizing tournaments.
The duration of this game is about 45 minutes.

This box contains:
- 1 large Playing Board representing a naïf plan of a Medieval City of Pisa, subdivided into two opposing sides along the Arno River: Tramontana (north) and Mezzogiorno (south).
- 200 illustrated Strategy Cards: Warriors, Flags, Pangeant Figures, Captains, etc.
- 2 Dice.
- 2 Parade Tokens.
- 12 "Chariots", one for each team to be used for the Bridge combat.
- Stickers with the emblems of the 12 teams.
- 4 Large Card Holders.
- Game Booklet with explanation of the rules and examples of strategic moves.
categories: Card Game, Dice, Fighting, Medieval, Party Game, Racing
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Roll / Spin and Move, Simulation, Simultaneous Action Selection, Team-Based Game

name: Allah Akbar: The First Crusader's 1096AD. - 1099 AD.
description:
Allah Akbar presents a set of rules for handling a miniatures campaign covering the First Crusade. As the introduction puts it:
"Now you command those armies once again in this exciting stratigic (sic) game of the First Crusade. If you have never played a strategic game before, it is the same as a board wargame except that all battles are fought out in miniatures and there are more than two players in the game."
"Allah Akbar has been designed so that you the player may use any sort of miniatures you desire. Just make sure that all players agree to the same set of rules before the game begins."
The rules themselves present maps of the area, a system for strategic movement of land and naval forces, campaign record keeping, army lists, city management and rebellions. The rules are 25 pages, single-sided in a staple-bound booklet.
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Simulation, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Grand Prix Cribbage
description: In Grand Prix Cribbage, players race each other around a twisting, turning, two-lane track using traditional Cribbage scoring methods. Through strategic card play and and tactical pegging, each player attempts to avoid Collisions, Oil Spills and Spin Outs while trying to force his opponent into them. By crossing over the inside lane before each turn in the track, a player can shorten the overall distance from 121 holes -- as in traditional Cribbage -- to 107 holes. By taking advantage of the powerful "Slipstream", a trailing player can change the face of a game in a single hand.

name: Haunted Destinies
description:
Haunted Destinies is an identity mystery game set on the Scottish moors. At the start of the game, one player is secretly assigned the role of Opener, but no one - not event the player who is the Opener - knows who the Opener is. The Opener card, and other attribute cards, are distributed to the players in destiny piles.

As the game progresses, your destiny, and the destiny of the other players, will gradually be revealed. The Opener is destined to break the walls that keep past, present future, the dead, and the living separate. If you discover that you are The Opener, your goal is to complete the opening ritual by killing all of the other players. If you are not The Opener, your goal is to bind him or her and stop the opening ritual.

If you die and the game is not over, you become a ghost. Ghosts can only win if a Haunting card that gives them a win condition is in play. What are Haunting cards and how do they work? You add Haunting cards to your destiny pile when you are haunted by ghosts or if you fail a destiny search. A Haunting card comes into play when another player probes your destiny pile and finds a Haunting card.

Haunted Destinies uses a tiled board system similar to Betrayal at the House on the Hill, but each tile edge indicates the minimum number of movement points need to leave through that edge. Some tiles have an "X", indicating that you can not leave that way. This tile setup creates interesting, semi-solid maze-like boards that are different each game.

Haunted Destinies is a game for three to six players. It uses a custom set of board tiles, three custom card decks, a black six sided die, and a white six sided die. You can download the custom parts and the rules at http://www.invisible-city.com/play/499/haunted-destinies. A four-player game takes about 60 minutes to play. Since it deals with ritual sacrifice and murder, Haunted Destinies is appropriate for ages 16 and up.
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Deduction, Dice, Exploration, Fighting, Horror, Maze, Memory, Murder/Mystery, Print & Play
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Memory, Modular Board, Variable Player Powers

name: Babbela
description:
Players taking turns putting stones on the lines of the game board. Once every stone is placed, they move their stones to the intersections. If a stone doesnt have any intersection to move through, he van be put on the area between the lines.
Once all moves are done you get negative points for stones remaining on the lines. Fewer begative points wins.

name: Quintorium
description: Players use their color of cards to make five in a row. Each player starts out with either the red or black half of the deck and attempt to make five in a row either vertically, horizontally or diagonally with their color. A card may be played on top of an opposing card with the same rank.

name: Capitalist Canasta
description:
Capitalist Canasta is played with two standard decks of cards and a supply of money. Players attempt to make small melds and cash them in to get enough money to make larger melds which are worth more money.

On a turn a player draws a card and then may make melds, but they have to be paid for: 5-10 cost face value but J-A cost significantly more. Deuces are wild. Cards may be added to existing melds by paying for them.

Melds may be sold to the bank. Melds may also be raided with 3s and raids may defended against with 4s.

name: Fund Manager
description:
Released in Essen 2008, Fund Manager is a game about the stock market. Player with the most asset, cash and portfolio, in the end wins. The game comes with two decks of cards, one sheet for stock prices, paper money and a board.

Fund Manager can be played with either three or four players. Depending on the number of players each have either three or four action chits numbered from one to three. Players use this chits to move one single pawn around the game board. When the pawn lands in a space that action is then executed. These actions spaces include buying/ selling stocks, drawing random events from the deck of cards, rolling dice to see which companies rise or fall and collecting cash at the completion of one round. When round is completed the chits are turned over and are ready to be used again. Game is played for eight round and takes about one hour to complete.

name: Ranabag
description:
Players advance their frog by taking frogs from the bag and placing them on the board. But some frogs don't like others - so frogs also have to be at the right color. By placing frog of the wrong color You find Yourself right where You started. But You can always stop risking and say that You'll stay right where You got with the last frog.

At Essen '08 there also was this poster: "These frogs are not edible!"
mechanics: Area Movement, Hand Management, Pattern Recognition

name: Fourthought
description: From the box. A Family Get Together Game. A competitive fast moving game of skill & Strategy with a unique playing board. There are three ways to line up your marbles and hundreds of ways to play and win. Strategically designed blocking panels. Mislead your opponent ... attack and counter attack. Think one or two moves ahead and hope your opponent spoil your game plan.
publishers: Berwick's Toy Co. Ltd., ED-U-Cards Mfg

name: Jerusalem
description: Jerusalem is a German Game about a sight-seeing tour in modern Jerusalem. The Players have the tasks to make photos of places of interest. The plans for each tour are hidden from the other players. Special events are handled by event-cards. Additionally the players have to bargain for special souvenirs. The player who was able to make all photos and buy all souvenirs first wins.

name: GanXtaZ!
description:
Each player plays their favourite 'ganxta', tries to build their reputation, choose the correct tactics and to become the boss of the underworld at the end of the game.

The system is based on communication between the players. The game board does not say whai happens, but what could happen. Everything is decided by the result of a 'roshambo' with the other players. You can try to guess your opponent's intentions, bargain with them, trick them, even bribe them.

The game takes place in four quarters, from the ghettos to the luxury of the choicest casino.

Further details on www.rebelshop.cz

name: Hexe Lilli macht Zauberquatsch: Kartenspiel
description:
Hexe Lilli is a famous German children‘s book character.
In the game Hexe Lilli (witch Lilli) makes a big chaos when performing magic. The players have to keep in mind where the different sized bewitched things are.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Fantasy, Memory, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Evil Vendetta Pie Fight
description:
From the Blood-and-Cardstock website:

Evil Vendetta Pie Fight is a quick free for all game. In EVPF you're all evil magic-wielding nightmares from the human psyche and you hate each other's guts. Your union won't let you actually hurt each other, so the only way to settle this like, well not like men, is to have an…Evil Vendetta Pie Fight.

Players each take a unique monster character (Witch, Mummy, Werepoodle, Vampire, etc.) and commence to throw magic pies and spells at eat other. If one of their six body regions is struck by a pie then it is immobilized and can not be used. There are spells to deflect pies, clear pies off body parts, and bend the rules. Last thing standing wins.

In general, when a player begins to carry more pie than others, players will gang up on him/her to eliminate them from the game. In addition, as play progresses more and more of the defensive cards leave the game thus ensuring acceleration of pie hits and a certain and quick end to the game.

Evil Vendetta Pie Fight is currently available in a Flagpole edition. What does that mean? Glad you asked. It means the game is made out of cardstock that I have printed out on my little HP Officejet and chopped up on a paper cutter by my very own hand. It comes in a plain white cardboard box BUT every game is numbered and autographed. There will only be 100 copies of the Flagpole edition. If they sell well we hope to have a production version out soon.

The flagpole comes with:

64 pie cards and 32 spell cards for a total of 96 cards
36 cards to construct your being's bodies from.
1 normal six-sided die
42 bingo tokens which are used to target pies and spells

You can play it right out of the box. Come on, you KNOW you want to throw pies at your friends…

name: Kurt Halbritter's Halbwelt Spiel
description:
This game (the name means "demimonde") was designed by the German writer and cartoonist Kurt Halbritter and was published 3 years after his death by his widow. 120 image tiles, drawn in his typical style, and 10 text tiles can be used by the players to lay "tableaux" or play a dominoes variant if following one of the three variants that come with the game. The images and texts range from the funny through slightly erotic to absurd. However, the author himself makes it clear that this is not meant to be a game in the first place but rather a flight of fantasy for the players: "Whoever did not have to suppress his play instinct from earliest youth will know immediately what to do with the tiles, and will have a foreboding of the sinful diversity of variations." But, since "the Germans always want to win something" (Kurt Halbritter, but also Arno Schmidt), he provided some rules nevertheless: Demimonde Dominoes, Basic Demimonde and Demimonde Tableau. The aim is, in all variations, to get rid of one's tiles first (or not to be caught to be the last with tiles left). The tiles have a varying number of points on their backs which can be used for some kind of scoring system.
The game comes in a flat, long box with a cardboard sleeve.
More samples from the cover text: "...tile-laying fun from the erotic flora, ... designed and drawn in colour for pan flautists, Faun girls and creation engineers".

description:
A golf game based on the rules of the real thing. Instead of a club players use dice. There are 18 holes on the gameboard in all sorts of terrain and also a putting green and driving range. There are also golf cards,green cards and fairway cards where unexpected things can happen.
The game was equipped with a diskette that also allows play on the computer.

name: Lahemay waladat
description:
A manqala game.

From Wikimanqala:

http://www.wikimanqala.org/wiki/Lahemay_waladat

Lahemay waladat ("my cow has given birth") is a mancala game widely known in the Maqalé area of southern Tigé, Ethiopia. The game was was first described by Richard Pankhurst in 1971 as Game 17. Similar games exist in Western Eritrea and Somalia.

Rules:

Lahemay waladat is played on a board of two rows of of (sic) six holes. The game starts with four stones in each hole.

The right to start the game is decided by a hand-play referred to in Tigrinya as shekut. To begin with, the two players are holding hands as in a handshake. After breaking the hold, they would either expose the first finger, last three fingers or the open hand with fingers side by side. A player who displayed his first finger defeats one with three fingers, three fingers defeats the hand, and the hand the first finger.
On his turn a player distributes the contents of one of his holes anti-clockwise, one at a time, into the succeeding holes.
If the last stone is sown into an occupied hole, its contents are distributed in another lap.
The move ends when the last stone falls into an empty hole.
Groups of three stones made during a turn belong to the owner of the row, except a group of three that was effected by the last stone in hand which is won by the player whose hand it was. The latter kind of capture, however, does not terminate the move. The player would continue to move until his last stone in hand is placed in an empty hole (in other words, the player gets a bonus move).
The game ends when a player cannot move at his turn. The remaining stones are won by the player who could move last.
The player who wins more threes wins the round.
For the next round each player fills his holes with four stones from his winnings. If a player has one surplus stone, he cedes it to his opponent who can then together with his own surplus of three stones would open another hole. If each player has a surplus of two stones, their ownership is decided by shekut. Any holes that could not be filled are closed down with sand, but can be re-opened in a later round.
The aim of the game is to close down all the opponent's holes, that is to reduce his provision to less than four stones. "

Pankhurst, R. 1971. 'Gabata and Related Board Games of Ethiopia and the Horn of Africa', in Ethiopia Observer; 14 (3). Page 173.

name: DracoKrak Chess
description: DracoKrak Chess is a boardgame that is essentially Chess unleashed. The core system allows players to create various pieces, play on a bigger board, have multiple players and more. The fantasy element is strongly emphasized while keeping the abstract game play of Chess. So now, you can play Chess with interesting pieces such as The Cyclops, Ninja War Lord, Succubus, and the Fairy. Expansion for this game is unlimited and at an extremely low cost as players can do everything in a homemade fashion. Unlike normal Chess, the game play is not as competitive and has a much more laid back atmosphere.

name: New World Disorder: CyberZone
description:
Cyberzone is a cybernetic rules add-on for New World Disorder: urban skirmishes in a dark future, the easy-to-learn, miniatures-based tabletop game that takes place in a very near and very dystopian future.

Enter the CyberZone, a prison for the hordes of illegally-mechanized citizens that once plagued the outside world. These freaks are even more deadly than the crews that battle it out for control in Angel City. The residents of the CyberZone take advantage of the power that their cybernetics provide—from stronger limbs and better vision to mounted weapons and sub-dermal armor. Embrace the metal!

Available in PDF format and as a Printed Set with full-color paper miniatures.

Expands:

New World Disorder: urban skirmishes in a dark future
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fighting, Miniatures, Science Fiction

name: Zombies Want Fluffy
description:
Zombies Want Fluffy™ is an exciting two-player head-to-head board game where shambling undead horrors meet Fluffy, the adorable family dog. Each game takes 20 to 60 minutes to play, and features a tense, surprise-filled chase mechanic.

The story thus far... Fluffy has had a lot to drink and is looking to “visit” a tree on his way home late one night. And he’s found his mark -- a beautiful, secluded tree right there in the back corner of the cemetery. Unbeknownst to poor Fluffy, the cemetery is filled with man-eating, er..., dog-eating zombies who just woke up for a midnight snack. Fluffy is gonna be that snack if the shambling menaces having anything to say about it. Can you help Fluffy race to freedom (and relief!) before his bladder explodes or he becomes zombie chow?

A serious game is at the heart of this absurd premise.
categories: Horror, Miniatures, Print & Play, Racing, Zombies
mechanics: Hand Management, Open Drafting, Point to Point Movement

name: The Oblivion Pack
description:
This 12-scenario pack was released by Fanatic Enterprises to utilize the new armies made available by the ASL module Armies of Oblivion. The scenarios all include armor and the armies of Bulgaria, Croatia, Romania, Hungary or Slovakia.

FE 116 Bad Neighbor Policy: A small scenario set on boards 3 and 49. The scenario features a March 1939 border action featuring a small Slovakian combined arms force attacking a small Hungarian force. This is nice tourney sized scenario.

FE 117 Sanok Action: This scenario is set on boards 48 and 2. This is a medium sized scenario set in the opening days of Barbarossa. The scenario features a dug in Russian force holding off a German-Slovakian force that needs to capture some pillboxes.

FE 118 Zaporhze Island: This is another tourney scenario set on boards 47 and 8. Some dug in Russian defenders defend a stream crossing and try to hold some buildings against a infantry armor Hungarian force.

FE 119 The Face of War: During the Crimea Campaign, this scenario features the Rumanians attacking some dug in Russians supported by late arriving armor. This scenario is set on boards 19 and 16. This is your typical attack counterattack situation.

FE 120 Nasty Business: Much of the time Axis Minor troops were performing security services. This scenario set on boards 19 and 49 features a small partisan screening force attempting to delay rear echelon Slovakian troops from attacking the buildings on board 49 from a force of partisans set up on 49. This is a medium sized scenario.

FE 121 Allies in a Few Days: This one is set on boards 40 and 42. This is a meaty scenario featuring a river crossing with a twist. A dug in Russian force tries to keep a Rumanian force from crossing the river but the twist is that the Rumanians have troops popping out of the ether behind their lines. This action represents a situation where the Russians had broken through the Rumanian lines and reached a river. The Rumanian 1st Armored Division was tasked with counterattacking but the Russians were still dealing with bypassed units.

FE 122 Slovakian Slugfest: This one is set on boards 40 and 50. The Germans are attempting to squash the Slovakian Uprising. The Germans are attacking down these boards against Slovakian armor and infantry supported by partisans. Some unique set up conditions give this good replay value.

FE 123 Enemies All Around: The Bulgarians show up in this scenario. A small rear echelon German unit is surrounded. The Bulgarians have to destroy their vehicles. This scenario is set on boards 24 and 50.

FE 124 Paulis Detachment: This is a very meaty scenario featuring the Hungarians fighting the Rumanians on boards 49 and 22. A dug in Rumanian force tries to hold off an strong Hungarian attack.

FE 125 Lessons Learned the Hard Way: Here is a quick playing tourney scenario set on board 48. A small German force sets up HIP and tries to ambush a Bulgarian Reconnaissance unit. This should be a good one for lots of play with a great deal of replay potential.

FE 126 Path to Retribution: The Yugoslavian armored brigade shows up in this one as they try to catch and destroy a German/Croatian combined arms force. This meaty scenario is set on boards 41 and 49.

FE 127 Junkyard Wars: This scenario features the Bulgarian Armored Regiment attacking a force of Germans. Both sides get substantial armor and this is a meaty scenario. This scenario is set on boards 16 and 48
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fighting, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Modular Board, Secret Unit Deployment, Simulation

name: Treasure Chase
description:
The game's designer emailed me a description of the game as follows:

"It’s a game of pirates, adventure, skill and skulduggery. In essence it’s a race to find the X square and discover the location of the hidden treasure. Along the way you have to collect eight various items to aid you in your expedition, but also look out for all the things which can trip you up and tunnels that can aid you in your search.

Treasure chase is a whole lot of fun with just a little element of strategy thrown in and is designed for the whole family to play almost anywhere – as there is no board. You just need a flat surface and up to 4 willing pirates!

Next year we intend to release the garden size version - perfect for the out door and the beach." This was emailed today 19 Nov 08 and so "next year" would mean 2009.

name: What belongs where?
description:
A game derived from Picture Bingo featuring Playmobil toys. It takes the boards from Bingo, but the pieces are in puzzle-shapes. This adds the ability to try and recognize the overturned pieces from their shapes.

The rules include a variety of other games using the pieces included. This includes guessing and memory games.

name: 1808: Guerra de la Independencia
description:
Components:
• One 18 x 24 map
• 192 Counter
• One Rulebook
• Two Scenarios

Time Scale: 10 days
Map Scale: 35 km.
Unit Scale: Division / Brigade

The Peninsular War is set in Spain and Portugal during the Napoleonic wars. Year: 1808.

The hex map represents a map of Spain and Portugal with most of the major towns and cities represented.

One player takes the role of the French whilst the other plays the allies (Britain, Spain and Portugal).

description: Part of the War for Southern Independence Series, Unconditional Surrender is a brigade level simulation of the battle fought at Fort Donelson, Tennessee on February 15, 1862, specifically the Confederate failed attack to break out and escape from the surrounded fort.

name: Selus
description:
A mancala game. From http://mancala.wikia.com/wiki/Selus:

"Selus is a generic name given to mancala games which are played on three-row boards. Apparently, the word derived from Geez selus which means "three". [NB: This makes sense since Ge'ez is an Afro-Asiatic language and this is then cognate with Hebrew shelosh.]
In 1972, Richard Pankhurst wrote an excellent 53-page article on Ethiopian mancala games, including games from Eritrea, Djibouti and Somalia. He gave the rules of 103 games, of which 12 were three-row games or "Selus".

In the 1970s, Selus was still played in the highlands of Eritrea and in certain regions of modern Ethiopia, notably northern Tigre, Dorzé and Kulu Konta.

This particular variant was reported from the city of Massawa, Eritrea. It was described as Game 13 by Pankhurst.

Rules:

The board has 3x6 holes. Initially there are three seeds in each hole. Each player owns the row closest to him and the three holes of the central row at his right hand.

Each move starts with a player emptying the contents of one of his holes that is not a wegue ("wound"). Then, the seeds are dropped one by one into the following holes.

If the last seed falls into an occupied hole other than a wegue, the player takes up its contents and distributes these seeds in a new lap. Let's suppose you start the move in your left corner: the seeds are first distributed in your own back row from left to right, then in your central holes from right to left, afterwards in your opponent's back row from right to left and finally in your opponent's central row from right to left (see the diagram).

It is not permitted to pass a move unless a player has no legal move left.

The move ends if the last seed is dropped into an empty hole. This is called kwah, an onomatopoetic word that imitates the sound of the stone alighting on the board.

Wegues are created when the last seed distributed falls into a hole of three, thus making four seeds. The creator is called the owner of the wound who marks it in a distinctive way. Creating a wegue ends the move. A wegue can be created on either side of the board.

If the last seed of a move is dropped into a wegue, the player captures this seed and, unless the wound was empty, one of the seeds it contained. Capturing is permitted from any wegue, irrespective of the owner. The player must move again (beginning with any hole of his side which is not a wegue) if he captured from a wegue he owns, but must stop moving, if he captured from a wegue owned by his opponent.

Exception:


The two left-hand holes in a player's back row are called ayemi ("eye"). A player is not permitted to capture from an eye on his side, only from the opponent's side. In that case, he must move again, even if he has captured from an opponent's wegue. If the last seed fell into a wegue in your own ayemi, the move ends.


The creation of a wound is only permitted after the original set-up has been destroyed, i.e. after the first move of a game. If, in the first move, the last seed makes four seeds, they are distributed in another lap.

The game ends when both players have no move left. Each player scores a point for each captured seed and a point for each seed in a wegue owned by him. The player with most points wins."

name: Deep into the Bekaa
description:
DEEP INTO THE BEKAA
Final Confrontation, 1000 hrs, June 11, 1982

DEEP INTO THE BEKAA is a simulation depicting the first T-72 and Merkava tank battles in the final stages and hours of the Peace for Galilee Israeli offensive in 1982. These tank battles were the largest of the war and occurred as both sides sought to position themselves before the ceasefire at noon. They began at 10 a.m. as the Israeli Merkava tanks moved deep into the Bekaa Valley from their 77th battalion and the 409th Anti-tank (TOWs on Jeeps) swept far to the north until both collided with the fresh Syrian T-72 tanks of the 82nd Brigade, 3rd Armor Division.
As soon as elements of the Merkava tank battalion arrived, Syrian T-72 tanks began to fire from a distance of 2500-3000 yds. The Israelis inched ever closer to the Syrian border and in desperation, Syrian Milan AT units and Gazelle TOW gunships began to appear. To the Israeli, the going was a cautious advance yet one that had to achieve the most territory before the agreed ceasefire at Noon. The battle is unique for it was the first time the new Russian T-72 tank faced off with the new Israeli Merkava, for both their debut in battle.

Units represent single AFVs, helicopters or infantry AT teams. Each hex measures 324 yards from side to side. Each turn represents 5 min. time.

The game comes with a 11x17" map, 280 counters, rules.

name: Indunas Colonels and Emirs
description:
Indunas Colonels and Emirs, created by Rudy Scott Nelson, is a 1:10 scale based miniatures game set in the British Colonial period of the late 19th century (1850 to 1900). Much of the information is centered around their African campaigns.

The movie Khartoum and the fights between the British and the Mahdi is a good exemplar of the time period for these rules.

It uses a unique set of leadership rules, which perhaps is overdone, but also provides some degree of humor to the game.

Apparently Mr. Nelson revised and re-released this game in 2000
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement

name: Formula D√©: ITALY SERIES ‚Äì Misano, Santa Monica
description:
This is a Formula Dé track available for free download online - created by Alessandro Crespi.
It is a course based on MWC Misano World Circuit, located near Misano.
You will race in Santa Monica circuit.

This is part of a track series called ITALY SERIES.

01. Formula D√©: ITALY SERIES ‚Äì Bologna Centro
02. Formula D√©: ITALY SERIES ‚Äì Roma Colosseo
03. Formula D√©: ITALY SERIES ‚Äì Roma Isola Tiberina
04. Formula D√©: ITALY SERIES ‚Äì Milano Castello Sforzesco
05. Formula D√©: ITALY SERIES ‚Äì Bologna Stadio Dall'Ara
06. Formula D√©: ITALY SERIES ‚Äì Palermo Marina
07. Formula D√©: ITALY SERIES ‚Äì Trieste Porto
08. Formula D√©: ITALY SERIES ‚Äì Agrigento Valle dei Templi
09. Formula D√©: ITALY SERIES ‚Äì Torino Centro
10. Formula D√©: ITALY SERIES ‚Äì Firenze Lungo Arno
11. Formula D√©: ITALY SERIES ‚Äì Commemorative Track
12. Formula D√©: ITALY SERIES ‚Äì Misano, Santa Monica

name: Dash-N-Dine
description:
"Shake, roll, but don't get rattled in this frantic fast food race game. Be fast or be last in the whackiest, zappiest American Diner on the block!

Sunny die up, over easy, hold the fries! Take the order, serve the food and collect a tip - but its your opponent that's in control of the time with the unique, shake, rattle and roll salt pot timer. They shake - you quake, as you race to be the first player to collect three tips and win the game."

One of the last game to be produced by Waddingtons before they were taken over by Hasbro. The game is for 2-4 players, Ages 6 and up.

Each player has a coloured playing piece representing a waiter or waitress. On their turn, each player is timed using a salt pot shaker (which is effectively a timer), which is frantically shaken to make the 'salt' within it drain faster. When all of the 'salt' within it reaches the bottom, the players turn is over.

During a players turn, the player may do as many of the following before their time runs out:

- roll a standard six sided die and move from the kitchen to the nearest table of their colour
- on arriving at a table, the player picks up a food order disc and tries to return to the kitchen
- upon reaching the kitchen (which contains a spinner), the player spins the spinner until it matches the food order they have picked up. The spinner can reveal either a blank or food. If food is displayed, the food order is ready
- return back from the kitchen to the table where the order was placed, and collect a money tip

The first player to collect three money tips wins.

The game board requires some assembly, and consists of the kitchen, the tables to be served, and narrow lanes which the players move along.

As with many of the later Waddingtons games, it was firmly aimed at the younger end of the market, and as a consequence has limited replay value. Still, it is fast and frantic - players are constantly rolling dice and moving pieces, whilst another player is shaking the timer to end that players turn, egged on by any other players. The narrow lanes in the board do introduce a limited amount of strategy - you can block opposing players off - and the salt pot timer is a work of genius.
mechanics: Pick-up and Deliver, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Barbarossa in the South
description:
This game covers the Southern half of the Barbarossa Campaign. The period starts June 1941 and ends February 1942.

100 counters unmounted (must be mounted on hard-paper. Be careful because double-sided)
1 game map (printed on the back of the magazine thus mounted)

This is a second part of a two parts game and published in (old) Game Journal issue #44.

name: Abdanco
description:
Players play a card face up, matching the color, number, or word on a card in the middle. Stop, Out, and Take One cards modify the play. When a player plays the last card from his hand, the others must count and score the remaining cards in their hand. Hands continue until 2,000 or more points are reached, and that person is the loser. The player with the lowest score wins.

108 cards. Ages 6 and up.

name: Cthulhu: Tora! Tora! Tora!
description:
Cthulhu: Tora! Tora! Tora! is a two player, print and play boardgame that sets Kamikaze fighter pilots against the Great Old One Cthulhu.

This game was designed as the final work for a Game Design course. It started as a modding of Sink the Bismark (http://www.boardgamegeek.com/game/38702), but acquired a new theme and new game mechanics based on "Purrinha".

It is freely distributed under a Creative Commons License.

Download link original version 2.0 - http://www.boardgamegeek.com/file/download/4pnl825wrh/Cthulh...

name: Marsh Master A Wetlands Game
description:
Equipment: 20 Pairs of Species Cards, 4 hazard cards, 4 hazard solution cards, 4 trash cards, 1 Arnold Pathetic playing piece, 1 die, gameboard.

Object: Match all pairs of cards and the species in the marsh master habitats before Arnold Pathetic completes his destructive journey around the wetlands.

A cooperative memory game that will help you learn about some of the amazing species of plants and animals that live in the wetlands.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Memory, Roll / Spin and Move, Team-Based Game

name: Infected!
description:
Infected!
A game for 2 to 6 players (4 to 6 recommended).
Ages 14 and up
A standard game should last 30-45 minutes.

Object
The object of Infected! is to make the other players sick. The winner is the player that makes another player's Wellness drop below zero.
Basic Concept
