"In practice, depending on umpire experience, we have found you need one umpire for every 3-4 players - there is quite a lot to do."

"This game can also be played quite successfully as a solo game. To be most successful played solo it needs plenty of time to work through all the actions."

This set of rules was originally released in 1983. A revised edition was released in 2001.

name: Crossing the Wire
description:
Subtitled "Brigade Level Combat - Western Front 1916".

"A command post game about commanding brigades and divisions in WW1 - particularly focused on 1916. The rules are intended to be run in real time, and by umpires - who then write messages to the HQ players in the form they would have been historically, and subject to the delays and inaccuracies that would have existed at the time."

"The players never see the rules at all, and must work from a map (ideally in a smelly cellar by the light of a flickering oil lantern while umpires chuck buckets of earth at then)."

"Players must not be allowed to use game counters, plastic overlays or any modern aids. If a telephone is available it must be unreliable."

"The basic player team is probably a Brigade HQ - but with a few more players it can be expanded to a division of 2-3 brigades."

"The rules are simplistic and built around a few, hopefully easy to remember, die rolls - because umpires will need to spend time writing as well as adjudicating. Verbal reports from junior officers are possible, but rarely happened - the HQ builds its picture of the battle from a collection of highly unreliable information sources."

name: En Avant!
description:
En Avant! Tactical Warfare in the Age of Napoleon.

From the rulebook introduction:

"This system is designed to play out a regimental level battle using 25mm figures in about half an hour or so."

"Ideally, the game is controlled by someone acting as Game Control (or Umpire) who does not give the rules to the players. This adds some uncertainty play and discouraged player from ‘rules optimising' rather than just getting on ad playing the game."

"In order make it as clear as possible what is going on, the status of the units is shown by labels next to the unit, and players issue orders by using order flashcards. The system does not use dice in combat resolution, which is an approach that is a unusual in most wargaming circles and will come as a bit of shock to conventional gamers."

"This does give a slight chess-like feel to the game, and it does mean that a game which follows the same course will always have the same result. Fortunately, no game survives first contact with the players, and the chances of two games being exactly alike is small."

"Although the rules were tested using 25mm figures, it doesn’t really matter what size models you use, and it might look more realistic to put, say, 15mm or 1/300 scale figures on the same sized base."

name: Heroic Samurai
description:
Heroic Samurai: One Brain Cell Rules for Clan Feuding in Classical Japan.

From the rulebook:

"These are rules for playing a wargame with toy soldiers. It is intended for several players - say 4 or more. Players control significant leaders - the key samurai of a clan, who in turn have contingents of fighters under them."

"These rules are intended to simulate some of the smallscale
conflicts that went on from time to time in Japan."

"There are many sets of rules that simulate the epic battles of the Sengoku era, and a number of games about individual skirmishing. These rules are intended for situation in between these two scales."

"There are many examples of fights breaking out between smaller families or clans - or even between factions within a clan. These fights might involve only a few hundred fighters - too small to be counted as a battle - too big to be a man-to-man skirmish. In this game, players are significant individuals - leaders with great martial skills - and they have a following composed of their friends, family, vassals and servants."

"This means that the composition of the force controlled by a player can be highly varied."

"The rules are written with 15mm scale figures in mind - but there is no reason why they can’t be adjusted for other figure scales - or even played with cardboard figures or counters depending on the sort of resources you have at your disposal."

name: Men At Arms
description:
From the rulebook: "These are rules for playing a wargame with toy soldiers. It is intended for several players - say 4 or more. Players control significant leaders - the key lords or knights, who in turn have contingents of fighters under them."

Medieval skirmish rules for fighting battles between small armed groups. Each figure represents a single leader, combatant, horse, cart, or siege engine. Combat is resolved through three rounds of rock-scissors-paper. The rules cover ranged combat, melee combat, morale, and personal combat between leaders.

name: Warfare in Western Europe, 1050-1300
description:
A set of rules for fighting large scale medieval battles. Each figure represents 50 men and each inch represents 25 yards.

Troops are divided into two types, mounted knights and infantry. Infantry can include bowmen and crossbowmen. The opposing armies are divided into divisions (consisting of 20 infantry figures or 10 cavalry figures) each of which has a division commander.

The command and control rules require written orders. Division commanders have a randomly determined character rating which reflects the reliability in which orders will be carried out by the commander's division. The rules also encompass morale and unit disruption.

name: Old Fritz
description:
Old Fritz: One Brain Cell Army Level Rules for the Seven Years War In Europe.

Excerpts from the rulebook:

"These rules were first devised some considerable time ago as an alternative to the mainstream of tabletop figure wargames, to find, through a different approach a radically faster method for calculating the results of inter-unit combats."

"So, perversely, I decided to design a game that allows a few players to fight battles, in a reasonable time and without the need for very large numbers of brain cells on the part of the players."

"The results of combat can be arrived at by reference to a single combat results table giving who won, how decisively they won, and the casualties inflicted, in one fell swoop."

"Each bound represents approximately 10 minutes on the battlefield . . . The ground scale is 1mm = 2 metres . . . Each figure represents between 50 and 60 men."

Units are controlled by written orders. The implementation of orders is delayed to reflect the time required to convey them to unit leaders. The rules encompass various aspects related to infantry, cavalry, and artillery units. Supply and logistics are represented in an abstract manner.

name: OP COM
description:
OP COM: Operational Map Combat in World War II.

A set of detailed rules for running an umpired, double-blind World War II wargame for two players or teams. Written orders are issued by the players and the results are resolved by the umpire. The players represent command staff at division level or higher. The units controlled by the players are at least battalion sized and each game turn is a half day. The map scale will vary by scenario.

From the rulebook:

"These rules started out as a set of guidelines for the operational megagame Operation Market Garden. This game was run twice, once in 1988 and again in 1993. In the course of these outings, the rules altered and benefited from considerable feedback from participants. The game system I offer here is a distillation of that feedback from users, together with additional thoughts and research."

"It is intended as a generic map gaming system for WW2 operations in the Western Europe Theatre, that is, covering operations from Normandy to the Baltic. With some alteration they might be suitable for the campaigns in Italy, although the terrain and operational practices make that theatre sufficiently different to make a rethink of the rules a good idea. The rules are not suitable for the Eastern Front or the Far East. The underlying assumptions vary far too much."

"Operation Market Garden was a large and complicated operational game. It involved forces down to battalion level and headquarters up to Corps. When running such a game there is a lot to bear in mind, and the game system has to be robust in order that things progress smoothly. Of course, these rules do not need to be used only in the context of a full sized 100 player megagame -
there are plenty of smaller operations that they could as easily be used for in the context of a club game for half a dozen players."

"In addition to the reasonably straightforward aspects of ground combat the rules consider the problems of air-ground operations (both close support and airborne operations) and logistics (hopefully not quite as boring as some folk make out!)."
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Simulation, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Pirates of Yendor Sea Battle Rules
description:
From the designer's website: "Naval battle game rules for fantasy (or ancient) battle. A development of Ed Smith's 'Greek Naval Warfare' rules of 1974. Suitable for ancient Greeks, Roman or Fantasy battles."

Each model represents one oared galley. Statistics for nine different types of ships are given in the rules. The rules provide for ramming, missile, and boarding combat. Movement is broken into five simultaneous phases, which ships moving in one or more increments based on their current speeds.

name: Red Army: White Guards
description:
Red Army - White Guards: 'Red Square' Rules for the Russian Civil War.

A set of miniatures rules for the Russian Civil War. Designed to be played with 15mm figures on an offset square grid. Each square represents about 500 yards.

Numerous types of units are represented in the game: infantry battalions, machine gun companies, tchanka companies, cavalry regiments, artillery brigades, armoured vehicles, and motor vehicles.

The detailed rules cover aspects such as unit basing, tactical formations, command/control, artillery concealment, artillery observation, vehicle breakdown, overrun, cavalry scouting, and dismounted cavalry.

name: Run?...Or Shoot?
description:
From the rulebook:

"These rules are designed for team play against an umpire-controlled zombie infestation. It is heavily influenced by '28 Days Later' and the game 'Left4Dead'. It is written for use with 20mm/25mm figures and a good source of large numbers of plastic zombies are the ones form the board game Zombies! (they also glow in the dark). The balance of the rules is on the assumption that the survivors are very heavily outnumbered, maybe 20 or 30 to one overall. Ideally the playing area should be fairly close - like an urban or wooded area - with plenty of places for the zombie hordes to lurk in ambush.

In the set up there should be a number of concealed hordes - in basements, behind fences, down sewers etc. These are triggered by player action and attack. In addition there will be small groups or individual zombies scattered about the playing area."
categories: Horror, Miniatures, Print & Play, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: Trench Assault
description:
Trench Assault: The Race to the Parapet 1916.

From the rulebook:

"Purpose of this game is to simulate the rush across noman’s land during a typical battalion assault in 1916. These assaults could be very varied in outcome - from very successful to devastatingly unsuccessful - and many factors, including copious quantities of plain luck would determine the outcome. These rules are simple and fast-moving and in many cases have glossed over a range of technical detail to achieve this."

Each turn equals 3-4 minutes and 1 cm = 5 meters. Figures should be 1/300 or 6mm.

name: Taking the Bull by the Horns
description:
Low level battles against the imperialist aggressors in Zululand, 1879.

From the rulebook:

"These rules are to provide a framework for wargames that simulate the wide range of small battles that were fought when the British Army launched an unprovoked invasion of Zululand in January 1879. The famous battles are well known, but the emphasis of this set of rules is on the smaller actions typically between 500-2000 Zulu and a company of 120 or so of British."

"The game is intended for use with toy solders at the 1/300 scale, although it could just as easily be played at other scales or even with counters on a map."

"The fundamental assumptions are that the firepower of a formed line of British infantry is very devastating, and that the determination and tactical handing of the fighters on both sides is critical to the outcome of each battle."

name: Aegir's Fire
description:
Aegir's Fire: Viking Raider Campaign Game.

From the rulebook:

"This game is starts in the year 83O AD. It is a time when the Vikings (a collective term for various Norse peoples - Danes, Norwegians, Swedes and Finns), started their raiding of the coastlines within reach of their longships. Their control of the oceans eventually meant that they also became a major trading force, as well as the discoverers and colonisers of places like Iceland and Greenland."

"In this game, you are a minor Viking village leader (think up a suitable name). You have managed to stretch the village’s resources to the point of building a longship, to the latest and most fashionable design."

"You will be able to equip and man the ship from your village initially, and dependent upon success or otherwise in your first voyages, you will be able to recruit more experienced fighters from outside the village."

"Success is measured in two ways, status and treasure. These are self-evident."

name: Front Rank...Fire!
description:
Front Rank...Fire! The Zulu War 1879 - Skirmish Wargame Rules.

From the rulebook:

"These rules are intended for small unit actions, involving a handful of British and a larger force of Zulu. In general, odds of around 3:1 in favour of the Zulu produce a balanced game. The Zulu should be grouped into units of 20-40 figures each."

"Ground scale is 1 inch to 2 yards (ie. the same as the figure scale). Time scale is one move represents 6-8 seconds of real time. Figure representation is one figure to one man."

name: Follow Me, Men!
description:
Fantasy miniatures rules for fighting small-scale medieval fantasy battles using 25mm or 28mm figures. The players are represented by leader figures. Other figures (followers) are controlled by the leading figures through orders and actions. Each player typically controls six to twenty figures.

From the rulebook:

"These are rules for playing a wargame with toy soldiers. It is intended for several players - say 4 or more. Players control heroes (and, of course, heroines), who in turn have contingents of fighters under them."

"The setting for fantasy games is one of a sort of mixed dark ages/medieval European environment. Recommended reading for this are the Conan books, Tolkein's Middle Earth books and Terry Pratchet's Diskworld books. There are thousands of heroic fantasy books, of course, but if you've read these you will at least know where the author of the rules is coming from."

name: Tank Duel
description:
Tank Duel is an umpired, dual blind Tactical level miniatures wargame of a battle between two opposing tanks. Two four-player teams represent the opposing tank crews, portraying the commander, gunner, loader, and driver.

From the rulebook:

"The purpose of the game is to simulate, in a simple but realistic way, the problems confronting the crew of an individual tank in combat. To make the game even more difficult, the action takes place between two or more crews, in a sort of stylised 'duel'. Obviously, such one-on-one duels practically never took place, but these games are intended more as a sort of teamwork game, to illustrate a point. There is no reason why the game cannot be expanded to take on larger actions of up to troop level."

"Any scale of model can be used, although it is important that the turrets of the tank models can be rotated independently. For reasons which become apparent later, 1/200 is probably the smallest practical scale, and 1/72 or 1/90 are probably the ideal scales."

"It is vitally important that the terrain scale is the same as the model scale, ie. for 1/72 the ground scale would be 1" = 2 metres."

"Each 'bound' of activity takes 4-5 seconds of real time, and represents approx 10-15 seconds of game time."

"Each player represents one crew member."

name: Fast 111's Card Game
description:
It's a fast-paced race through the U.S.A. along a route that you create. Lay out the license plate cards of the states you will pass through...choose your Fast 111's racer cards...and the competition is on! Try to leave your opponents "in the dust" while you build up your own speed. Hit the maximum and you're on to the next state. The speed and excitement of car-racing...all in a card game. The first one to complete the route wins the game.

This is a card game version of the board game of the same name.

name: I ask you answer
description:
A Swedish card-game for any boys and girls learning English.
The game consists of 50 cards half of which have four questions printed on them (e.g. Where can I meet you next time? Can you lend me ten shilling?) the other half have four answers (e.g. My poor little head! I'm afraid you will be angry with me if I tell you).
Each player gets an equal number of each kind of card. On your turn you ask question number 1 on one of your question cards to any other player who has to use answer number 1 from one of her answer cards. The effect can be hilarious. Continue until all questions and answers have been used. There is no winner. the aim is to get familiar with the English language.

name: Horde Runners
description:
From the online rule page:
Two opposing forces wage a war of the minds as the attempt to steal the "horde" of the other team. Each side has four "thieves" that are attempting to retrieve the treasure of the other team.

Find rules at: http://www.icehousegames.org/wiki/index.php?title=Horde_Runn...

This Icehouse game requires four Icehouse sets, a chess board and one die. This capture the flag style game for two players has players trying to sneak treasures out of their opponent's stockpiles. The first player to bring three pieces of treasure back to the home base is the winner!
mechanics: Action Points, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Flag Grid
description:
Flag Grid is a two player game played on a 9x9 square board.
On each turn,a player must move one of his stones.
A stone moves(orthogonally or Diagonally)a number of cells equals to the number of stones in its row or column.
Wins the player that takes the flag into one of his own bases.

name: Icebreaker, rompe el hielo
description:
Desde las reglas:
Como cualquier otra noche de fin de semana, tienes un objetivo en mente: LIGAR. Y como en la realidad, no te será fácil, tendrás que usar tu encanto personal y para que resulte realmente efectivo, algún que otro regalillo para conquistar a ese/a chico/a con el que te has cruzado en la discoteca.

Por medio de los dados podrás moverte por el tablero para ir entrando en las casillas de tienda, donde comprar objetos, para tu pareja.
El tiempo es limitado, pudiendo variar de entre 15 a 45 minutos, por lo que tienes que darte prisa en conquistar a esa chica o chico antes que los demás.
Un tablero modulable para que cada partida sea única.
Tu objetivo, conseguir 20 puntos para besar a tu personaje.
Ocho personajes que conseguir ligarte, con características únicas.
Más de 40 objetos divididos entre 10 tiendas para elegir.
Y para más diversión, las "Putadas de Calle", cartas para complicarte un poco más conseguir tu reto.

From the rules:
Like anyother night on weekend, your aim in mind is: Get off with sombody. And actually, it isn't going to be easy. You must use your personal charm and, to make it realy effective, some gifts to conquer that boy or girl yoy found in the disco.

Using dice you must run across the board, going into the shops to buy objects to conquer that boy or girl before anyonelse.
Be fast, your time is limited and the other players are going to try to win too.
A modulable board to make every play different.
Your objective, score 20 points to kiss your objective.
8 different characters to kiss, each one with different
characteristics.
More than 40 objects dividen into 10 shops to choose.
And if you need more fun, the "Street Shits" to make harder your goal.
categories: Card Game, City Building, Humor, Party Game, Print & Play
mechanics: Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Simultaneous Action Selection, Variable Player Powers

name: Original Scala
description:
From the back of the Box (translated from German):

An exciting puzzle game for 2 to 4 players. The players try place down five of their own pieces in a row, while preventing the other players from doing the same.

name: Financial City
description:
Financial City is a game made up to increase your knowladge in areas such as the Stock Market, Real Estate, Business. By playing the game, you will experience different situations from real life and you will increase your decision making skills related to income increase. Financial City is for players 14 and up and can be played by up to 8 players. Every player will receive an expenses keeping file. Every player will pick a card from the Jobs category. On each of the cards one will find the profession (specialty), the salary and the monthly expenses. At the beginning of the game every player will receive a sum of money equal to the double of the salary.

From the publishers' website.
mechanics: Paper-and-Pencil, Roll / Spin and Move, Team-Based Game, Trading

name: Schlaub√§r: Wer kennt die Berufe?
description: The children should try to find the halves with the same professions and name the professions correctly. The cards are turned face down, shuffled and laid out. The active player turns up two cards, if the pair matches, the child is asked to describe the profession. The “Schlaubär” allows control, if he fits into the cut-outs of the pair, the pair matches. If so the child receives both cards. The game can also be played with open cards and the child simply should find matching cards.

name: Dice Floor
description:
A game for 2 or 3 players, played with 36 dice per player. Each player tries to score higher than their opponents in rows and columns of a 6x6 grid they fill in with dice.

Each player will fill in his grid die after die, but all players will be using the same die value on a given turn.

In the end, the player with the most high scoring lines wins the game.

name: Behind the Lens
description:
Behind the Lens features 12 endangered species native to New Zealand and their habitats.

Join a team of wild life photographers who are taking a collection of photos overseas to an exhibition. Just as they are about to leave, they discover that three of their photos are spoiled. By helping each other and using your memory, work out which photos are Behind the Lens, but hurry - the plane leaves when it's full.

name: The Flintstones
description:
User summary:
Roll and move race game with cartoon characters...
From back box:
"Everything is ready for departure. Competitors shudder at the wheel of race cars craziest of prehistory.
Here deploy robust Flintmobile , the fast Sabertooth, the reliable Rubblemobile and, finally, the agile Rockasaki.
And now are start!
Along the streets of Bedrock City held the most exhilarating race of prehistory. Vehicles from different performance and unplanned stop decided by your passengers, refueling or police checks, will make the race even more enjoyable. But remember that luck is not enough. A bit of strategy may prove decisive.
Is best a fast vehicle that consumes many gasoline or that slow one but never stop? The choice is yours. So are you ready? The craziest race of prehistory is about to begin. Yabba-dabba-doo!
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Prehistoric, Racing

name: Undead Avenue
description:
The Front Cover Caption:

The Zombie War Skirmish Miniatures Game

Publisher Web Site Blurb:

Undead Avenue is a new take on the classic "escape from the city" urban Zombie Apocalypse story. You start in a section of downtown sealed off in all directions, maybe by accident, maybe because the government or the police or the National Guard doesn't want anyone, or anything escaping.

Unfortunately that includes you.

Choose your character type and begin your search for weapons,
equipment, allies, and most importantly, a way out. The game has
been designed for individual human miniatures to attempt to escape a zombie infected city. While it can be played as a standalone game, it can also be used as a prelude to the miniatures wargame Undead States of America.

name: Labyrinthine
description:
User summary: One player is the Evil Wizard. The Evil Wizard may arrange the sections of the gameboard, representing rooms and hallways, in any way desired. The Evil Wizard places the Princess in the last room. The player(s) representing the questing party wins the game if the Princess can escape from the Evil Wizard. The Evil Wizard player wins by destroying the questing party.

See also Labyrinthine
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Line of Sight, Modular Board, Movement Points, Paper-and-Pencil, Pick-up and Deliver, Secret Unit Deployment, Team-Based Game, Variable Set-up, Zone of Control

name: Willy's Walk to see Grandmamma
description:
A moral race game.

Equipment required: counters of glazed earthenware marked with the letters A to H, teetotum of bone marked with red and black numbers 1 to 6.

Rules:

The game is played with a teetotum and small blocks marked with letters of the alphabet. A player chooses his letter, then spins the teetotum and his block is placed upon the number turned up, of course, according to the directions on the other side. It is best to choose a chairman and allow none to touch the blocks but him. As each player spins, he should call out '6' for 'A' or '2' for 'B' and no persons should spin till the former spinner's move has been made. The coloured squares mark the numbers to which any advantage or disadvantage is attached. If the player makes more than 79, he must count the over plus back - 78,77, and no one is the winner till he has made the exact number.

name: Cars: Radiator Springs Rallye
description:
Game takes place in Radiator Springs, a town created by a Pixar animation studios movie Cars.
Game is mainly for smaller children. The principle is simple: you create one of three possible race tracks (assembles as puzzle) as throw dice to be the first in the finish.
Many obstacles comes in your way: you must draw cards, you lose few turns or you have to go back by a few spots. Each tile is home of one of movie characters.
On the race track can be up to 6 cars made of plastic, but they are looking good. You have to assemble them first.
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Racing

name: Civil War Trivia Board Game
description:
A game of Civil War trivia played across a map of the U.S. and C.S.A. with lead figures. It uses a mix of wargaming and trivia to reproduce the American Civil War.

Players each have 3 armies. On a players turn they will roll the dice, march an army, and answer a question. As a bonus to answering a question correctly, an Active Move is earned. An incorrect answer always ends a players turn. Battles are fought when players end their turn with their armies in the same space as the other player. The game ends when one player holds 5 key positions in the West and Eastern theaters.

Action Moves
a) Raise the Colors
b) Travel by Rail
c) Travel by Water
d) Draw a Travel Card
e) Parole an Army

From the Creators
Civil War Trivia Board Game was produced with the Civil War enthusiast in mind. Based upon actual personalities and events of the Civil War era, it stands as a unique concept of trivia and strategy. So...make yourself Comfortable, General, and prepare to meet the enemy...

name: Satsuma Rebellion 1877
description:
This game covers the last battle around Meiji-Ishin.
One of the important Bakumatsu people, Takamori Saigoh decided to make a revolt in his home area, Satsuma (Kagoshima) in 1877 against his old friends and partners inside Meiji government.
The map covers the whole Kyushu island and uses point to point system.
The game has only 48 counters. This is a small second game, but players can focus the important strategic decisions.
The victory is basically determined by Saigoh's end.
Historically he killed himself in the middle of his losing battle.
But, in this game, if Saigoh player cleverly play the game, there's a chance of bloody stalemate which means that he can propose some of his desire to the government for this revolt.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement

name: Nexus Taxi
description:
Designer Summary:

The galaxy is a busy place and no job is as busy as a taxi driver. Your job is to pilot your taxi ship through warp gates picking up and dropping off passengers. Be careful of the nexus though, should your ship stop there you never know where you will end up. Will you be the first taxi driver to deliver seven passengers before the work day is over?

Nexus Taxi is a light and chaotic two player print-and-play game. Players will need, besides printing the game board, 1 ten-sided die, 14 passenger bits (such as cubes or meeples), and 2 taxis able to hold a passenger piece.

The game board and directions for play can be found in the image and files section (pending).
categories: Abstract Strategy, Print & Play, Science Fiction
mechanics: Pick-up and Deliver, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Make A Match
description:
From the back of the box:

Mixing and Matching fun for all ages.
Players roll the die and try to make as many mixed up comical characters as they can, choosing and combining card parts from different figures. The object then is to try to make complete figures by winning cards from other players. Each complete character scores one point, and the player with the most points wins!

name: Kreuzwort-Pulok
description:
Kreuzwort-Pulok is a collection of games with the same materials: 256 letter tiles (15 don't have letters, but faces on them - these are wildcards) and a grid board for each player that is protected from the view of other players by an integrated paper screen. There also is a cardboard "plate" (a round disk for discarded tiles).

The goal is to form crosswords on the grid boards. There are ten games included:

Sechzehner-Spiel: Each player has to form a word that someone announced. Tiles not needed for this are used for crossing words. Tiles are drawn and discarded (openly, so other players can grab the discarded ones). When the first player finishes, the other get penalties depending on the number of tiles left over and the number of tiles missing for the basic word.

Fünfer-Spiel: Each player has to form a cross of two words with five tiles. When that isn't possible, additional tiles are drawn, but not more than two unused ones can be held in the end. The first player to achieve a legal crossword scores points.

Achter-Spiel: Same as the Fünfer-Spiel, but two or more crosses have to be formed, three tiles can be kept.

Kaufspiel (for two players): Each player draws ten tiles and looks at them without sorting them. The active player can then announce "buying" or "playing". When buying, he/she also announces a number of tiles. Both players now have to discard this number of tiles and redraw them. When playing, both try to form a legal cross with their tiles. The winning player gets 10-15 points, the other one a penalty depending on the number of unused tiles.

Leiter: Two columns of ten letters each are places on the table. The task of the players is to extend each pair of letters in one row into words. Thus they can get rid of their tiles. A player who cannot play has to draw a new tile. The first player to get rid of his/her tiles is the winner.

Gruppenspiel: Similar to Leiter, but with an open cross instead of fixed columns. So the players can add tiles in any direction, as long as the letter combination occurs in a German word.

Wettrennen: Each player gets 19 tiles and secretly forms a cross using at least 11 tiles. The score of the first player to achieve this is 10 plus the last digit squared (11 to 91 points). The other players lose one point for each unused tile.

Wörter anbinden: A letter is placed on the table. Each player takes turns to add a letter, but the letters still have to form the beginning of a word. When that is not possible, all but the last (at least) two tiles are discarded and the last letters start the new word. The first player who can use up his/her tiles is the winner.

Ausfüllspiel: Three letters are flipped open on the plate in the middle of the table. All players now try to form a word which uses two of these letters as first and last letters. The first player to manage this is the winner.

Alleinspiel: A collection of four solitaire games.

The designer of Kreuzwort-Pulok is uncredited, but the preface is signed "J.M." (It seems likely, but isn't entirely clear whether these are the initials of the designer).

(User Summary by HilkMAN)
publishers: J. F. Steinkopf, Otto Maier Verlag

name: Push
description:
Push is played on a initial empty 8x8 board.
Each player inserts a stone onto the board from an edge.
The push may be horizontal,vertical or diagonal,but must be away from the pushing edge.
Passing is not allowed.
If a stone,when pushed meets another stone,this too is pushed on the same direction,and so on.
Wins the player which has 5 stones in a row.

name: Cutlass of Cheese
description:
This is a dungeon crawl created by the same designer as "Cutlass of Fire" and made to poke fun at it. The rules are filled with funny references to the game itself and the previous game.
Squares are laid face down on the table and turned up as player put their pawns on them. The player will encounter walls, monsters, skulls, fountains, and treasure chests. By using cards for all actions except moving, the players battle monsters, find gems, and find spells, weapons and armor. The players' ability to use the items depends on their skills. Spell skills are based on the known elements of the universe, namely: Cheese, Nougat, Lint, and Uranium 236. Weapon skills could be: Stabby, Pummely, Huckey, and Minty Fresh. The number of hits a player or monster can take is called, "Chutzpah." The game ends when 7 gems are returned to 7 skulls (just like Cutlass of Fire) and the player with the most points wins.

name: Der schwarze Ritter
description:
Each player receives 2 Knight (painted plastic) figures.
The aim of the game is to move one of his knights to the castle on the other side of the game board.
A die is used to move the knights.A player can roll as often as he wants until he stops OR until he rolls the "Black Night" which is a symbol on the die.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Election Day
description:
From the Decktet wiki: Rule of the land was benevolently shared by the six Crowned Princes. Every five years the people would elect one of the Princes to lead the land for the next five years. Before the election, the Princes would hold a series of debates in which they would demonstrate why they were most fit to lead for the next five years. The debates were always reviewed by the three major newspapers and typically two of the papers' editors would agree that one of the Princes won the debate while the third paper's editor would choose someone else as the clear victor. In the end, the people would vote and a new leader would rule peacefully for another five years.

Election Day takes great advantage of the structure of the Decktet cards. There are 6 suits with 2 suits on each card. Each suit represents a prince. Each player plays one card face up on their turn until all players pass, ending the debate. The suit appearing most frequently during the debate keeps two of its highest point cards as influence points until the end of the game. The next most frequently appearing suit keeps one of its highest point cards until the end of the game. After all the debates, the influence cards accumulated are added up and the suit with the most influence indicates who the winning prince is. The player who backed that prince is the winning player.

name: Schlangenprinzessin
description:
Each player has a snake which is made of colorful pearls. The game has no board, instead, a starting line and a finish line are determined at the players' discretion. The snakes are laid out at the starting line.

Each player rolls two color dice in his/her turn, then moves one end of his/her snake forward until the two colors are adjacent to each other. The first snake to reach the finish line is the winner.

The game is luck-driven, but there is minimal decision making for the kids, as they have to understand which end they should move forward in order to go faster.

(User summary by HilkMAN)

name: Italian City States
description: Historical Game for 2-5 players. Each player controls 1 of the following Italian powers during the 15th century Renaissance: Republic of Florence, Republic of Venice, Duchy of Milan, Kingdom of Naples, and Papal States. Players compete to improve their scores in 6 Categories: Religion, Politics, Humanities, Military, Buildings, and Economics. Having the lead in a category gives you a special ability as long as you are able to maintain that lead.

name: Imperial Powers
description: Bidding Game for 3-5 players. Theme: Imperial Expansion of European Powers circa 1600-1750. Players compete for control in 10 Global Regions by assigning influence cards of differing values. Control of a region awards victory points. Regions gradually grow in value (in a partially player-determined fashion) as the game progresses. Finally, Events at the end of each turn can radically change influence totals in each of the Regions.

name: Farligt hav
description: Fairly abstract game supplied with a naval theme. Players try to cross the board with their ship while firing mines to block the progress of enemy ships. The mines and ships all have pegs which fit in the grid of holes on the board. There are a few different ways of playing depending on the number of players and desired playing time.

name: The Golf Game
description:
A lavishly produced game which tries to be a straight simulation of playing all 18 holes on the course at St Andrews, the home of Golf. The game has 9 huge colour printed, double-sided boards, laying out an accurate depiction of the course. Players shots are randomise by using a spinner and cards for direction and distance. There are a series of long clear plastic rules which are your clubs. You choose which one to use as you progress. These mark the point where your ball finally lands, based upon the randomisation.

The rules are in English, French, German, Italian and Dutch. There is no designer given, nor actual year of production, but the score-pads included refer to St Andrews as the home of the 1978 Open, suggesting it was produced around then.

name: Tank Traders
description:
Tank Traders is an auction game in which you build terminals with building cards you acquire through 3 kinds of auctions: ascending-price, descending price and sealed-price. The player who manages to build 2 terminals first, wins the game.

From the back of the box: An exciting and fast family game in which strategy, bluff and commercial spirit come together. Conquer the world of logistics by building your own independent tank terminal network.

name: Bid$
description:
From the box:

"Bid$ is a truly challenging experience that is totally unique from most board games in that any property is available, if you are willing to bid the right price. You can taste the satisfaction of forcing your opponents to pay too much for their modest properties, or jump at the opportunity of stealing a legitimate good deal by being shrewd and cunning. If you like fast paced competitive fun that keeps the chance factor to a minimum, try Bid$, the game where you do control your own destiny."

Object of the game (2-6 players) - To make as much money as possible by buying stores and eventually towers. Each player picks a marker and starts at "receive $1500" (you do not collect the money until you have gone around the board once). All players play around the outside edge (lower level) and can only move into the upper level (inside edge) with a bank payment of $15,000. The players begin by rolling the dice, and the player with with the highest number starts first. The rest of the order is determined by going clockwise. When play begins, if a player rolls doubles, he/she is allowed to go again. The player keeps rolling until he/she stops getting doubles (property that you hit along the way must be bid on or if it is owned the owner must be paid). Each player is given $21,000 at the start of the game. When a property is landed on, the bidding starts.

name: ROLLette
description:
From the box: Ready, set, ROLL! Land three or more marbles in a row and score!

Object: Be the first player to score 50 points. Score points by landing your marbles to create rows of three or more in the same quadrant.

User comment: The game consist of 25 marbles (5 each of 5 colors) and a circular board, about 12 inches in diameter. Around the outer rim of the board are 28 three-quarter inch holes. Between the holes and the rim of the board is where a player will roll his marble--in the style of a roulette wheel--and hope it lands in a desirable hole in a desirable quadrant of the board. Landing several marbles in a row gains points, whether they be three in a row of your color or of mixed colors.

Instructions are printed on the bottom of the box.

name: Clovis: The Dice Game
description:
This is a dice-based version of the card game Clovis, which was released as a free Print and Play game early in 2009. The Dice game consists of 10 dice and a scoring sheet for each player. Players roll the dice to simulate hunting large game animals on the North American continent 12,000 years ago. There are special option dice which allow players to acquire more dice to roll and modify the results of their rolls. The game ends after the players jointly have accumulated a certain number of unsuccessful hunts (busts).

One major difference in Clovis: the Dice Game' from the original card game is the solo option. In a solo game of Clovis: the Dice Game you are challenged to earn 100 points or more to win.

Clovis: the Dice Game' Game is fast (10 - 20 minutes), easy to learn, easy to setup and put away, and best of all... FREE!!

name: Havoc Expansion: John of Gaunt
description:
User Summary

The John of Gaunt Expansion is a two-card expansion for Havoc: the Hundred Years War and cannot be played without the base game.

The expansion introduces John of Gaunt, son of Edward III, who led a series of lightning raids striking deep into France with a force of about 10,000 men. Later in life he helped his brother's son (Richard II) consolidate power during his reign.

John creates his own special battle when he comes into the game before "retiring" to his estate.

Components:
- 1 Rules sheet (double-sided with English & German instructions)
- 1 John of Gaunt card, to be added to the regular HAVOC deck
- 1 Chevauchees Battle card, two-sided (Side 1 is Calais to Tours, side 2 is Tours to Bordeaux)
- 1 Plastic ziplock bag for Havoc game Tokens

It appears that this expansion, and a few other promos, were later combined to form the Havoc Character Card expansion.

name: Scoreboard Tennis
description: Scoreboard Tennis is Inside Sports' latest addition to our Quick Play line of games. All players are rated for each surface they played on, based on their real life performance. With each season that is rated, any match-up can be replayed on your tabletop. You can even replay entire Grand Slam tournaments. Scoreboard Tennis offers two different quick play options. You can choose to play a match either Set by Set or Game by Game with just a single roll of the dice determining the winner of the set or game. Scoreboard Tennis is the perfect companion to Inside Sports' Inside Volley Tennis game. With these two games combined, you have the option to play a match Set by Set, Game by Game, or Point by Point. The choice is yours. No other tennis game on the market offers this kind of versatility!

name: Star Block
description:
From the back of the box:

GET TO CRYSTAL CITY BEFORE THE ROBOTS TAKE OVER

A landing party from the starship "Aurora" beams down to explore an uncharted planet in search of provisions. The spacemen meet unfriendly robots who move about trying to keep the "invaders" from entering Crystal City. But the spacemen need supplies, so they plot thier course over the alien surface in a bid to occupy Crystal City before the robots can take over their landing site.


* *


User Summary:

In Star Block, each player controls five pieces, either spacemen or robots. The two forces start on opposite sides of a board consisting of forty-four pentagon-shaped spaces. The object is to be the first player to occupy all five spaces of the opponent's starting row. Pieces may neither be captured nor jumped; however, pieces may be blocked (hence the name of the game).

name: The Ivory Castle Game
description:
Advertisers variant of Snakes and Ladders, produced in 1935 to advertise D& W Gibbs "Dentifrice" Toothpaste.

Size approx.35cm X 46cm when unfolded (central fold). Printed on cardboard - board has two holes and a string at the top to allow it to be hung up as an advertising item. Rules are printed on the rear of the board.

Includes dice and 4 coloured counters.

Game was posted in a pink envelope with the rules printed on them. Publisher unknown, but game was produced for D & W Gibbs Ltd, Wapping, London E1.

The object of the game is to reach the land of Health and Happiness, and the player who gets there first wins. Along the way there are various difficulties to help and hinder the player; for example, the Gibbs Fairy helps, an Imp hinders, and a Giant (called Decay!) handicaps the player at the start of the game. Various spaces have actions associated with them, that send the player to other squares. A roll and move mechanism with a standard six sided die is used to determine each players movement.

Unusual variant of Snakes and Ladders, produced by the Gibbs toothpaste company to promote their products and raise awareness of dental hygiene. Who said that games weren't good for you?

Other links:
http://www.tes.co.uk/article.aspx?storycode=334946

name: Hickory Dickory Dock
description:
From the box back:

Learn about time as you help your mouse climb to the top fo the clock.

Aim of the game:
To correctly match the activity cards with the clock and reach the top of the clock first.

Contents:
1 Clock playing board
2 Clock hands and pivot
16 Illustrated activity cards
18 Clock cards
4 Mice and plastic stands

Aim of the game
To correctly match the activity cards with the clock cards and reach the top of the clock first.

How to play
1. The hands are attached to the clock face. The playing board is assembled and placed in the centre of the table.

2. Four activity cards are dealt to each player, picture side up. Any leftover cards are discarded, along with the matching clock cards. The remaining clock cards are spread out face down on the table.

3. Each player chooses a mouse counter and places it in the 'start' area of the playing board.

4. The first player begins by turning over one of the clock cards on the table. They read aloud the time and look to see if it matchs the time on one of their activity cards. If a match is made, they move the clock hands on the playing board to the correct time, move their mouse forward one space and keep the clock card.

5. If the time on the clock card does not match any of the player's activity cards, the clock card is returned to the table, face down, and play moves onto the next player.

6. If the clock card shows 'one o'clock', each player must move their mouse back one space on the clock board. All players also return one of their clock cards to the table. The matching activity card is then back in play.

7. Play continues until one player has matched all their cards and has reached the top of the clock playing board.

Winning the game
The first player to have match all their activity cards with the clock cards and reached the last space at the top of the clock playing board is the winner.

name: Mandala: The Strategic Game of Life Choices
description:
From the box: "Object of the game: be the first player to put together a full life pyramid. You use success strokes, health and soul strokes and riches to do this."

From the rules: "The winning player is the first one to build a full life Pyramid. The Pyramid is build of four rows of colorful squares, called strokes.

"Each player gets strokes four ways: Trading strokes with others; By rolling the dice each turn; By risking Life Choices; By drawing FATE cards.

"Players can lose strokes through Life Choices, FATE cards or trades, also. You cannot lose more than you have, however."

User comment: Players start on the The Birthplace space, and could end up on Skid Road, Paid Vacation or The Northerly View Home for the Befuddled.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Q4
description:
The game is played on four trays, each tray having four by four holes where marbles can be placed. The trays are placed side by side on the board and each player starts the game with 12 marbles. On each players turn he can place one of his marbles on any tray as he chooses and thus trying to make four in a row (or a Q4 as it's called in the game rules). The Q4 can be on a single tray or spanning all the trays (that is, three dimensional).

After a player has played all his marbles he can start to move them around (on the same tray or between trays). After placing a marble he can claim a Q4. If the Q4 is on a single tray it should be fairly obvious whether it's a Q4 or not. If the Q4 spans all the trays, they must be stacked (the leftmost being on the bottom, the rightmost on the top) and then it can be checked whether the claim for a Q4 is true or not.

The first one to make a Q4 wins the game.

Similar to:

3D Tic Tac Toe - which is played on 3x3x3 grid
Four Letter Words - though with words
Qubic - which is also played, with placement only, on 4x4x4 grid but with 32 markers for each player
Tetrano - which is the same game represented on a 4x4 board.
Qubic - which has a version for 3 players also
Score Four - 4x4 grid of pegs that are filled from the bottom up

name: Starbattles (The Card Game)
description:
User Summary...

Created as a follow-up to the Starbattles tactical space combat game, Starbattles (The Card Game) is described in its rulebook as "a beginner level card game of tactical space combat. It is a fast paced card game where all the action is in front of you and in your hand."

To date, only simply produced play-test versions of this game have been documented. It is unknown whether or not this game ever made it into full production.

Components:
- 1 Rules Folder (6 pages on continuous paper)
- 54 Ship Cards (all cards for this game are printed on sheets for players to cut out)
- 1 Set of Hit/Destroyed Counters (the sheet devoted to last minute changes indicates that these are not included)
- 6 Play Sheets
- 6 Player Order Cards
- 114 Action Cards
- (a six-sided die is required, but not included)

Notes on play:
Each player has a Play Sheet where ship status and damaged is tracked. Essentially, the Play Sheet represents a player's home base... their ships (as represented on Ship Cards) are placed on areas on the Play Sheet that show the ship's position relative to their base. Players score victory points by finishing off other player's ships. The game ends and victory points are totaled when only one player has active ships left.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Variable Phase Order

name: Recession
description:
A trick-taking game played with traditional playing cards.

When you win a hand, the winning card is discarded and the rest of the cards in the trick go into your hand. The round ends when one player runs out of cards.

Score is kept after each hand for every card left in that player's hand.

The player with the most points after 3 rounds wins.

name: el Desierto: el Tesoro del Tuareg
description:
"el Desierto" is game for 2 to 6 players where all try to find the tuareg's treasure. One player manages the tuareg pieces and the rest are explorer looking for clues in different cities. When they draw the right cards, they can do an excavation and look one of eight treasure locations (represented by eight face down cards). When a player believes to know where the treasure is hidden, he moves his piece to that location and do an excavation; if it's correct he wins the game. The tuareg player have different rules to move his camel pieces and also can obstruct other players actions.

From the back of the box art: "Hace mucho tiempo los tuaregs, tribu nómada del desierto del Sáhara, encontraron una gran parte del legendario tesoro del Rey Salomón, regalo de la Reina de Saba. El hallazgo fue por casualidad, mientras excavaban buscando un pozo enterrado por una tormenta de arena. La codicia que tal tesoro despertó consiguió romper la armonía que hasta entonces reinaba entre este pueblo del desierto. Muchos tuaregs murieron por culpa del antiguo tesoro y Halim el Sabio, Señor de las duna, quedó tan apenado que mandó a sus súbditos que enterraran el tesoro de nuevo en el desierto. Hombre previsor, Halim pensó que quizás en el futuro el tesoro podría ser útil a su pueblo, así que esparció pistas falsas y verdaderas por todo el desierto, para que solo él o sus descendientes superan el lugar donde el tesoro estaba enterrado. Pero sucedió que su bisnieto Al Denir, el Bienmandado murió sin descendencia, y el tesoro de los tuaregs y su situación se convirtió con el tiempo en tan solo una leyenda, una historia para contar junto al fuego las largas y frías noches del desierto..."

name: Please Stand By
description:
From Publishers Website:
Please Stand By is a quick and easy to learn rules system for fast paced tabletop miniature gaming. Game play can be enhanced with special and advanced rules that players can incorporate into their games. Please Stand By gives you the opportunity to play in almost any genre or era from your favorite zombie settings. Seven different scenarios and multiple objectives make for a unique and different game experience each time you play.
categories: Book, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame, Zombies
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game

name: The Pre-Dreadnought Era 1870-1905
description:
This is a naval combat game designed to recreate the tactics used in the transitional period of fleet actions that spanned the era between sail and steam.

The only scenario provided in the rules covers the decisive 1898 battle of Santiago during the Cuban Campaign. The designer suggests that players consult reference works like "Jane's Fighting Ships" to create additional scenarios. The battle system uses dice and hits are determined by armor thickness and the penetrating power of the projectile.

Includes a map, 60 counters, and a 24 page rule booklet.

name: Prime
description: Each player begins with seven face-down cards, four of which he is allowed to peek at. A card will display one of the following prime numbers: 2,3,5,7,11,13,or 17. A round lasts seven turns. On each turn, a player either exposes one of his cards or exchanges it for a card that is in the draw deck or discard deck. The object is to collect the most primes without duplicating any. Scoring is based on the face values of the un-duplicated cards. Play a few rounds until a designated point total is reached. (User Summary)

name: Newfoundlandia III: The Photo Game
description:
Would you recognize John Crosbie from a photograph? Could you identify Joe Batt's Arm? Do you know what barnacles look like? Each photograph tests your knowledge of a Newfoundland location, personality, or cultural item.

Contains OVER 200 PHOTOGRAPHS for you to identify. Photos are in four different categories: Arts & Culture, People & Politics, History & Geography, and Townie Trivia. Suitable for two or more players (or teams) ages 7 to adult. Ideal for the car, cottage, or classroom.

-(from the box cover)

name: Ruhrgebiet-Quiz
description:
Simple trivia game with questions related to the German Ruhr area. The game consists of cards with one question and answer each. Players take turns asking the other player(s) questions. A player who can answer a question gets the card. The player with most cards at the end of the game is the winner.

(User summary by HilkMAN)

name: Berlin-Quiz
description:
Simple trivia game with questions related to the German capital city. The game consists of cards with one question and answer each. Players take turns asking the other player(s) questions. A player who can answer a question gets the card. The player with most cards at the end of the game is the winner.

(User summary by HilkMAN)

name: Niagara
description:
You are caught with your canoe by the raging torrent of Niagara Niagara Falls. But you're not alone. Several teams compete, who will remain the longest on the rapid?

Each player chooses two canoes of the same color and place them on the starting line.
Each turn the player throws three dice: two normal D6s to determine canoe movement, and a special dice with blank sides and stars.
The star indicates that the movement mechanism is activated, thus carrying the canoes over the edge of the waterfall.
The player can move his own canoes or the canoes of his opponents!
Tree trunks floating on the river can force re-throws for the canoes passing them.
The goal is to stay the longest on the rapid.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: The Gatling's Jammed: Wargaming Colonial Warfare in the 19th Century
description:
A colonial stand alone variant of the General de Brigade Napoleonic wargame rules. Unlike most colonial wargames, this set is aimed at recreating the larger battles of the period rather than skirmishes.

Includes army lists for:

The First Afghan War
The Second Afghan War
The Sikh Wars
The Indian Mutiny
The Zulu Wars
The Sudan

name: Campaign
description:
Campaign is played on an empty 10x10 square board.
Initially, each player drops a Knight into an empty cell. The 1st Player may not drop his Knight into any of the four center spaces.
On each turn, each player moves his own Knight (like in Chess) into an empty cell, leaving behind a marker of his color.
The first player that makes a 5 in-a-row wins.
A player who cannot move on his turn loses.

name: Wargamer's Guide To Ancient Combat
description: From the frontispiece: "A practical set of rules and background material covering the period 1500 B.C. to 200 A.D. for wargaming in 15mm to 25mm scales."

name: Froggy Land
description:
In Froggy Land, each player controls 6 daring and dauntless frogs trying to arrive, safe and sound, through a winding water lilies’ Path to their home. To achieve that, they would have to use all the elements (support tokens) that inhabit the Pond; moreover, they have to avoid the wicked Owl if they don’t want to lose all their advances. Once a player gets the 6 frogs to their home, she’s the winner and the game ends.


Playtestings & Design Notes (in Spanish)



Print & Play en Heraldo de Arag√≥n (in Spanish)


Froggy Land was explicitly inspired by Cartagena (Leo Colovini) and Corporation (Eric Solomon).
categories: Animals, Dice, Memory, Print & Play, Racing

name: Monopoly: Elvis 75th Anniversary Collector's Edition
description:
From USAopoly.com:

Happy Birthday Elvis!

Get ready to rock 'n' roll with the King in this special 75th anniversary collector's edition of the MONOPOLY game. Celebrate Elvis' music and live performances as you buy, sell and trade his most memorable albums and concerts such as Blue Hawaii, G.I. Blues and Madison Square Garden. Recall Elvis' movie career with music from King Creole and Jailhouse Rock. Don't pass GO without visiting Memphis and Vegas in an attempt to Own it All.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Monopoly: Prologis Industrial Real Estate Edition
description:
Prologis Industrial Real Estate Edition by Parker Brothers. Custom made edition for the world largest owner, manager, and developer of distribution facilities. Includes 6 custom pewter
tokens including semi truck, train, airplane, frieght ship, forklift and passport. World wide properties, houses and hotels replaced by distribution centers and distribution parks.
Global and substainability card replace chance and community chess. A really unique version for a classic game
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: A Box of Matches
description: A Box of Matches is an abstract tile placement game for 2 to 4 players using 42 square tiles with one of 4 symbols on each side of the tile. Tiles are worth 1 to 3 points as indicated in the center of the tile. The game begins with a square made of 4 randomly drawn tiles and each player drawing a hand of 3 tiles. Players take turns in clock-wise order placing a tile and replenishing their hand. The newly placed tile must be set side-by-side to the previously played tiles such that any adjoining sides have matching symbols. The turn is scored by adding the value of the newly placed tile to each tile that it touches. The winner is the player with the highest score after all tiles are played.

name: O&O
description:
In Ontwikkelaars & Ontwerpers (Developers & Designers) you (and the competing players) are developers of computer games. You only have one goal; design the best game ever!
To achieve this you have to acquire different resources, like art designers, game engines etc. Of course you have to stay ahead of the other developers. You have to use your insight, cunning and financial funds to reach the top.

O&O is a fast-paced deck-building game for 2-4 players suitable for ages 12 and up that can be played anywhere (where there is a flat surface).

name: First War for Scottish Independence
description: This is a Warpspawn two-player card game representing English v. Scots circa 1296-1314 (You all saw "Braveheart"). Game lasts exactly 72 turns, every 4th turn a very short one to account for that year's winter season; automatic victory at any time if one side captures all 20 territory tokens. Each turn each plays leader, nobles, and troops cards; then event cards to affect cards in play; then strategy cards to enhance their side, highest number of different types of cards gets victory that year, takes a token from the other, may get some additional benefit. I've made a card set (deleting 2 equally-matched cards, 1 for each side, to fit the cards conveniently on 3 sheets.

name: Renpaarden
description:
Renpaarden is played on a 9x9 square board.Each player starts with 18 stones 9 on each of the two back ranks.
A player must move one of his stones.Each stone moves like the chess Knight.
Wins the first player that moves all his stones to the opponent´s initial position.

name: On The Edge
description:
On The Edge is an abstract block-stacking game for two players:
From the Rules:
Be the first person to stack your cubes on their edge making sure not cover any white square in the center of each cube.

Play of the game:
Each player takes 8 of the same coloured cubes. Each cube has a weight on one side, so that when stacking players will need to put the side with the weight on the cube below it. To start, take any cube from your pile and place it on a flat surface in front of you. Take another cube and stack it on the edge of your first cube. Be sure not to stack the cube on the white square in the centre. Continue stacking until you have stacked all 8 of your cubes. If your cubes should fall, continue stacking.

There are two alternate ways to play: a race to stack your cubes or take turns and stack on a shared stack. First to cause the stack to fall, loses the round. Play for five rounds.

name: Chieftain Chess
description:
Chieftain Chess is a structured multi-move game for 2 teams of 1-4 players/side. It is scalable, with larger and smaller versions available. A chess-wargame fusion that uses 5 different types of simple short-range chess-like pieces, it mimics various aspects of an ancient battle on a 12x16 rectangular field. Four chiefs [the strongest but not the fastest pieces] per side lead their 32 piece armies in a set-piece battle that begins just after the 2 armies start to close with each other.

Victory is achieved by killing all 4 enemy chiefs before your 4 get killed. Players move as many pieces per turn as they have friendly chiefs on the board. The moving pieces must be within "command control range" of the chiefs, generally 3 squares, to be able to move that turn. This forces the royal pieces to be active participants in the heat of the battle, rather than trying to hide in the corners like the kings of chess.

Most games, regardless of size, are determined in 30-40 turns. The game is designed so the pace increases from beginning to end. The players start with 1 chief for every 8 pieces, so they move about 12% of their armies each turn in the beginning. By midgame, 20-25% of the army moves each turn, and by the endgame, roughly 50% of the remaining pieces move each turn.

The game trades space for time compared to western chess. Where attacks in chess are sequenced deeply in time but concentrated in space, in Chieftain multiple attacks are spread out across space, but can't be accurately calculated more than 2 or 3 turns deep in time. It has a deliberate, almost defining theme, yet it is a pure abstract game, with perfect information, and in its specific "combat" pieces and their movement rules, there is no semblance of reality. What it allows is a game played on 2 levels, the tactical level being a pure, simple chess variant, and the strategic level being a simulation of a wargame.

The game may be played online at chessvariants.org, or a Chieftain Chess set can be made from 2 complete sets of chesspieces and 3 same-sized chess boards, one cut in half, for face to face play.

name: Monster-opoly
description:
What’s a Monster to do?

Let’s face it! Monsters are horribly misunderstood... They’re just trying to get along, just like everybody else. Trying to find a place in the world, make friends, find jobs, fun things to do. Monsters have hopes and dreams, you know.

SO WHY ALL THE SCREAMING?

Everytime we see a monster- WWWHHHHAAAAAAAHHHH! Get over it! Sit down and play a game of MONSTER-OPOLY and get to know these lovable mugs! Collect monster friends, increase your rents with a Scream. This is a game that could change the world! Monsters and humans UNITE!

Why can’t we all just get along?

Source: Publisher's Web Page
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection
publishers: Late for the Sky Production Company

name: Spurt a√∞ leikslokum: Fyrir 7-12 √°ra
description: Expansion for the base game, with 540 new questions for children 7-12 years old.

name: Spurt a√∞ leikslokum: Popp ‚Äì d√¶gurm√°l ‚Äì af√æreying
description: Expansion for the base game, with 540 new questions on music, pop culture and recreation.

name: Spurt a√∞ leikslokum: √ör √Ωmsum √°ttum
description: Expansion for the base game, with 540 new questions on various subjects.

name: Schachdame
description:
Schachdame is the oldest crossover between Chess and Checkers. The game is known since 1883 when its inventor, the German Chess player Heinrich Richter, published a small booklet (8 pages) about his game:

"Schachdame: eine neues Familienspiel, welches die Principien des Schachspiels mit der Leichtigkeit des Damenspiels vereinigt"

(Translation: "Chess-Checkers: a new family game, which combines the principles of the game of Chess with the lightness of the game of Draughts")

Rules:

The game is played on a chess board. Each player has eight pieces: six "Bauern" (Peasants), one "Ritter" (Knight) and one "Dame" (Lady).

Initial Set-up

White:
Dame e1; Ritter c1; Bauern a1, b2, d2, f2, g1, h2.

Black:
Dame d8, Ritter f8, Bauern a7, b8, c7, e7, g7, h8.

The Peasants move like Draughts men.

The Kinghts move like the Bishop in Chess.

The Lady moves like the King of American Straight Checker/English Draughts.

A Peasant is promoted to a Knight when it reaches the last file.

Capture is by replacement (as in Chess).

The object is to mate the opponent's Lady.

name: Category Craze
description:
From the box: "Draw a Category Card and roll the Letter Die to select a letter. Everyone has ONE MINUTE to write things from the selected category that start with the letter on the die. THINK FAST! WRITE FAST!"

This Scattegories-type game includes a die with every letter of the alphabet on it, plus some sides that say "Vowel", meaning the rolling player chooses a vowel.

According to the rules, a game consists of each player taking a turn flipping up a card with a category written on it (such as "sports teams") and rolling the letter die, and then all players have one minute (timer not included) to write down (paper and pencils not included) as many words starting with that letter as possible.

Each player gains one point per word, and any unique words (ones that other players don't have), then it is worth two points.

The game finishes when each player has rolled the die three times. The highest score wins.

name: 6 x 6 Abstract Game
description:
Players put arrows to reach and win the treasures. Each treasure won, depending on the situation on the board, awarded to the player that get it, victory points (hereafter VP). Players also can put barriers and play action cards to prevent the rival wins VP.
When three treasures have been removed from the board ends the round. The players roll the dice again to put the treasures on the board and the second round starts. The game ends when one player reaches 66 VP, is the winner, or at the end of the third round. In this case, the winner is the player who has achieved more VP.

Components:
- Board.
- 1 green dice and 1 white dice.
- 4 treasures to win by players and 1 token to indicate the round in which we are.
- For each colour 5 short arrows and 1 long arrow, 1 marker score, 5 action cards.


Los jugadores ponen flechas para alcanzar y ganar los tesoros. Cada tesoro ganado, dependiendo de su situación en el tablero, otorgará al jugador que lo consiga puntos de victoria (en adelante PV). Además pueden colocar barreras y jugar fichas de acción para impedir que el rival gane PV.
Los jugadores van jugando por turnos, cuando se han retirado 3 tesoros del tablero acaba la ronda. Se vuelven a tirar los dados para colocar de nuevo los tesoros en el tablero y se empieza la segunda ronda. El juego termina cuando uno de los jugadores alcance los 66 PV o al final de la tercera ronda. En este caso, el jugador que más PV haya conseguido seré el ganador

Componentes:
- Tablero.
- 2 dados, 1 verde y 1 blanco.
- 4 tesoros a ganar por los jugadores y 1 ficha para indicar la ronda en la que estamos.
- Por cada color 5 flechas cortas y 1 larga, 1 marcador de puntuación, 5 fichas de acciones.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Line Drawing, Network and Route Building, Race, Square Grid

name: Mexico Bronco
description:
It´s 1910 and revolution is about to start in Mexico because the welfare of the few is based on the oppression of the majority. Several chieftains are fighting to impose their ideals. You´ll have to control them and take advantage of the historical events to win the race of power.

There are two types of cards: chieftains and event cards.
Players choose a pawn that will move spaces in the board depending on the event cards. At the beginning of each turn a player draws 5 cards and can play 3 cards, chieftains and/or events. The events affect the players controlling the chieftains involved in the historical event and the pawns of these players move forward/backward. The game ends when a player is in the "Power" space at the beginning of his/her turn.

name: Rich Making Board Game
description: This is a discount priced Korean children's roll-n-move game sold at Daiso stores. The gameplay is similar to The Game of Life. Players move around a brightly colored board at one of four stand-up figures. The players collect cards that will be used to score the player's fortunes at the end of the game. The player with the greatest fortune at the end is the winner.

name: Omega War: Salvo 2064
description:
Omega War: Salvo 2064 is a solitaire print-n-play game loosely based on the old pencil-n-paper game Salvo, with several new twists and the option for multi-player games.

You play the lone survivor of a global war battling against a mobile AI bunker intent on exterminating you with powerfull reflex beams capable of targeting locations on the other side of the planet. You are simmilarly armed and must pin down the AI and destroy it before it locates your last safe haven and finishes off the human race.

The game was designed to be blind accessible and may be found at the Starfield Games site.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Paper-and-Pencil, Secret Unit Deployment

name: Hell on Wheels: a Warpspawn card game
description: A Warpspawn game simulating the emergence - and rapid disappearance - of "vice towns" as the Union Pacific Railroad was laying down tracks in the 1860's to link the east and west coasts of the USA. Each of 2-6 players bids to become RR Supervisor, who controls the order of activities in that turn, then spends their filthy lucre to build civilized establishments (schools, post offices) that bring in tax money and "other" establishments (saloons, gambling halls) that bring in more filthy lucre if they have lots of customers and mayhem. The game was just made available by Lloyd Krassner's Warpspawn Games, rules available on the Warpspawn website and e-group.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Hand Management, Variable Phase Order

name: Peter the Great: Warpspawn card game
description: Players bid on cards representing various events during the reign of Peter the Great. Successful bids capture cards which generate victory points symbolizing accomplishments in the modernization of Imperial Russia. Cards with Peter himself don't generate victory points, but rather grant advantageous contingencies. There are 10 cards in each of 7 suites, unlike most Warpspawn card games there aren't different "force" or "power" levels for different cards. The bidding requires different colored cubes picked at random, a unique mechanism in which high bid is most-cubes-of-that-color rather than most-play-money.

name: Crystal Formation
description:
Crystal Formation is an Icehouse game for 2-4 players played on a chessboard.
Each player is given all of one color pieces and starts with a tree of their color in their corner of the board.The piece represents a node.
During your turn,you may perform one of the following actions:
1.Place new nodes.
2.Increase the total power of a node.
3.Move a node.
First player with 5 trees on the board wins.

name: Ice 3
description:
Ice 3 is an Icehouse game played on a chessboard.
Dump the Icehouse pieces out and arrange them as randomly on a chessboard as you can.Leave the center four spaces empty.
During your turn,you may move all pieces of either a color or a size any number of spaces in any one direction.
The object of the game is to get all of one color in any corner.

name: Forest Wars of the Haven
description:
"Forest Wars of the Haven" is a Fantasy themed board-wargame based on the novel The Haven (later revised as Forest Wars) by Graham Diamond, the co-designer. The game depicts an assault by the Forces of Man (also called the Forces of the Haven), consisting of humans, wolves, hawks, and eagles, on the camp of the Forest Lords, who control dogs and bats.

The gameplay will be familiar to anyone who has played a grand tactical wargame. The system is fairly standard for the period, with some special rules for air support, charging units, and units which can be hidden or have variable loyalty.

name: G√™m y Steddfod
description:
Gêm fwrdd hwyliog ar gyfer rhwng dau a chwe chwaraewr yn gofyn i chwaraewr deithio o gwmpas maes yr Eisteddfod Genedlaethol yn osgoi rhwystrau di-ri cyn dychwelyd i'w gar o flaen ei wrthwynebwyr, yn cynnwys cyfarwyddiadau llawn, bwrdd chwarae, cardiau, cwestiynau, dis a chownteri; i blant ac oedolion.

A lively board game for two to six players requiring a player to circuit the National Eisteddfod field avoiding many hindrances and returning to his car before his rivals, comprising full instructions, a playing board, question cards, dice and counters; for children and adults alike. (www.gwales.com)

For those who don't know the National Eisteddfod is the largest travelling arts festival in Europe, the game attempts to recreate a visit to the Eisteddfod avoiding unpopular relatives, achieving goals, etc. Particularly poigniant to those who have spent any time on the "Maes".

name: Lucky Ducks
description:
Players each have a stack of cards, each card with 3 ducks of the same color, each with 2 of the 3 ducks having a hole in the center of their body. The game board has large colored circles, the same colors of the ducks. The object of the game is to be the first to lay down all your cards, by placing them on the game board so that the ducks with holes match the circles on the board.

Each player always has two cards face up to be seen by all, so opportunities for strategy occur by placing the ducks (vertically, horizontally, right-side up, upside-down) to block opponents. Also, if a card cannot be placed, one from the board is removed, thoughtfully, so that the played is helped on his next turn, but not the opponent.

Contents:
1 playing board
28 cards in 4 colors

name: Der Wortwal
description:
Willi the Word Whale plunges the players into the depths of the sea and bring his word friend the octopus with him to blow letters. Unfortunately he has forgotten the vowels. Can you allocate the appropriate vowels so that meaningful words arise?

Gameplay: The 36 cards are dealt to the players, the players divide the cards into two stacks - backside up. The first player reveals the two cards simultaneously and place them on the middle of the table -the players then try to form words from the letters on the card by inserting vowels. The first to form a word wins a card. If one of the cards shows a golden ring the players try to be first to shout "Ahoy", the next time a golden ring card is revealed you should shout Ehoy!, then Ihoy!, then Ohoy! and then Uhoy! When all cards are revealed and distributed, the game is over. The player with the most cards is the winner.

name: Flash
description:
The objective of the game is to get as many points as possible answering questions. Every correct answer is awarded one point.

Every question (1920 in total) is accompanied by a picture. Cards with pictures and questions are put into a specially designed folder that allows you to only see the questions on one side and the answers on the backside.

The person or team that has the most points after finishing the 3 folders with random questions, wins.

(Source: inside box)

name: Derriba la Letra
description:
